fields.headline: Soul in need of a lift
fields.standfirst:
Jamelia
Hanover Grand
London
**
fields.trailText:
Pop
Jamelia
Hanover Grand
London
**
fields.body:
Warming up for Jamelia's debut show, a DJ deafens us with modern American R'n'B: hits from Destiny's Child, Q-Tip and Sisqo. Jamelia is a 19-year-old Brummie, hailed as Britain's R'n'B queen with chart successes Money and Call Me, but it's such glossy US expressions that she aspires to.

Wailing sirens signal Jamelia's presence. Coloured spotlights sweep the stage as various session musicians and backing singers assemble. Does Jamelia make the flamboyant entrance worthy of a young R'n'B diva? No; she creeps in from the side, grinning bashfully. She looks fantastic, though: a vision in diamante, and her vocals cut smoothly and sweetly through a funky opener.

Jamelia's set draws on her well-received album, Drama; the problem, however, is that drama is what she lacks. Things really go awry when she performs Call Me. It has a plush soul melody, with a sharply-choreographed video. Onstage, however, we're distracted by Jamelia's pubescent backing dancers, bounding all over the stage (and the song) like excitable puppies, affecting "manly" expressions. Luckily, they disappear for a bit after that, but the awkwardness persists. Although Jamelia exudes charm, vacillating from American vocals to introduce numbers in Birmingham brogue, she can't bring herself to make eye contact with the audience.

Choosing this glamorous club venue for Jamelia's debut is a mistake; its age restrictions exclude the kids who buy her records (although, sadly, it hasn't deterred her backing dancers). Jamelia is essentially a pop star. She's an approachable pin-up and sings catchy tunes, but certain moments during this show almost swallow themselves with self- consciousness. Like when Jamelia raps that her "Room 101" is "a little hideaway that nobody knows" (so it's not an Orwellian nightmare, then). Or when a wooden guest vocalist joins her to cover Barbra Streisand's Guilty; he gets his chest out, but at least he looks past the age of consent.

Jamelia plays her Baroque-swingbeat hit Money as an encore (with ragga hero Beenie Man on backing tapes), but she's clearly had more enjoyable appearances on CDUK. She'll prove she's capable of greater things when she performs with a tighter ensemble to a more responsive pop crowd. Right now, merely emulating American acts makes British R'n'B more shopping precinct than ghetto fabulous.

fields.headline: Sometimes sublime
fields.standfirst:
Betty Buckley
Donmar Warehouse
London
***
fields.trailText:
Betty Buckley
Donmar Warehouse
London
***
fields.body:
When Betty Buckley walks on to the Donmar stage to begin her sad cabaret, you are aware of her ageless beauty that avoids the selfconsciousness of glamour. She closes her gig with Memory from the musical Cats. The song retroactively haunts the evening, for this is very much Buckley's own memoir of a career that transformed a girl from Fort Worth, Texas, into a huge star in the US and something of a cult figure here.

Buckley's British appearances have been sporadic. She calls London her second home, though she hasn't sung here for five years. Her greatest claim to British fame is that she starred as Norma Desmond in Lloyd Webber's Sunset Boulevard, which she also sang on Broadway. She returned to the role at various points in the evening, to the whooping delight of the audience, capturing the character very much as Gloria Swanson originally incarnated her - a faded diva of yesteryear, whose allure nevertheless transcends the degraded present in which she now finds herself.

A note of nostalgia reigns throughout. Buckley's repertoire is astonishingly wide, ranging from standards by Rodgers and Hart, and Lerner and Lowe, country and western numbers, and lieder-ish art songs to texts by Emily Dickinson and Edna St Vincent Millay, written for her by the composer Ricky Ian Gordon. Their dominant theme is one of loss, and of the dogged persistence of memory, which causes us to recall what we would prefer to consign to oblivion.

Her vocal range is comparatively narrow, swivelling between a gentle, lived-in sweetness at once innocent and wise, and a rasping, domineering fortissimo. Her diction is at times less than admirably clear and her repartee with the audience carries with it a whiff of psychobabble.

Bathed in a murky pool of light, she whispers Mary Chapin Carpenter's haunting Come On, Come On, her hands raking the air in fragile desperation. She desentimentalises Memory in a way that is unforgettable, twisting her body into a shape half-human and half-feline, her voice ricocheting with the anguish of loveless homelessness.

It's an uneven evening, though it brings with it moments of greatness which make it all worthwhile. We don't always hear the best of Buckley throughout the evening - but when we do, the results are magnificent.

 Until September 2. Box office: 020-7369 1732.

fields.headline: In the grip of the spirits
fields.standfirst:
Clear Water
Barbican,
London
***
fields.trailText:
Theatre
Clear Water
Barbican,
London
***
fields.body:
The Barbican's rather hit-and-miss Bite season continues with the British premiere of Christopher Rodriguez's Trinidad tale of past grievances and present lives, and the way we must understand our history to forge our futures. This is very much fledgling work and does look slightly exposed in the Barbican Pit, but it is good to see black experience taking centre stage at the theatre. For all its flaws, this dense, ragged play has an almost carnivalesque, hallucinatory power, and is never less than interesting.

Joel, abroad studying for almost 10 years, is drawn back to Trinidad and to the house where he was brought up by his grandmother, a believer in the ancient Yoruba religion that has mingled with local Catholic practices to create a strange hybrid.

As a child Joel was apparently possessed by spirits and almost driven mad. On his return he is haunted by the past and drawn once more into rivalry with Garth, the young man he believes to be his cousin, who is now a singer with a band that plays rapso (a mix of rap, calypso and salsa). Joel soon falls prey to la Diablesse, the devil woman of Trinidad folklore, who appears here like a wrecked Marie Antoinette figure, a witty witch who "keeps these niggers in their place" with fear and superstition.

The stage is set for a showdown between old beliefs and new, as Joel and Garth learn to resolve their differences and family rifts are healed. This is all far too neatly achieved, with lots of speeches that tie the message of the play up in ribbons, but there is fun to be had along the way with a slick production that has a strong sense of the importance of ritual and an even greater sense of rhythm. Chanting, drumming, rapso are used to stunning effect, creating a mesmerising backcloth to a piece of theatrical storytelling that is all about the importance of oral tradition and memory in a world where the rush of the new roughly shoves the past aside.

Until September 9. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

fields.headline: New post office bank plan
fields.standfirst:
Abbey National puts forward alternative version of government's proposals for universal bank

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Banks could have their own counters in post offices under a scheme being devised by Abbey National to encourage the government to scrap its plans for a universal bank.
fields.body:
Banks could have their own counters in post offices under a scheme being devised by Abbey National to encourage the government to scrap its plans for a universal bank.

The proposal, which the high street bank hopes to discuss with ministers soon, would see post offices offering a range of banking facilities such as cheque payments and cash withdrawals.

Andrew Pople, Abbey National's managing director of retail banking, said it was still "an embryonic idea" but described a possible scenario where the bank is the last one in town. "Why doesn't the local post office take it over and run it as a single unit?" he said.

Mr Pople insisted that the plan would not see branch closures by the back door."Even if it was closure by the back door, it's got to be better than closures altogether," he added. However, a spokesman for the Communication Workers Union, which represents 180,000 postal workers, accused the banks of looking to the taxpayer to prop up their operations. "It's a government subsidy for the high street banks in terms of giving them access to sites. The government might as well subsidise the Post Office instead."

Abbey will promote the idea as an alternative to the post office-based universal bank which the high street banks are reluctant to support, claiming that it could carry the stigma of a "poor people's bank" and be expensive to run.

The idea has been spawned from Abbey National's early experience of franchising its own branches. It is the first constructive proposal devised by any of the banks since they refused to participate in the scheme for the financially excluded.

The universal bank is designed to solve two problems for the government. It throws a lifeline to the post office net work as the government axes one of its main revenue streams - by paying social security benefits directly into bank accounts.

It also tackles the issue of providing accounts to people who do not have access to financial services facilities.

But the banks are reluctant to back it, seeing it as a costly plan and a duplication of the government's efforts to tackle social exclusion as the banks are already cooperating with Treasury instructions to provide basic, no credit bank accounts for the financially excluded.

Mr Pople plans to raise the issue at a meeting with ministers next month. He calls for the meeting in a letter, obtained by the Guardian, in which he insists that the bank already has accounts for the socially excluded and for which the bank has 650,000 customers.

"If they want to talk about the basic bank accounts we will use it as an opportunity to raise the franchise idea. We've got experience of the franchising and may have a proposal which is a bit of a win-win for every one," Mr Pople says.

"We've got basic bank accounts and got large numbers of customers for them, and the Department of Social Security has been referring customers to us anyway," the letter adds.

Mr Pople sees the plan as giving the government a viable economic use for post offices, that will also bring in useful cash for the Post Office.

Alan Johnson, the trade minister with responsibility for the Post Office, last night reiterated the government's commitment to developing a universal bank but said Abbey National's proposal could be part of that scheme

The Post Office is due to present its business plan for the universal bank to the DTI next month and is devising a new brand for the accounts while at the same time trying to quash the banks' concerns about the cost of the plan.

fields.headline: Banks miss Pin numbers deadline
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Twenty-one banks and building societies were yesterday named by a financial watchdog for failing to meet a deadline for allowing customers to choose their own personal identification numbers for their debit and credit cards.
fields.body:
Twenty-one banks and building societies were yesterday named by a financial watchdog for failing to meet a deadline for allowing customers to choose their own personal identification numbers for their debit and credit cards.

The 21 include Lloyds TSB, Bank of Scotland, Sainsbury's Bank and Bradford & Bingley building society.

Yesterday's announcement by the Banking Code Standards Board coincides with renewed debate about banking security and card fraud. The new rule was introduced by the banking industry to help customers remember their personal identification numbers so that they do not write them down, thereby increasing the risk of this information falling into the wrong hands.

All banks and building societies subscribing to the voluntary code of banking practice were supposed by July 1 this year to allow customers to change their Pin number to one which they select themselves. Most have complied but 21 have not yet carried out the necessary IT systems changes to allow this to happen, said the BCSB, which monitors compliance with the code.

The institutions were given the deadline three years ago, and the public have the right to know which institutions have not met it, the watchdog said. The change was made following pressure from consumer groups.

The 21 institutions have been set new deadlines ranging from October this year to March 31 2001. Several million Lloyds TSB customers with debit cards are among those affected, though its credit card holders and former customers of TSB are unaffected. More than 2m Bank of Scotland customers will also be unable to choose their own Pin for another few months.

fields.headline: Anglo-Welsh dilemma for Canadian wunderkind
fields.trailText: Unlikely though it may sound, Owen Hargreaves, a 19-year-old Bayern Munich midfield player born in Canada, has, thanks to his parents, become the subject of a tug-of-love between England and Wales.
fields.body:
Unlikely though it may sound, Owen Hargreaves, a 19-year-old Bayern Munich midfield player born in Canada, has, thanks to his parents, become the subject of a tug-of-love between England and Wales.

Hargreaves, who has broken into the German champions' first team this season, was named in the Wales Under-21 squad to travel to Belarus next week for their first European Championship qualifier. But having been "invited" by England to become involved with them instead, he has pulled out of the Welsh squad.

Hargreaves, who has a Welsh mother and an English father, has been involved in the Wales set-up for three years and has played for the Welsh youth side in friendlies, which do not commit him to anyone. But if he had agreed to play for the Under-21s next week he would have been able to play only for Wales for the rest of his career.

The Wales Under-21 coach Jimmy Shoulder said: "We have unearthed the lad and done all the hard work, but now he is unsure so the right advice is to not commit yourself. We hope that eventually he decides to play for Wales.

"He is a very assured young man and it's clear that he won't commit himself unless there is a full cap at the end of it and he can be sure he will not be getting just a couple of games and that's all."

Lennie Lawrence, 52, the former Middlesbrough and Charlton manager who was sacked by Luton two months ago, is set for a return to management as a replacement for Alan Buckley at Grimsby Town.

Leicester City's assistant manager John Robertson has left Filbert Street by mutual consent and is expected to take up a similar post alongside the former Leicester manager Martin O'Neill at Celtic.

Real Madrid have left Steve McManaman out of their squad for the European Supercup against Galatasaray in Monaco tomorrow.

England Under-21 squad (v Georgia, Riverside Stadium, next Thursday): Bramble (Ipswich), Brown (Manchester United), Campbell (Middlesbrough), Carrick (West Ham), Chadwick (Manchester United), A Cole (Arsenal), J Cole (West Ham), Dunn (Blackburn), Jeffers (Everton), Naylor (Wolves), Newton (West Ham), Parker (Charlton), Prutton (Nottingham Forest), Robinson (Leeds), A Smith (Leeds), T Smith (Watford), Stockdale (Middlesbrough), Terry (Chelsea), Thirlwell (Sunderland), Vassell (Aston Villa), Weaver (Manchester City), Young (Spurs).

webTitle: Cole the man to lead Keegan revival

fields.headline: Cole the man to lead Keegan revival
fields.trailText: David Lacey reports as Kevin Keegan prepares to announce his squad to face France in Paris on Saturday week.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan's powers of resuscitation are about to be tested as never before. Compared with revivifying Newcastle United and breathing fresh life into Fulham, the job of restoring credibility to the England team after the failures of Euro 2000 will demand something more complex than turning water into wine.

Keegan will embark on his task today when he announces a squad for the friendly against France, the world and European champions, in Paris on Saturday week. The fixture reciprocates the French visit to Wembley in February last year when Howard Wilkinson was briefly in charge after the dismissal of Glenn Hoddle.

Given the almost contemptuous ease with which France won 2-0 that night, as well as England's pitiful showing in Euro 2000, a visit to St-Denis just now smacks of masochism.

Keegan was let off lightly by the critics when his team sloped home early from Euro 2000 but, like Ron Greenwood, Bobby Robson and Graham Taylor before him, he will be spared little if a poor performance in the European championship is not redeemed by early signs that England will make a better fist of qualifying for the next World Cup.

That is easier said than done. Keegan has only the French match to work on a team for the opening World Cup qualifier against Germany at Wembley on October 7, with England due to face Finland in Helsinki four days later.

The 1-0 victory over the Germans in Charleroi offered England a flickering moment of optimism amid the gathering gloom but by beating Spain 4-1 in a friendly last week Germany, responding positively to the 12-month appointment of Rudi Völler as coach, have recovered some self-esteem.

Keegan has basic groundwork in hand. He has to find someone to lead the team and someone else to lead the attack. For the past four years both roles have been filled by Alan Shearer but he has retired from international football.

The captaincy would appear to be the least of Keegan's problems. He has already intimated that Tony Adams will wear the armband as England set about qualifying for the World Cup in Japan and South Korea in two years' time.

Adams has always presented as authoritative a presence on the field for England as he does for Arsenal. Yet, if he continues to be plagued by the sort of injuries that restricted him to one match in Euro 2000, Keegan will have to look elsewhere.

Not that there is a queue of alternatives. Sol Campbell looks the most likely option although under Keegan he has struggled to find the form that blossomed under Hoddle. One newspaper has quoted Shearer as pleading for the captaincy to be given to David Beckham. There is Geordie humour for you.

Replacing Shearer's goalscoring potential is well-nigh impossible in the short term. The supply of strikers who can find the net once every two internationals on average while winning more than 50 caps will always be limited.

With form impossible to assess so early, Keegan will doubtless round up the usual suspects for Paris and hope that Beckham and Paul Scholes will provide inspired support for whoever plays up front. The argument that he should abandon two strikers and opt for, say, Michael Owen with Scholes playing off him is bound to resurface.

So will the demand for Andy Cole to be recalled now that Shearer is not available. At Old Trafford against Newcastle on Sunday Cole offered Keegan an excellent example of his ability to link up play. He also scored United's second goal after a quick exchange of passes with Ryan Giggs.

Keegan left Cole out of his Euro 2000 squad, explaining that the player had not been sure about his fitness. If Cole is not in today's squad, however, more questions will be asked.

fields.bodyText: Kevin Keegan's powers of resuscitation are about to be tested as never before. Compared with revivifying Newcastle United and breathing fresh life into Fulham, the job of restoring credibility to the England team after the failures of Euro 2000 will demand something more complex than turning water into wine. Keegan will embark on his task today when he announces a squad for the friendly against France, the world and European champions, in Paris on Saturday week. The fixture reciprocates the French visit to Wembley in February last year when Howard Wilkinson was briefly in charge after the dismissal of Glenn Hoddle. Given the almost contemptuous ease with which France won 2-0 that night, as well as England's pitiful showing in Euro 2000, a visit to St-Denis just now smacks of masochism. Keegan was let off lightly by the critics when his team sloped home early from Euro 2000 but, like Ron Greenwood, Bobby Robson and Graham Taylor before him, he will be spared little if a poor performance in the European championship is not redeemed by early signs that England will make a better fist of qualifying for the next World Cup. That is easier said than done. Keegan has only the French match to work on a team for the opening World Cup qualifier against Germany at Wembley on October 7, with England due to face Finland in Helsinki four days later. The 1-0 victory over the Germans in Charleroi offered England a flickering moment of optimism amid the gathering gloom but by beating Spain 4-1 in a friendly last week Germany, responding positively to the 12-month appointment of Rudi Völler as coach, have recovered some self-esteem. Keegan has basic groundwork in hand. He has to find someone to lead the team and someone else to lead the attack. For the past four years both roles have been filled by Alan Shearer but he has retired from international football. The captaincy would appear to be the least of Keegan's problems. He has already intimated that Tony Adams will wear the armband as England set about qualifying for the World Cup in Japan and South Korea in two years' time. Adams has always presented as authoritative a presence on the field for England as he does for Arsenal. Yet, if he continues to be plagued by the sort of injuries that restricted him to one match in Euro 2000, Keegan will have to look elsewhere. Not that there is a queue of alternatives. Sol Campbell looks the most likely option although under Keegan he has struggled to find the form that blossomed under Hoddle. One newspaper has quoted Shearer as pleading for the captaincy to be given to David Beckham. There is Geordie humour for you. Replacing Shearer's goalscoring potential is well-nigh impossible in the short term. The supply of strikers who can find the net once every two internationals on average while winning more than 50 caps will always be limited. With form impossible to assess so early, Keegan will doubtless round up the usual suspects for Paris and hope that Beckham and Paul Scholes will provide inspired support for whoever plays up front. The argument that he should abandon two strikers and opt for, say, Michael Owen with Scholes playing off him is bound to resurface. So will the demand for Andy Cole to be recalled now that Shearer is not available. At Old Trafford against Newcastle on Sunday Cole offered Keegan an excellent example of his ability to link up play. He also scored United's second goal after a quick exchange of passes with Ryan Giggs. Keegan left Cole out of his Euro 2000 squad, explaining that the player had not been sure about his fitness. If Cole is not in today's squad, however, more questions will be asked. fields.headline: The best wake-up scene: X-Men
fields.trailText: Having been attacked by a band of malign mutants, Logan, aka Wolverine (Hugh Jackman), wakes up in what appears to be a laboratory. Rising to his feet, he tries to find out where he is.
fields.body:
Having been attacked by a band of malign mutants, Logan, aka Wolverine (Hugh Jackman), wakes up in what appears to be a laboratory. Rising to his feet, he tries to find out where he is.

As he sprints through a labyrinth of corridors, a disembodied voice beckons him: "This way" and "Over here". Finally, he arrives in the offices of Professor Charles Xavier (Patrick Stewart). Xavier dismisses his pupils, one of whom collects her books, then walks through the closed office door. Xavier manoeuvres his wheelchair to the front of his desk.

"I'm Charles Xavier. Would you like some breakfast?"

"Where am I?"

"Westchester, New York. You were attacked. My people brought you here for medical attention."

"I don't need medical attention."

The office door swings open: a pair of X-Men enter, Storm (Halle Berry) and Cyclops (James Marsden).

"Ah, Logan, I'd like you to meet Ororo Munroe, also called Storm, and this is Scott Summers, also called Cyclops. They saved your life."

Logan looks deeply unimpressed. Xavier continues.

"We're in my school for the gifted. You'll be safe here from Magneto."

"What's a Magneto?"

"A very powerful mutant who believes a war is brewing between mutants and the rest of humanity. The man who attacked you is an associate of his called Sabretooth."

"Sabretooth?"

A sneer creeps into Logan's voice. "And what do they call you? Wheels?"

See also: The Godfather, Sleeper, Alien, The Wizard Of Oz

Don't see also: Awakenings

Pointless Trivia: In his leisure time, Hugh Jackman enjoys playing the piano and going windsurfing.

webTitle: Glass tops off whirlwind through County ranks

fields.headline: Glass tops off whirlwind through County ranks
fields.trailText:
Newcastle 3 - 2 Derby
Goals from two home debutants and a forgotten man beat a stubborn Derby side at St James's Park.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at St James's Park
fields.body:
In the end last night was one of wild celebration in the Toon as goals from two home debutants and a forgotten man beat a stubborn Derby side. Not even the dismissal of Warren Barton for hauling back Deon Burton or Seth Johnson's late second could spoil the party.

Summer building work has increased the capacity to more than 52,000 and Tyneside hosted its largest crowd since 1973 with the darling of the Gallowgate that day, Malcolm Macdonald, back to mark the occasion. It was clear they expected Derby, without six regulars, to be torn apart - Rams to the slaughter.

The breathtaking start suggested as much. With four minutes gone Kieron Dyer fed Nolberto Solano down the right. The Peruvian tricked his way past Danny Higginbotham and crossed for Carl Cort who, under challenge from Otto Bragstad, headed into the corner of the net.

But, while the Newcastle whirlwind continued to rage, it rapidly blew out of control. Burton might have levelled had Nicos Dabizas not intevened and, when United did emerge from midfield with the ball, Solano's pass was just too strong for the on-rushing Dyer.

Rhythm was further disrupted by Cort's withdrawal after the half-hour as County's midfield steadily took control. Stefano Eranio teased his way past two players before curling an effort over the bar and Burton should have done better moments later when through on goal.

The crowd, starved of their goal feast, vented their frustrations. Their disappointment was complete on the stroke of half-time as Johnson's innocuous ball into the area caught the home defence dithering and Branko Strupar calmly placed an equaliser beyond Shay Given.

But parity was retained only for the duration of the interval. A minute after the break Stephen Glass's cross was half-cleared by the beleaguered Bragstad and Cordone nipped in to restore United's lead.

This time there would be no revival. Glass, who spent most of last season on the treatment table or the transfer list and was seizing his chance with some glee, saw to that by curling a magnificent left-foot shot into the top corner from 30 yards.

Higginbotham's last ditch challenge prevented Alan Shearer adding a fourth but Derby's defence had long since descended into blind panic. Macdonald must have fancied his chances.

webTitle: City off the mark with Wanchope hat-trick

fields.headline: City off the mark with Wanchope hat-trick
fields.trailText:
Man City 4 - 2 Sunderland
City squandered a two-goal lead before Paulo Wanchope completed his Maine Road debut with a match-winning hat-trick.
fields.body:
Manchester City will surely have to strengthen their defence in the coming weeks, having now conceded six goals in two matches, but it might have been so much worse. Having established a 2-0 half-time lead they duly squandered it through gross defensive profligacy before Paulo Wanchope, a City hero if ever there was one, struck two late goals to complete a match-winning hat-trick as the Blues welcomed back Premiership football here last night.

If there had been any trepidation among the City supporters it was quickly cast aside with Wanchope scoring his first goal for the club as early as the third minute. Sunderland allowed George Weah to create space, something he is particularly adept at, on the left-hand side and their defences were ripped apart.

Weah, taking the ball from Mark Kennedy, crossed to the far post where Wanchope, from an acute angle, hit a rising shot beyond Jürgen Macho, who continued to replace the injured Thomas Sorensen in the Sunderland goal after coming on at half-time during the 1-0 defeat of Arsenal on the opening day of the season. There was an immediate and uncontrolled outbreak of delirium at Maine Road - joy mixed with relief which told its own potent story.

With Malcolm Allison and Francis Lee in the directors' box there was even an echo of the good old days and City came mightily close to increasing their lead just a few minutes later when a Kennedy free-kick, curved in from the left, was brilliantly anticipated by Weah, although he could not quite direct his header which skimmed wide.

Gradually Sunderland began to settle as the shock of the new began to wear off a little. But any progress they tried to make through the middle was disrupted by stern tackling from Alfe Inge Haaland and Kevin Horlock. Kevin Phillips was hobbling when he lifted himself from one such challenge, although before his side could respond to City's vigour City went two goals ahead.

It was Weah again who unravelled the Sunderland defence, creating sudden space for himself before passing precisely to Wanchope. For an instant it seemed the former Derby and West Ham striker might go for glory again himself. However he intelligently squared the ball for Haaland to score with ease.

These were riches indeed to City, coming off their 4-0 defeat against Charlton last Saturday when their manager Joe Royal admitted his side had played like strangers. There had only been one team in it during the first half, with Sunderland failing to create a single opening of note. But all was to change quite dramatically.

In the 64th minute a long cross by Chris Makin from the right was headed in by the former City striker Niall Quinn as if he had been on the practice pitch. Three minutes later Phillips struck a splendid equaliser with City's defences again shredded.

It was a hard and early lesson for City and there were real fears among their supporters that their side's early and exhilarating opening might all be thrown away. But with Sunderland searching for a winner, and clearly believing they could get it, Wanchope struck for a second time in the 79th minute to restore City's lead, his sudden burst of pace being decisive against a rather laboured Sunderland back four. Two minutes from time he completed his hat-trick to clinch the points.

fields.headline: Seven-up Lampitt scents promotion
fields.standfirst:
Worcestershire 338 & 36-1
Warwickshire 142 & 231
Worcestershire win by 9 wickets
County Championship Second Division points table
fields.trailText:
Worcestershire 338 & 36-1
Warwickshire 142 & 231
Worcestershire win by 9 wickets
fields.body:
The old rivals Warwickshire had been banished in three days, Stuart Lampitt had a career-best seven wickets in an innings to mark his benefit year, and Worcestershire were back among the Second Division's promotion trio. But such is the scramble to escape this most balanced of leagues that nobody dares predict how long they will stay there.

Well, almost nobody. Across the way in L'Aroma the restaurant's avuncular Greek-Cypriot owner Dennis has accurately predicted Worcestershire's fortunes since Ian Botham was in his heyday. He does this not by watching the cricket - he has not seen a day's play in his life - but by leaning against the bar and listening to his customers.

When the customer was Botham, insights were easy. Large bill = season going well. Very large bill = season going badly. Now he needs to be more astute. "Ah, my good friend," he said (his universal greeting), "last year, bad. This year," and here he allowed himself a throaty rasp resembling an old steam engine, "this year very close, but I tell you they do it."

Warwickshire can recover ground by winning next week's Edgbaston return but they should be grateful that, at mention of their name, Dennis's interest faded. This was a mediocre display by a side mesmerised by this Saturday's NatWest Trophy final. Facing the near-certainty of a follow-on at the start of the third day, all they envisaged was a little face-saving.

The last two first-innings wickets held up Worcestershire for 10 minutes, at the end of which Chris Liptrot, a former England Under-19 who "lost it" completely in early season, had a career-best six for 44 and Worcestershire a lead of 196. Then it was left to Lampitt to stuff the Bears as quickly as Dennis was stuffing the dolmades.

Lampitt, now 34, has been an unstinting servant, surpassing 5,000 first-class runs and 500 wickets, and turning many a one-day game too with his manoeuvrable medium pace. He wrapped up Warwickshire's innings in four overs after tea by twice taking wickets with successive balls.

First to fall were Dougie Brown and Graeme Welch, the latter collecting a pair as he was leg-before to his first delivery; he has taken only three first-class wickets in a miserable season. Lampitt concluded by dismissing Keith Piper and Ed Giddins, whose compliant slog to mid-off was that of a No11 who saw no cause for further delay.

There had been better earlier. Michael Powell thrashed Alamgir Sheriyar to cover in the first over but Anurag Singh, with 15 fours and a six in his 79 from 93 balls, and Trevor Penney, with a bland half-century, ensured some entertainment on a beautiful summer's day.

fields.trailText:
Glamorgan 718-3 dec
Sussex 112-5
fields.body:
Steve James became the first Glamorgan batsman to score a triple century and the Welsh county posted their highest total since they were admitted to the County Championship in 1921 as the Sussex attack was torn apart yesterday at Colwyn Bay for a second consecutive day.

James was unbeaten on 309 when Matthew Maynard finally put Sussex out of their misery by declaring in mid-afternoon, and all this after Sussex had asked Glamorgan to bat first in this Second Division fixture.

In defence of the Sussex captain, Chris Adams, it should be pointed out that a year ago at the same ground Nottinghamshire won the toss, chose to bat on a slightly damp wicket and collapsed to nine for six.

By the time Glamorgan batted the pitch had dried out and they rattled up 648 for four, the county record that they beat yesterday. James made a mere 259 out out.

Yesterday he was again a model of vigilance, concentration, shot selection and perfect timing during his 602 minutes at the wicket.

He beat the previous Glamorgan best of 287, scored by Emrys Davies against Gloucestershire at Newport in 1939, and earlier became the first Glamorgan batsman to score five double hundreds for the county. The 374 he put on with Matthew Elliott on the first day was Glamorgan's highest opening stand and their second highest ever.

Needing to score 569 simply to avoid being asked to follow on, Sussex could scarcely have made a worse start to their reply and lost their first two wickets for 11 runs inside the opening five overs before closing the second day on 112 for five. Adams, 55 not out, will have a lot on his shoulders when play resumes today.

fields.headline: Crawley spices up Kumble encounter
fields.standfirst:
Leicestershire 372
Lancashire 334-3
County Championship First Division table
fields.trailText:
Leicestershire 372
Lancashire 334-3
fields.body:
Modern English batsmanship, by and large, attracts the sort of notices associated with uncompromising socialists and any movie starring Jean-Claude van Damme. All the more reason, therefore, to have been here yesterday. David Graveney was, although whether what he witnessed provoked delight or dismay is another kettle of cod entirely.

On a sluggish pitch whose occasionally subterranean bounce is expected to make batting last a fraught affair, Mike Atherton, John Crawley and Andrew Flintoff put Lancashire in sight of a significant lead in their vividly contrasting ways. Crawley alone turned control into a century but the spectacle was no less hypnotic for that.

Obliged, seemingly, to accommodate a spinner at the Oval - how Laker, Lock and Wardle would have reacted to such a state of affairs one shudders to think - the England selectors could always go on form and do the brave thing: drop Atherton.

Troubled initially by Jon Dakin's pace, he never got out of second gear yet pushed, steered and nudged his way to 48 in 51 overs before being trapped by Phil DeFreitas's grubber. For England to take on Courtney and Curtly without the master of stubbornness still seems too risky.

Outscoring Atherton four-to-one in a 97-run partnership, Crawley all but toyed with Anil Kumble, endorsing the conviction held by some that overlooking his expertise against spin on the subcontinent would be even riskier.

His partnership with Flintoff, who biffed 55 off 60 balls, added 89 at nearly seven an over and was akin to being confronted with a set meal offering the best of Thai and British. Where Crawley is all subtle spices and light noodles, Flintoff is strictly meat and potatoes; Kumble undid him, as he always appeared destined to.

To see the Indian sans moustache - the result of a vow at Canterbury that resulted in his most productive match of a so-so summer - is shocking enough. Now he has promised, should he make a century, to grow a beard of Sherwood Forest proportions, so the abrupt end to his sturdy knock, bowled by Glen Chapple, was bad news for those despairing of the current rash of slapheads and hankering after the new WG.

After the way Kumble bowled, mind, that upper lip may soon be restored to its familiar shrubbery. Playing into Crawley's deft hands, he strayed all too frequently to leg and waited 19 overs for his sole wicket. Perhaps this novel attempt to reverse the Samson principle is wearing off.

Amid it all buzzed the Chris Lewis grapevine. The former England all-rounder is said to be so fed up with what he sees as the reluctance of officialdom to take his allegations of bookmaker approaches seriously that he is threatening to retire in order to "write" a book naming the England players he was asked to approach by a bookmaker.

Not that Leicestershire would be distraught. Given that a hip ailment has restricted him to fewer than 100 championship overs, Lewis has been about as useful as Banquo's ghost, and only marginally more visible. Patience is thinning.

"It'll all come out in the wash," said Leicestershire's coach Jack Birkenshaw, somewhat obliquely. One can only guess whether Lewis is seeking revenge for a perceived slight, trying to earn a few bob for his dotage or has genuine cause to shatter English cricket's holier-than-thou self-image.

webTitle: Emburey will be too late to save Durham

fields.headline: Emburey will be too late to save Durham
fields.standfirst:
Derbyshire 167 and 346-6
Durham 144
County Championship First Division table
fields.trailText:
Derbyshire 167 and 346-6
Durham 144
fields.body:
Norman Gifford and Graham Gooch, the Durham brains trust, have cooked up a cunning plan to bring John Emburey out of first-class retirement for their last game of the season against Surrey at the Oval if it is crucial to their hopes of avoiding relegation.

Emburey, now 48, took four wickets against Durham in this year's NatWest Trophy in his new role as player-coach of Berkshire, and yesterday it was hard to deny that Durham's attack could use a lift as Derbyshire were allowed to recover from 121 for six with unbeaten centuries from Dominic Cork and Matthew Dowman.

The flaw in the plan is that with Kent on course to beat Hampshire in Canterbury, Durham's survival hopes will virtually disappear here unless their batsmen can conjure up an unlikely win; they are already 369 runs behind.

Things were going swimmingly as Simon Brown, Melvyn Betts and Steve Harmison helped themselves to two cheap wickets apiece, aided by further inept batting by Derbyshire's top order.

But Dowman, a 26-year-old left-hander who was released by Nottinghamshire last year after failing to fulfil his early promise, was then joined by Cork to add an unbroken 225, only 16 short of Derbyshire's record for the seventh wicket and a record for any wicket for Derbyshire against Durham.

Dowman's previous century for Derbyshire, against Hampshire three weeks ago, was surely one of the luckiest of all time, as he was dropped six times and the ball twice hit his stumps only for the bails to remain unmoved.

Yesterday he offered only one half-chance on 41, off Simon Katich's first chinaman, which flew between wicketkeeper and slip, although he was troubled on several occasions by Harmison's raw pace.

David Graveney, England's chairman of selectors, was present for the early part of the day and could only have been impressed by a slippery delivery from the rangy 21-year-old which struck Dowman on the hand and shoulder, another which nipped back and cut him in half, and finally a brute of a bouncer which flew off Cork's ribs for four leg-byes.

But they were Durham's only bright moments in 67 overs of toil, with Cork seizing the opportunity to scoff at the notion of his being omitted for next week's Oval Test, and also to demonstrate his continuing commitment to his county to a good-sized, sun-baked crowd.

Dowman took 219 balls to reach three figures, the last 18 on a nervous 99, and although Cork needed 27 balls fewer he was also made to work hard for his 100th run, finally celebrating it more expansively than his partner by punching the air and kissing his helmet.

Surprisingly it is already a career best for the lanky all-rounder, beating his 104 in Cheltenham in 1993, and only the fourth century of his career: the way he played yesterday, with 16 boundaries driven crisply off front and back foot, suggested there should have been several more.

fields.headline: Wenger accused of intimidation
fields.trailText: Arsène Wenger faces becoming the first casualty of the English game's promised disciplinary crackdown after being charged yesterday by the Football Association with "alleged threatening behaviour and physical intimidation" to the fourth official after Arsenal's bitter defeat at Sunderland on the Premiership's opening day last Saturday.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger faces becoming the first casualty of the English game's promised disciplinary crackdown after being charged yesterday by the Football Association with "alleged threatening behaviour and physical intimidation" to the fourth official after Arsenal's bitter defeat at Sunderland on the Premiership's opening day last Saturday.

Arsenal, already reeling from the Patrick Vieira affair, must now suffer the embarrassment of their French manager, one of the game's most respected figures, being hauled into the FA dock and, if found guilty, condemned to possibly a 12-match touchline ban and a fine of four weeks' wages under the new guidelines.

The disrepute charge follows a report from the fourth official, Paul Taylor, to the FA in which he claims he was involved in "an incident" with Wenger , who was incensed at Vieira's last-minute sending-off at the Stadium of Light.

It is understood that Wenger, who was highly critical of the referee Steve Dunn's performance in his team's 1-0 defeat, was attempting to break up a scuffle in the tunnel between an Arsenal and a Sunderland player before the manager remonstrated with Taylor.

An FA statement added little more clarification, speaking of "an incident after the match in the players' tunnel close to the Arsenal dressing-room. The charge relates to his [Wenger's] alleged improper conduct and to bringing the game into disrepute."

Arsenal, who also learned yesterday that Gilles Grimandi's apparent stamp on Liverpool's Gary McAllister in Monday's match at Highbury will be investigated by the FA, were clearly taken aback by the accusations against their manager, who denies the charges.

A statement from the north London club said: "Arsène is certainly surprised by the charge. He is looking forward to providing the FA with a detailed explanation of events."

So now the erudite, professorial Wenger, who has vigorously defended most of the 31 Arsenal players sent off in his four-year reign at Highbury, must now defend himself in what is a major examination of the FA's will and potentially the highest-profile case of the entire season.

Most surprising, and disturbing, is the accusation against Wenger of "physical intimidation" of the fourth official. Under the new guidelines "jostling or holding" with a match official will lead to at least a 12-match ban and a fine of four weeks' wages. Threatening behaviour or words towards match officials carries a three-match ban and a fine of a week's wages.

Ironically, when the crackdown was announced early this month Wenger was highly sceptical, predicting that it would work only "until Christmas", citing last season when a rash of cautions in the first few months led to complaints and a general refereeing relaxation on cards in the second half of the campaign.

But the FA's chief executive Adam Crozier immediately retorted: "We will not get bored of it by Christmas. This is not a three-month wonder. We will be absolutely rigid about seeing it through because we have to be. The only way people will learn is if we do that."

Grimandi will shortly learn if he too is to face an FA charge after his alleged stamp on McAllister is examined by the newly formed three-man video panel, which has also been asked to review the sending-off of McAllister in Monday's match by Graham Poll after an appeal by Liverpool.

Poll has already watched a match video himself and presented the FA with another complication, admitting that he made a mistake over Dietmar Hamann's second yellow card, for an innocuous challenge on Robert Pires, and has asked for it to be rescinded.

But Poll vehemently defended his red card for McAllister and second yellow for Vieira, saying they were "absolutely correct".

"The offence by McAllister was what is commonly known as an over-the-top tackle," said Poll. Vieira's challenge on Hamann "must be deemed as at the least reckless".

The Tring official added: "The amount of criticism levelled at me from certain quarters has left me disappointed as we are always asked to protect players. Having done so, I expected a lot more support from those who claim to know better."

fields.headline: Newcastle United
fields.trailText: This season has got to be a better one for Newcastle United. After all the last one, at least the first half of it, couldn't have been any worse. Rob Lee without a squad number, Sunderland stealing victory in a sodden St James' Park, the cold war between Shearer and Gullit - it doesn't bear thinking about. But now that Bobby Robson's in charge, the team have a new spirit and, it seems, an understanding of how to play to a tactical design. And with the newly expanded St James' set to open it's all looking rosy for the Mags. Isn't it?
fields.body:
This season has got to be a better one for Newcastle United. After all the last one, at least the first half of it, couldn't have been any worse. Rob Lee without a squad number, Sunderland stealing victory in a sodden St James' Park, the cold war between Shearer and Gullit - it doesn't bear thinking about. But now that Bobby Robson's in charge, the team have a new spirit and, it seems, an understanding of how to play to a tactical design. And with the newly expanded St James' set to open it's all looking rosy for the Mags. Isn't it?

Well, pretty much. There's certainly no disputing Bobby Robson's coaching credentials (although Simon Kuper made a valiant attempt in Football Against the Enemy) and Newcastle undoubtedly had a better squad of players than last season's final league position of 11th suggested.

The squad has also been improved by Robson's summer signings. Christian Bassedas and Daniel Cordone look likely to improve a midfield already crammed with the creative talents of Kieron Dyer, Nolberto Solano, Diego Gavilan and Stephen Glass (how many other Premiership clubs have can boast such a collection?). And Carl Cort should also prove to be a more consistent, if less fearsome, partner for Alan Shearer than Duncan Ferguson.

However for all the excitement elsewhere on the pitch, Newcastle's defence remains a worry. They shipped goals in pre-season and still seem to lack a first choice back five. Will it be Given or Harper in goal? Hughes or Domi at left-back? Will the talented Andy Griffin get a game? And can Robson really persist with the big-hearted, but error prone, Nikos Dabizas much longer?

There is no reason to think that Newcastle will be flirting with relegation again this season, but unless they start displaying the sort of defensive consistency that has been alien to the club since before Keegan's time, they are unlikely to gain a place in Europe. Through the league at least.

In: Christian Bassedas (Velez), Daniel Cordone (Racing Club) Carl Cort (Wimbledon).

Out: Alessandro Pistone (Everton), Carl Serrant (Sheffield Utd), Stuart Elliott (Darlington), David Cunningham (Livingston), Silvio Maric (Porto), Lionel Perez (Cambridge), Temur Ketsbaia (Wolves), Steve Howey (Man City), Duncan Ferguson (Everton).

Odds: 50-1

Football Unlimited writers' prediction: 7th.

webTitle: Crush in south 'due to London exodus'

fields.headline: Crush in south 'due to London exodus'
fields.trailText: The belief that overcrowding in southern England is caused by migration from the north is scotched today by a fresh analysis of population trends from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, an independent research body.
fields.body:
The belief that overcrowding in southern England is caused by migration from the north is scotched today by a fresh analysis of population trends from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, an independent research body.

It shows that the most powerful motor of population growth in the southern counties is the flight of relatively prosperous families from suburban London.

People moving out of the capital were responsible for 50% of the population growth elsewhere in the south between 1991 and 1998, whereas migration from the north, midlands, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales accounted for only 8%, the researchers said.

Other factors explaining a 623,000 increase in the southern population outside London over the period were a higher than expected birth rate and immigration.

The report said an extra 4.3m households would need accommodation in the UK by 2021. The demand for homes would fall disproportionately on the south-east, where the population was expected to grow by 50,000 a year, putting pressure on greenfield sites.

But a continuing middle class exodus from London would not reduce its population, because it had a high birth rate and it was the main destination for migration from within and beyond the EU.

London's migrant population was expected to increase by 31,000 a year for the foreseeable future and would include extremes of rich and poor. This would put pressure on central London house prices and increase demand for affordable "social" housing for rent.

The report accepted that there had been some population drift from north to south. Net migration from the north and west midlands was about 30,000 people a year during the 1990s, although this was expected to fall.

A more significant trend was a move in all regions from towns and cities to the suburbs and rural areas. This had not been one-way traffic. Typically 500,000 left the cities each year and 400,000 moved in.

"There is a clear life cycle feature, with net movement by people aged 15-19 out of almost all regions and into London," the report said. "However, London is shedding people in all other age groups, and this net outward movement is on a much bigger scale than any other kind of migration."

Those moving out tended to be relatively wealthy families with children, or retiring couples.

Richard Best, the foundation's director and joint editor of the report, said: "The decline of great cities is a national problem demanding action to regain and retain economically active people on the scale urged by Lord Rogers and his urban task force.

"But our analysis shows that attempts to achieve an 'urban renaissance' by blocking migration from north to south would be misconceived. Most movement from cities only takes people as far as the suburbs and surrounding areas.

"There is no escaping the conclusion that population pressures will remain intense in the southern regions, and that London will be unable to meet all its housing needs within its own boundaries."

On the Move: Housing consequences of migration, edited by Richard Bate, Richard Best and Alan Holmanis; Joseph Rowntree Foundation; £13.95

Net migration from the north and west midlands was about 30,000 people a year during the 1990s, although this was expected to fall. A more significant trend was a move in all regions from towns and cities to the suburbs and rural areas. This had not been one-way traffic. Typically 500,000 left the cities each year and 400,000 moved in. "There is a clear life cycle feature, with net movement by people aged 15-19 out of almost all regions and into London," the report said. "However, London is shedding people in all other age groups, and this net outward movement is on a much bigger scale than any other kind of migration." Those moving out tended to be relatively wealthy families with children, or retiring couples. Richard Best, the foundation's director and joint editor of the report, said: "The decline of great cities is a national problem demanding action to regain and retain economically active people on the scale urged by Lord Rogers and his urban task force. "But our analysis shows that attempts to achieve an 'urban renaissance' by blocking migration from north to south would be misconceived. Most movement from cities only takes people as far as the suburbs and surrounding areas. "There is no escaping the conclusion that population pressures will remain intense in the southern regions, and that London will be unable to meet all its housing needs within its own boundaries." On the Move: Housing consequences of migration, edited by Richard Bate, Richard Best and Alan Holmanis; Joseph Rowntree Foundation; £13.95

webTitle: Amanda Platell said one thing then. And another  now

fields.headline: Amanda Platell said one thing then. And another  now
fields.standfirst:
The Conservatives' press secretary is hardly a good
                                          advertisement, writes Julia Langdon
fields.trailText:
The Conservative party is currently torn by disagreement about
                                          the nature and content of its forthcoming election programme.
                                          There have been a series of changes in different areas of policy
                                          and in the party's approach to winning its way back into public
                                          esteem. There are furrowed brows in Conservative Central Office
                                          and long faces among the party's MPs. And no wonder. The
                                          Tories are in a mess and nothing that they are doing at the
                                          moment is likely to improve things.
fields.body:
The Conservative party is currently torn by disagreement about the nature and content of its forthcoming election programme. There have been a series of changes in different areas of policy and in the party's approach to winning its way back into public esteem. There are furrowed brows in Conservative Central Office and long faces among the party's MPs. And no wonder. The Tories are in a mess and nothing that they are doing at the moment is likely to improve things.

One reason why this should be has come my way. It is not - alas - another sensational leak. It is not even a particularly impressive document. It is the transcript of part of a Question Time programme on BBC Television and it is the contribution to that programme by Amanda Platell, press secretary to William Hague. It was released by the Labour party to at least one other newspaper some days ago but very little attention was paid to it. I cannot imagine why not - it is extraordinarily revealing, in a number of different ways, about the nature of the political process. And about Ms Platell.

First, an explanation which itself says much about the issues involved. Why was the Labour party in possession of this transcript? Perhaps they had asked the BBC for a copy because some bright spark at the party's headquarters in Millbank remembered that Amanda Platell had appeared on the programme and thought it might be worth finding out what she said in the hope of embarrassing the Tories? Wrong. The Labour party had this material because when Ms Platell was a guest on Question Time she was the Managing Editor of the Mirror Group of Newspapers and, in that responsible position, was briefed for the programme by the appropriate department within the Labour party itself. They made a recording and kept the transcript.

But why did the briefing occur? Why would someone deemed smart enough to be the managing editor of anything - let alone a mass circulation tabloid newspaper - need to be briefed about what she thought about any area of current affairs? It might perhaps have been understandable if she had asked the public affairs department of MGN to furnish her privately with the up-to-date political position on the coal industry, care in the community or proportional representation before the programme. All of these subjects were among those discussed and were clearly in the news at the time. But it says something very bizarre about public affairs and the way current news issues are handled on television that it should be necessary for such a briefing to be offered by the Labour party and, even more, that it should be accepted by a high-profile public figure.

It is known and understood by journalists that in the hermetic conditions of today's clinically controlled politics, most MPs are briefed to the eyeballs. Their bleepers tell them what to think and say about everything. Should they be invited to express their views in public and if, of course, their appearance is approved by their minders at HQ, they will secure a run-down from their own parties on the correct line to take on every subject before daring to tiptoe before a microphone. Anything to avoid the shame and horror of having to risk expressing any kind of individuality or personal political commitment.

Yet it is rather odd to discover that this also extends to executives of the once great Mirror. The obvious implication is that Amanda Platell was expected to express views consistent with those supported by the Labour party, which was then in opposition. There is no date on the transcript but it seems evident from the context that the programme was broadcast some time in early 1993. But whenever it was, it will have been a relief to those involved on the party's side that Ms Platell performed her role to perfection.

She spoke with sympathy about the problems of striking miners, forced to work extra hours for less pay by a (Conservative) government seeking to sell off their industry. She spoke powerfully about the Mirror's support for the leftwing. "As long as we have breath," she said of her newspaper, "it will continue to support the Labour party." She spoke of "fighting against social injustice", for the views of "our readers" who were Labour supporters. Later she boasted of the newspaper's coverage attacking the closure by the (Conservative) government of Westminster Hospital and how they had exposed the "outrageous" expenditure by Peter Lilley, the then (Conservative) secretary of state for social security on his travel to and from his home in France.

She was a bit woolly about PR but said that "you would not have had the poll tax in a million years if there had been any chance - if we'd had proportional representation." And she spoke about being "terribly terribly worried" walking down any street in this country and seeing "people in doorways who obviously should be in hospitals, who should be in institutions and who've been kicked out by this (Conservative) government because they didn't have the funds to keep them in the hospitals."

Now I have no idea whether Amanda Platell believed what she was saying when she said it, but I rather suspect that she cannot possibly have done so. She doesn't express herself particularly well or fluently and there is no indication that she has actually thought through any of the points that she made on the programme, let alone believed them.

What really is astonishing is that we have a political system which makes it possible for someone who was, relatively recently, prepared to go on television and mouth ill-considered thoughts on behalf of one of our major parties, shortly before she was to become the press secretary to the leader of the other. Admittedly William Hague was only joint parliamentary under-secretary at the Department of Social Security in 1993 - the job politicians laugh about as arguably being the least desirable on offer - but he was only two years away from promotion to the cabinet and only four from the leadership.

The metamorphosis of Amanda Platell is a small but depressing episode. One of the truly surprising things about the state of our political parties at present is the lack of serious attention that any of those involved in running affairs seems to pay to the important business of sincerity.

It is difficult to under-estimate how much this matters to the electorate. Time and again opinion polls demonstrate that what chimes best with the public is a politician who is palpably honest and human and who tells the truth. It may not be about something with which everyone will necessarily agree. That doesn't matter at all. It is the sincerity that matters. But people like Amanda Platell treat such matters with careless disdain. Since she is now running press relations at Conservative Central Office, is it any wonder that they are in such a mess?

webTitle: Clinton issues warning over high oil prices

fields.headline: Clinton issues warning over high oil prices
fields.trailText: Fresh evidence that US oil stocks are drying up caused a sharp jump in the price of crude oil yesterday as Bill Clinton warned that economic growth in the west could be harmed by the present level of prices.
fields.body:
Fresh evidence that US oil stocks are drying up caused a sharp jump in the price of crude oil yesterday as Bill Clinton warned that economic growth in the west could be harmed by the present level of prices.

Mr Clinton warned Opec that oil prices above $30 a barrel could provoke a recession in the industrialised world which would cut demand for oil, harming the producers as well. He called on the cartel to help bring prices down to $20-25 a barrel.

Mr Clinton promised to discuss oil production levels at a meeting in Lagos this weekend with Nigerian president Olusegun Obasanjo. Opec is set to meet in early September, but the cartel has given conflicting messages in recent weeks about whether it will turn on the taps to ease prices.

Extra oil from the cartel had been expected to replenish dwindling western stockpiles but new figures yesterday showed another sharp decline in US oil reserves. Statistics from the American Petroleum Institute marked US crude stocks in the week to August 18 down 7.7m barrels at 279.7m - 11% lower than at the same time last year.

"This is clearly a shockingly large draw," said Lawrence Eagles of head of commodities research at brokers GNI.

Brent blend futures by late afternoon in London had risen $1.24 to $31.18 a barrel, while US light crude sped $1.56 higher to $32.78. Prices are now back near the 10 year peak reached earlier this month. Speaking in London, Mr Obasanjo, agreed that excessive prices were bad both for oil producers and consumers. "Oil producers should try to work out a medium [price]," he said.

Opec meets on September 10 to decide new quotas, but it is not clear if they will bow to western pressure and increase production.

webTitle: Girls take top grades in most subjects

fields.headline: Girls take top grades in most subjects
fields.standfirst:
First detailed GCSE breakdown confirms trend that puts girls on top and leaves boys best only in mathematics
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Girls are outperforming boys both at the top grades and across subjects, it was confirmed last night after the publication of the first GCSE results broken down by gender.
fields.body:
Girls are outperforming boys both at the top grades and across subjects, it was confirmed last night after the publication of the first GCSE results broken down by gender.

Even in mathematics - the only subject where boys won more A* grades than girls - achievement by the two sexes was broadly the same, the exam boards said.

The joint council for general qualifications last night published details of examination results on behalf of the regional boards not only for GCSEs, but also for GCSE short courses, certificates of achievement and the vocational part one, and foundation and intermediate GNVQs.

The figures confirmed that youngsters took more exams than the previous year - the number of GCSE entries increased by 5.4%, compared with an increase in the number of 15- to 16-year-olds of just 2%.

The results published by the awarding bodies and released to candidates today cover England, Wales and Northern Ireland relate to all entrants regardless of their age or where they took the exam.

Overall, the percentage of candidates achieving A* to C in full GCSE courses rose to 56.6% from last year's figure of 55.7%.

Last week's A-level results showed girls getting more A grades than boys for the first time, triggering a national debate about boys' so-called under-achievement.

The breakdown in GCSE results according to gender reveals some interesting trends within individual subjects.

In modern languages, for example, girls showed superior linguistic skills to their male classmates in contrast with this year's A-level results where boys' performance was ahead.

In GCSE French, 60.1% of girls got a grade C or higher, compared with 44.5% of boys. In German, the corresponding figures were 63% of girls and 49.1% of boys, while in Spanish the figures were 65.8% for girls and 51% for boys.

This year the most popular GCSE subject continued to be maths, which was taken by 673,056 candidates and accounted for around one-eighth of all the entries.

In maths, 3% of boys were awarded A*, up from 2.6% last year, while girls achieved 2.6%, up from 2.1%.

Close behind was English, with 647,436 entrants. Here, girls achieved 3.7% of A* grades in English, compared with 2% for boys, while they also picked up more As, Bs and Cs. Entries in the more traditional GCSE subjects such as biology, chemistry, physics, history and modern languages remain strong, while art continues to be the most popular examination subject outside the national curriculum, attracting 201,296 entries. But there was a slump in entries in geography and home economics.

The subject most likely to attract the A* grade this year was again Greek. This time it was taken by only 934 candidates but nearly half of them got the top grade.

Entries for information technology were increasing significantly at all levels and types of qualification, the results show, reflecting recognition of the importance of computer skills in today's workplace.

At GCSE, for example, IT had the biggest single rise in any one subject with a 10% leap in full course entries on last year, and a corresponding 8% increase in short course entries.

The exam boards also reported that numbers of entries for GCSE short courses increased year on year by 20,698 to 275,751. They are designed to be the same standard as a full GCSE, but take half the study time.

Short course subjects with the biggest increases in entries include religious education and information technology. Despite an overall decline in registrations for GNVQs, there was a sizeable increase in part one GNVQ entries, available to schools only last year.

Congratulating candidates on the results, the school standards minister, Estelle Morris, urged young people to consider staying on in further or higher education rather than quitting.

"There are plenty of opportunities to progress to higher qualifications and a more secure future," she said, "whether in full-time education at school or college, an apprenticeship or other vocational learning."

Paul Sokoloff, convenor of the joint council, commented: "The good GCSE results this year are a testimony to the hard work of students and teachers, who deserve congratulations.

"The increase in entries for GCSE, short course GCSE and part one GNVQ is good news, showing that students are taking a broader range of subjects at 16, particularly those they see as relevant to today's world. Awarding bodies will continue to innovate and to provide qualifications to meet the needs of a changing society".

The Professional Association of Teachers welcomed the small rise in standards at GCSE and urged critics to give credit to pupils and their teachers.

But the PAT general secretary called for a large scale inquiry into gender differences .

"At university - where there are more male than female lecturers and few senior women academics - male students still gain more first class degrees, while in the workplace men still dominate the top jobs in the professions, academia, politics and business," she said.

"Even in schools, where women outnumber men, 80 per cent of secondary school headships are held by men".

webTitle: Lack of allure in faraway places blamed for decline in geography

fields.headline: Lack of allure in faraway places blamed for decline in geography
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Foreign countries are losing their romance, and this partly explains another fall in the popularity of GCSE geography, a headteacher said last night.
fields.body:
Foreign countries are losing their romance, and this partly explains another fall in the popularity of GCSE geography, a headteacher said last night.

Candidates taking geography fell this year to 251,605 from 257,294 last year and 265,573 in 1998. At A-level, 37,112 students took it this year, compared with 42,169 in 1999 and 44,881 the year before.

Elspeth Insch, headteacher of King Edward VI girls' school in Handsworth, Birmingham, a member of the Royal Geographical Society's education committee, said: "The romance of foreign lands has gone. The world is a smaller place, and children have travelled."

Though the geography curriculum was now much better and more interesting than in her school days it was more fractured, and children were sometimes disappointed that they did not cover a country in detail. No longer did children "do Brazil", for instance. "I sometimes wonder whether we haven't lost something," she said.

Making technology a compulsory subject at GCSE level limited the choices in many schools, particularly when most pupils did double science. Subjects such as business studies, PE and sociology, which "we would have pooh-poohed years ago", were offered widely, "and they are probably pandering to teenage tastes".

Rita Gardner, director of the RGS, said geography was still the most popular non-compulsory subject.

Miss Insch said the government should pay geography graduates extra to encourage them to go into teaching. It was "a shortage subject. Geographers are very employable. They are literate and numerate and have very good IT skills.

"There are some outstanding people coming into the profession. But particularly in the lower part of secondary school we do have geography not being taught by graduate geographers but being taught as part of the humanities regime... And I think a degree in the subject is vitally important."

webTitle: Girls stay top of class in GCSEs

fields.headline: Girls stay top of class in GCSEs
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Another record success rate in today's GCSE results confirms girls' academic supremacy but shows half of all candidates still failing to achieve good passes in maths and science.
fields.body:
Another record success rate in today's GCSE results confirms girls' academic supremacy but shows half of all candidates still failing to achieve good passes in maths and science.

While there were slight improvements in the results in core subjects, in maths, fewer than half - 49.2% - of all candidates achieved a C grade or better, according to figures released by the exam boards last night. In English, fewer than 60% and only half of boys, 50.8%, achieved a C or better. Two-thirds of girls, 66.4%, achieved the same level.

In more than 5.6m GCSEs throughout the country, the proportion of starred A grades rose slightly, by 0.2% to 4.6%, and A*-Cs by 0.9% to 56.6%.

Today's results suggest that the education secretary David Blunkett's target of 50% of 16-year-olds achieving five A-Cs or better by 2002 will be touch and go. Last year 47.8% achieved that measure. Girls stayed well ahead of boys, with 61.1% achieving a C grade or better, compared with 51.9% for boys.

fields.headline: The national lottery
fields.standfirst: The national lottery commission has decided not to award the new licence to run the game to either the incumbent Camelot or Richard Branson's People's Lottery. However, it has given Sir Richard a month to fine tune his bid. Mark Tran explains this unusual decision.
fields.trailText: The national lottery commission has decided not to award the new licence to run the game to either the incumbent Camelot or Richard Branson's People's Lottery. However, it has given Sir Richard a month to fine tune his bid. We explain this unusual decision.
fields.body:
What is happening to the lottery?
The Camelot consortium's seven-year licence to run the national lottery expires in 12 months. The national lottery commission, which spent six months poring over competing bids from the incumbent and Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery, decided yesterday that neither bid was successful as they stood. However, it gave Sir Richard a month to fine tune his bid.

Why the delay?
The lottery commission is worried about the financial stability of the People's Lottery. It is concerned that the company would not have enough cash in the bank to cover the prize money on offer in the event of sales falling below hoped for levels or if the company goes bust. The People's Lottery will need to find another £50m on top of agreed borrowing facilities of £170m backed by JP Morgan and Lloyds TSB.

Why wasn't Camelot also given more time?
The commission has been accused of being inconsistent in rejecting Camelot's bid entirely while allowing Sir Richard to fine-tune his. The commission's response is that Camelot's probity was compromised by its problems with software supplied by the US firm GTech. Camelot suffered a software glitch which resulted in some players being short-changed over a four-year period up to 1998. Although the problem was resolved, GTech did not inform Camelot and the commission of the problem, which only came to light when a whistleblower sent a letter to the regulator. A separate report on GTech will be published next month.

Doesn't GTech have a troubled past?
Two years ago, its former chairman Guy Snowden was forced to resign after losing a libel case against Sir Richard, who declared that GTech had attempted to bribe him to withdraw during the last round of bidding in the early 1990s. In 1996, GTech's head of sales J David Smith was convicted of accepting kickbacks from lobbyists involved in acquiring lottery contracts. He was sentenced to five and a half years in prison, although GTech insisted he had acted alone.

Aren't there questions about Sir Richard's finances?
Sir Richard's exact wealth is a mystery as he has investments in a complex web of offshore companies. In delaying its award of the licence for a month, the commission in effect is asking Sir Richard to prove that he has the huge financial resources to run a £36bn business. His critics also question whether the fiasco of Virgin Trains, part of Sir Richard's empire, qualify him to run the People's Lottery.

What are Camelot's options?
Camelot will continue to run the national lottery until its licence expires in September 2001 before handing over to the People's Lottery. There are reports that it may seek a judicial review of the commission decision. In the unlikely event that the People's Lottery fails to satisfy the commission, Camelot could make another bid. But it looks like the end for the consortium - formed specifically to run Britain's national lottery - and its 800 staff face an uncertain future.

What would change under the People's Lottery?
Sales of lottery tickets have fallen over the last three years. Sir Richard plans to reverse this by injecting more sparkle into the game. Simon Burridge, chief executive of the People's Lottery, says the Saturday night TV show during which the jackpot draw is made will be more lively and "more watchable". The games will involve more numbered balls and there will be more winners. The People's Lottery says it will narrow the chances of winning £1m from the current one-in-14m to one-in-3m. It also aims to raise £15bn for good causes during the seven-year run of its licence - some £5bn more than Camelot is expected to have raised in its current licence period.
