webTitle: Leader: Branson must improve his lottery bid

fields.headline: Branson in waiting
fields.standfirst:
To get the lottery he has to improve his bid
National Lottery Commission
fields.trailText: At first glance the national lottery commission's ruling yesterday looked as illogical as trying to win the jackpot (odds against success: 14m to 1). Faced with two bidders for the next seven-year licence to run the lucrative game, the commission ruled out both the present operator, Camelot, and its challenger, Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery.
fields.body:
At first glance the national lottery commission's ruling yesterday looked as illogical as trying to win the jackpot (odds against success: 14m to 1). Faced with two bidders for the next seven-year licence to run the lucrative game, the commission ruled out both the present operator, Camelot, and its challenger, Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery (of which our retiring managing director, Caroline Marland, is a non-executive director). Camelot was rejected on three grounds: doubts about its software; concern over its breaches of its current licence, which could still lead to fines; and "unresolved concern" over the propriety of its arrangements with GTech, the American software firm, against which there have been serious allegations over lottery licences obtained in the US.

Dame Helena Shovelton, chairwoman of the commission, told reporters that despite reservations over the Branson bid, her members would now proceed with a new single bidder process, negotiating with his consortium about its shortcomings. This looked like the best of all possible worlds: Camelot, with its history of fat cat payments to directors, rejected; Branson's consortium told to improve its bid. But when reporters asked what would happen if the new negotiations failed, Dame Helena suggested negotiations with Camelot could be reopened. Given her earlier damning rejection, this looked illogical and unfeasible. But there is one reason for keeping the door open to Camelot: with no other bidder around - no Littlewoods or Ladbrokes this time - it maintains the pressure on Sir Richard to improve his bid.

Unlike her hapless predecessor, Dame Helena, an experienced audit commissioner, is proving a hard-nosed regulator. The evaluation has involved 2m words of evidence and 360 checks on the 100 companies involved in the two bids. We hope Branson wins: a not-for-profit consortium is more in tune with charitable goals. But the licence has to be earned.

webTitle: Derek Brown on freedom of expression on the net

fields.headline: Needling authority
fields.standfirst: When the mother of a Russian submariner can be forcibly sedated to silence her tirade - in full view of television cameras - what does it mean for freedom of expression? More importantly, what does it demonstrate about the media's duty to inform? Derek Brown investigates
fields.trailText: When the mother of a Russian submariner can be forcibly sedated to silence her tirade - in full view of television cameras - what does it mean for freedom of expression? More importantly, what does it demonstrate about the media's duty to inform? Derek Brown investigates
fields.body:
A Russian woman who was forcibly sedated after she shrieked abuse at a senior minister has become a potent symbol of Moscow's continuing intolerance of dissent.

Images of the incident have been broadcast and published throughout the world. They show the young blonde woman - the mother of one of the sailors who died horribly in the Kursk submarine - screaming her angry comments at Ilya Klebanov, the deputy prime minister in charge of investigating the disaster. An officer tries, without success, to calm the woman, before a nurse slides into the picture, clearly holding a hypodermic syringe. Moments later, the blond woman slumps to the ground, before being helped to a chair.

Officials later suggested that the woman's sedation was motivated by compassion. That explanation is as crass as the sedation itself, which took place in full view of a local television crew. At least in Russia today the authorities cannot muzzle the media, though they can silence a protesting mother.

In the Soviet era these things were organised better. The woman have been dealt with more swiftly and effectively, and the images would never have got out. In our own enlightened times, what happened was less sinister than bovinely stupid. And yet the incident raises all kinds of disturbing, fascinating questions about censorship and manipulation; about dissent and dissimulation.

There is a western tendency to smugness when it comes to media freedom. We congratulate ourselves for being able to call Bill Clinton a fornicating liar or Tony Blair a grinning prat. That kind of freedom is indeed precious, but it is superficial. So far as the mainstream media are concerned, there are many sly and pernicious restraints on freedom, most clearly explained by the US intellectual giant Noam Chomsky. If we accept that our freedom is not total, we may understand better what happens elsewhere. For free expression is a highly subjective matter, and what we regard as a precious right may in some countries be seen as an intolerable abuse.

India, for example, is a vigorous democracy. Its press is far from reverent, let alone obsequious. But on issues perceived to be of national importance, the Indian media tends instinctively to close ranks behind the government of the day. Kashmir is an obvious example: there can be strident criticism of day-to-day handling of the situation, but it is unthinkable that the mainstream media would question, let alone oppose, the notion that Kashmir is an indivisible part of India.

Another interesting dichotomy is between the private sector press and the state controlled television service, Doordarshan. The broadcasters in theory enjoy the same freedoms as their print colleagues, but in practice their news bulletins are dreary recitals of what the prime minister has said and done that day. The same is true, with knobs on, in next-door Pakistan, where at least the broadcasters have the current excuse of labouring under a military junta. But it was just the same in the days of Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif, both of whom insisted that the Pakistan Television news be little more than a court circular.

This confusion of the state with its rulers is ubiquitous in the Third World, as the Channel 4 news team now in custody in Liberia has found to its cost. They were doing what they ought to do: asking awkward, probing questions. But when they started to gather material that might have been embarrassing for Liberia's strongman leader Charles Taylor, they tripped the wire that binds together Nation, Ruler and Authority. We might scoff when Liberian ministers talk of Channel 4's "espionage" but to a certain mindset that's exactly what their activity amounted to.

In Russia and the former Eastern Bloc, elements of the same confusion exist more than a decade after the fall of the Berlin Wall. It was always naive to suppose that Western media standards could be transplanted wholesale into Eastern Europe - even if that was desirable. The region is still in a transitional stage, in which even impeccable liberals like the Czech Republic's Vaclav Havel have an instinctive distrust of 'free' television.

Indeed, rulers of every democratic hue, and of course despots of all kinds, are mesmerised by television. Its raw power to inform and to delude is undoubted, but in its conventional form it is the medium which, next to newspapers, those rulers can most easily control and manipulate. Oddly, the same rulers and manipulators have, for two generations at least, overlooked the much greater threat/opportunity of radio to subvert/inform. John Tusa, the former BBC World Service chief, strongly believes that it was radio, more than any other medium, which brought down the Wall.

Now the internet is the new radio, along with satellite television and, to an extent, mobile telephony. The new media are no respecters of frontiers, or even of laws. They allow the most extravagant conspiracy theories to flourish and, of course, they can be used to explain in graphic detail how the mainstream media have been suborned by big business.

Impressive phrases such as"the geopolitics of information" are woven into earnest academic treatises on the internet's impact on politics, on the Third World and, for that matter, more or less any other aspect of life.

The plain fact is that the net is more effective than any other medium for spreading news, views and images around the globe, with or without the permission of the kind of people who believe that distraught mothers should be sedated rather than give offence to a minister.

webTitle: Jubilant Branson returns to secure lottery deal

fields.headline: Jubilant Branson returns to secure lottery deal
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson returned to Britain from his Caribbean island today, jubilant at the prospect of realising his dream of running the National Lottery.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson returned to Britain from his Caribbean island today, jubilant at the prospect of realising his dream of running the National Lottery.

The Virgin boss vowed to keep his promise to deliver more for good causes and make more millionaires. And he threw a lifeline to Camelot's 800 workers, saying he hoped to recruit many of them to his People's Lottery.

The commission has now given the People's Lottery one month to resolve outstanding legal issues and demands for an emergency fund before awarding it the coveted licence, which will run from 2001-08. "Obviously there's a lot of hard work to do over the next month," Sir Richard said.

But he added: "I'm delighted. It is almost a lifetime ambition come true. From now the Lottery will be back in the hands of the British people. It's great for the British public."

Speaking at Gatwick airport, Sir Richard said: "Obviously, it's not a great day for the people of Camelot. Many innocent people will be jobless. We hope to take on many of those workers at the People's Lottery." Sir Richard said he would be urging Camelot to "grow up" and work with him to save workers from redundancy.

The 50-year-old multi-millionaire flew back from his Caribbean island, Necker, to meet the National Lottery Commission tomorrow. He plans to negotiate hard over a £50m emergency prize fund which the commission has set down as a precondition for securing the franchise. He said: "The money is only going to be needed if the lottery runs into serious financial trouble. That level of guarantee is unnecessary."

His failure to win the lottery franchise in 1994 left him bitterly disappointed. Now, tantalising close to realising his ambitions, he said: "If you can raise billions for good causes that a nice thing to do."

Sir Richard said he would postpone cracking open the champagne until the People's Lottery had officially won. He promised to make five times as many millionaires as Camelot, with one in three million players winning more than £1m.

He laid the blame for Camelot's failure at its lack of "integrity". Camelot's bid was rejected partly because of a software glitch, which led to overcharging retailers and underpayment of winners. US firm GTech, which supplied the software, covered up the mistake until a whistleblower tipped off the commission. Camelot could also face fines over breaches of its licence over the last six years.

Sir Richard has pledged to raise more than £15bn for good causes over the duration of the licence.

fields.headline: Unwanted guest at model jail
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The return to prison of Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair may have been welcomed by law-abiding citizens in Northern Ireland, but he was the last person the prison officers at Maghaberry jail wanted to see.
fields.body:
The return to prison of Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair may have been welcomed by law-abiding citizens in Northern Ireland, but he was the last person the prison officers at Maghaberry jail wanted to see.

Loyalist paramilitaries have threatened action against prison officers and their families unless segregation is introduced at the County Antrim jail.

The prison operates a policy of integration, with loyalist and republican prisoners living side by side with other inmates.

Sources with an intimate knowledge of Maghaberry said yesterday that staff feared he would become a rallying point for the loyalist prisoners, who are demanding the same rights as they were given inside the Maze.

Following the suspension of his licence for early release, Adair was dragged from his car on the Shankill road on Monday night by officers from the RUC's SAS-trained headquarters mobile support unit.

He was driven to Girdwood Barracks in Belfast, and flown to Maghaberry in a helicopter.

Once hailed as a model prison, Maghaberry has become a powder keg since the Good Friday agreement was signed. It was built to house "good honest criminals" not associated with terrorism, but members of paramilitary groups convicted or charged after the agreement have been sent there instead of the Maze, due to close in the autumn.

About 120 of the jail's 493 prisoners are affiliated to the Ulster Freedom Fighters and Loyalist Volunteer Force, a breakaway group set up by the infamous Portadown loyalist Billy Wright, who was shot dead in the Maze prison by the INLA two days after Christmas in 1997.

It was a spokesman for the LVF prisoners, who do not qualify for early release as the terrorist organisation has not declared a ceasefire, who issued the threat against the prison staff and their families.

Since Adair was freed from the Maze last September after serving five years of a 16-year sentence for directing terrorism, he has tried to forge close links with the LVF to muscle in on the lucrative drugs trade in Portadown.

Adair has publicly aligned himself with the LVF prisoners' demands, and prison sources fear a worsening of the violence that has already seen more than 60 officers injured in Maghaberry this year and several petrol bomb attacks on their homes.

But the prison authorities are adamant that they will not introduce the policies that resulted in the Maze being run by inmates.

The Maze was a home from home for Adair, who even had a mobile phone to direct operations on the streets of Belfast.

Maghaberry remains a much stricter regime than the H blocks. Yesterday the Northern Ireland prison service stressed that mobile phones were not tolerated in the jail and that Adair would be afforded no special privileges.

webTitle: Comment: Branson at the lottery could be what New Labour needed

fields.headline: New Labour's lucky ticket
fields.standfirst:
Putting in Branson at the lottery is exactly what No 10 needed. Yet it could still all end in tears
Special report: New Labour in power
National Lottery Commission
fields.trailText: Putting in Branson at the lottery is exactly what No 10 needed. Yet it could still all end in tears.
fields.body:
As well as breaking the hearts of Camelot executives, yesterday's lottery announcement shattered two golden rules. First, nothing of political significance happens in August. Second, every government announcement is always briefed well in advance. New Labour's in-house newspaper, the Mirror, confidently reported yesterday that "Camelot is today set to win the race to run the National Lottery again".

And these were not the only unique aspects of the announcements. While Chris Smith only knew about the decision earlier this week, No 10 advisers apparently found out at the same time as the rest of us.

Underlining the independence from political interference of the national lottery commission - and its improbably named chair Dame Helena Shovelton - is important for the government. Especially given that the decision to go with Branson is without question good news for New Labour. One of the most effective stories in Labour's 1997 election campaign was around the pledge to create a "People's Lottery". This pledge took up a whole section of Labour's manifesto. The measures in the 1998 Lottery Act committing distributors to focus more on social and regional need meant that the government was able to demonstrate it had met many of its promises. But the problem lay in the last line of the manifesto commitment: "Labour will seek an efficient not-for-profit operator to ensure that the maximum sums go to good causes." The Branson bid, as well as shrewdly taking the title "People's Lottery" from Labour, fulfils this last pledge.

So far so good. But while the success of the Branson bid is a result for the government, it doesn't end the controversy surrounding this national institution. While the likely establishment of the People's Lottery will be a useful addition to Labour's achievement list at next year's general election there are plenty of things that could go wrong in time to be an embarrassment in a Blair second term.

For a start the new organisers of the lottery will be taking over a business in decline. Recently, lottery sales have been declining or stagnant. Branson may not take the £230m in profits reaped by Camelot but this figure represents only 1.5% of the money for good causes pledged by both Virgin and Camelot. A decline in lottery sales of less than 1% would more than offset the benefits of not retaining profits. So the People's Lottery will need to succeed and be seen to succeed.

The second set of challenges concern legitimacy. Being not-for-profit helps but it doesn't solve as many problems as might appear. As trade union activists will tell you in the light of some general secretaries' salaries and perks, you don't have to be a capitalist to be a fat cat. The People's Lottery will still need senior executive and they will still be paid out of the proceeds. More fundamentally, the lottery will continue to be played disproportional by the poor. As the Right Rev Richard Harries, Bishop of Oxford, reminded us this week, many people maintain that the lottery is economically unfair, encourages gambling and fosters disempowering fantasies of escape amongst those at the bottom of the heap.

But the main question of legitimacy will continue to be the way the money is spent. Camelot executives never tired of telling us that they had no control over this. Of course, they were right. The responsibility for the distribution of the money lies in the hands of culture secretary Chris Smith and is devolved by him to various bodies ranging from the arts councils to the millennium commission and the new opportunities fund. It is with these bodies that the responsibility for controversial decisions like the purchase of the Churchill papers or the huge grant to the Royal Opera House. But awards of this kind do undermine the overall popularity of the lottery as an (albeit highly inefficient) form of charitable giving.

In relation to distribution, the funding bodies are stuck between a rock and a hard place. On the one hand many on the left continue to defend the often breached pledge that the lottery should not be used for funding mainstream public services. On the other hand many on the right go into apoplexy when lottery money is given to "politically correct" charities like those giving advice to gays. This inevitable controversy points to why the decision to go with Branson could ultimately prove to be a double-edged sword. While Camelot has been only too willing to fall into line with government wishes in a desperate attempt to salvage its battered credibility, Branson continues to be one of the most popular people in Britain. If Sir Richard feels the administration of lottery money is damaging its success he will say so loud and clear and - given his highly polished PR skills - with popular support. After all, anyone who can remain popular and respected while running the west coast main line must be made of Teflon. If Branson takes on the government over the lottery the sparks will certainly fly. I can even predict the sound-bite when the first argument kicks off: "this is not the New Labour lottery it is the People's Lottery".

 Matthew Taylor is director of the Institute for Public Policy Research

fields.headline: Pledge to create daily millionaire
fields.standfirst:
We will banish the boredom, vows Branson

National Lottery Commission
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson has promised to transform the way that Britons play the lottery and create a millionaire a day if his People's Lottery bid is accepted.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson has promised to transform the way that Britons play the lottery and create a millionaire a day if his People's Lottery bid is accepted.

"The People's Lottery will create more rollovers, bigger jackpots, more millionaires and better chances of becoming one," he boldly proclaimed when lodging his bid with the lottery commission in February. "Last time our bid was the best, this time it's even better."

The first changes will be new terminals in every shop selling tickets.

The Saturday night television show during which the jackpot draw is made will be made more lively and "more watchable", claimed Simon Burridge, chief executive of the People's Lottery. Despite several metamorphoses the centrepiece of the BBC's weekend schedule has been criticised for failing to live up to expectations.

One of the consortium's burning ambitions is to beat the popular show Who Wants to be a Millionaire to create a millionaire live on television.

The games will involve more balls and there will be more winners, both individual winners and charitable causes. The only thing that will be retained is the existing logo, but appropriately enough for a man once dubbed "the grinning pullover" by BA's Lord King, Sir Richard has promised to give it a wider smile.

The initiatives are tailored to increase the number of people playing the lottery and the amount of money that goes to good causes - 30p of every pound spent. Of the rest, 50p will go to prizes, 12p to lottery duty, 5.2p to retailers and 2.8p to the operator (the People's Lottery).

Sir Richard said people were getting bored of the existing formula. Over the last three years sales of lottery tickets had fallen, coming down last year by more than £300m, depriving good causes of nearly £90m. Sales of Instants also fell, from £1.5b in 1996 to £669m last year, a loss to good causes of over £200m in a year.

Sir Richard said he wanted to shake up the system, to bring more people to the lottery and to give all profit to good causes.

He was proposing to create 2,500 millionaires over the seven-year licence period, starting in October 2001, and to raise more than £15bn for good causes.

The strategy of the game would change, which, according to the People's Lottery, would see the chance of becoming a millionaire fall from one in 14m with Camelot, to one in 3m.

No longer would there be six balls drawn from 49 every Saturday and Wednesday. Under Branson's command, the game would see six balls coming from 53. There would also be a chance to buy a seventh number.

According to the People's Lottery this would create more rollovers. In all there would be eight double and two triple rollovers a year.

The group claimed it would also introduce a new range of Instants and interactive games to be played on the internet, interactive television and WAP mobile phones.

People's Lottery said surveys had demonstrated that more people wanted to play more often, and others would be inclined to return if they knew their money was going to good causes rather than to the operator.

"We are going to generate £15bn for good causes, £5bn more than Camelot expects to make during the current licence," Sir Richard said. "That's almost £100 more for every man, woman and child in this country."

Sir Richard's camp said it would give all profit to good causes and shareholder interests would not be placed above good causes.

The Virgin chief would be one of the six non-executive members of the People's Lottery board and its sole shareholder. However, he insisted it would operate independently of his own business interests.

Other members of the board would be: Don Cruickshank, the chairman of Scottish Media Group; Caroline Marland, outgoing managing director of Guardian Newspapers; Sotheby's director Michael Blakenham; Virgin employee John Jackson; and Rentokil Initial chairman Henry King.

The People's Lottery claimed to have a "best of breed" approach to ensure the best team in all areas. The technical team, which included KPMG Consulting, Energis and Compaq, would be headed by US lottery operator AWI. They won seven of the last 14 lottery licences awarded in the US.

Suppliers of new technology, reported to be an important element of the People's Lottery bid, include Microsoft and Cisco Systems. The marketing aspect will benefit from advertising agency J Walter Thompson and retailers Kellogg's.

webTitle: Sikh wins race case against the Met

fields.headline: Sikh wins race case against the Met
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A Sikh police officer wrongfully accused of sending racist hate mail to himself and his colleagues was racially discriminated against by the Metropolitan police, an employment tribunal found yesterday.
fields.body:
A Sikh police officer wrongfully accused of sending racist hate mail to himself and his colleagues was racially discriminated against by the Metropolitan police, an employment tribunal found yesterday.

There was no evidence to show that Sergeant Gurpal Virdi was responsible for racist letters distributed within the Ealing division of the Metropolitan police in December 1997 and January 1998, the tribunal said.

It also found that he was the subject of racial discrimination by the police force during its investigation of him.

Mr Virdi, 41, was sacked in March after an internal disciplinary panel decided he had sent racist hate mail to himself and other black and Asian staff.

The letters, delivered by the Met's internal mail system, told the officers to leave the force and were signed with the initials of the National Front.

Some of the messages were allegedly linked to his computer. In April 1998 his home was searched by police and he was suspended.

The hearing concluded that Mr Virdi, who had 16 years unblemished service in the Met, was motivated by frustration after being turned down for promotion and was planning a claim of racial discrimination against the force.

The Sikh officer, who gave evidence of racism in the Met at the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, claimed he was framed and discriminated against after challenging white officers on race crime and threatening to expose them.

The tribunal found yesterday that during the investigation Mr Virdi was treated differently to a white female officer, PC Jackie Bachelor, who was also a suspect in the investigation.

It found that as well as the search of his home, the Met at tempted to entrap Mr Virdi in a taped interview in February 1998 and failed to interview him in an informal way as it did PC Bachelor.

It concluded: "The explanations put forward by the respondents, the Metropolitan police, as representing good investigation practice are not sustainable or justifiable.

"We therefore infer and conclude that the reason for their failures is not incompetence but is because of Sergeant Virdi's race."

Speaking after the decision, a delighted Mr Virdi said: "It is a very sad day for the Metropolitan police again. Again, it shows the racism is still there. Despite what senior officers keep saying, nothing has improved."

The commission for racial equality, which supported his case, welcomed the outcome of the tribunal and confirmed it had already made a second applicaton to the tribunal to challenge Mr Virdi's dismissal.

The CRE's principle litigation officer, Lisa Connerty, said: "Mr Virdi's sole aim was to clear his name and put a stop to the allegations made by the Metropolitan police. This judgment does that without a shadow of a doubt."

Ian Blair, Metropolitan police acting commissioner, said the tribunal's decision was a "tough one for the Met, but one we accept".

He said: "We have reviewed the judgment and will not be appealing against it. It is time to draw a line under this long story."

He added: "It is important that we consider the lessons that can be learned from this case for the police service and for the communities of London and elsewhere.

"I have therefore consulted the Metropolitan police authority and agreed to set up a joint inquiry to review the original investigation, the discipline board and the Met case presented to the employment tribunal."

webTitle: Assurances demanded of Branson's lottery bid

fields.headline: Group needs another £50m
fields.standfirst:
Assurances demanded

National Lottery Commission
fields.trailText: The key worries identified by the regulator which still must be overcome by Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery concern the bid's financial stability:
fields.body:
The key worries identified by the regulator which still must be overcome by Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery concern the bid's financial stability:

In the event of the People's Lottery either falling into insolvency or having its licence revoked, the commission wants tighter assurances that there will be enough cash in the bank to pay any outstanding prizes and to refund the price of unused tickets.

The company has already agreed borrowing facilities of £170m backed by the City bank JP Morgan and Lloyds TSB. It will need to find another £50m to satisfy the commission.

The company's chief executive, Simon Burridge, said negotiations would now begin to secure the additional funds. At issue, he said, was the flow of money from retailers to the prize fund.

The group will have borrowings of roughly £130m at launch which he said would be paid back in two years if the lottery meets its targets.

It is not yet decided whether Mr Branson will be sole guarantor of the additional £50m or whether it will be shared by the partners in the company.

The lottery commission was also concerned about "legal uncertainties" over whether other creditors would be put before prizewinners in the event of the People's Lottery going out of business.

Mr Burridge was confident the company would be able to answer the questions raised by the commission in the next few weeks.

These issues were first raised in mid-July but John Jackson, deputy chairman of the People's Lottery, said they did not realise this would hold up the bid.

The seven-year rollercoaster

1993

October

Office of the national lottery established to supervise the bidding for the first UK wide national lottery.

May

Camelot plc wins, it is a consortium of Cadbury Schweppes, high security printer De La Rue, GTech, ICL and Racal.

Beats off competition from Sir Richard Branson, whose plans for a non-profit lottery are judged by Oflot to be unlikely to achieve its target.

1994

19 November

First draw takes place, preceded by massive award winning publicity campaign. Estimated that the "It could be you" adverts had been seen 13 times by 40m adults before a ball was drawn.

December

First millionaire, first example of the curse of the lottery winner. Mukhtar Mohidin, wins £17.9m. Tries to stay anonymous, and wracked with guilt because he is Muslim and his religion bans gambling. A year later he and his wife Sayeeda sue each other. Eventually gets court order to stop the media harassing him.

1995

March

Camelot launches Instants, a scratch card game

June

Largest single ticket jackpot nets two winners, Mark Gardiner and Paul Maddison, £22.5m. Paul and partner Ruth later split up.

November

Darren Vowell wins £25,000 on Instants. Tells press he will buy a Mercedes. Police read article, arrest him for driving while disqualified.

December

On BBC Panorama, Branson alleges attempt made to bribe him to drop his bid for the first licence. Claims Guy Snowden, former chairman of Camelot's partner G-Tech and Camelot director made the offer. Leads to libel case.

1997

January

£11m winner Ernie Bailey found dead, sparking speculation his demise followed binges on cigarettes, alcohol and food.

February

First midweek draw takes place

May

Labour wins election. It favours a "not for profit" lottery.

Magazine reveals pay rises of 40% for Camelot executives.

August

Camelot director David Rigg quits after his 90% pay hike revealed, netting him £333,000 including bonuses.

November

Fury after announcement that Camelot's pre-tax profits for first half of 1997 are £34.8m, up 10%, on sales of £2.5bn. It says £696m paid to good causes.

December

£5.4m winner Colin Sampson tells court that pressure of wealth and fame led him to grow cannabis.

1998

February

Libel case between Branson and GTech's Guy Snowden over bribery allegations comes to high court, with GTech losing and ordered to pay damages of £100,000 and costs of £3m.

Allegations of corruption swirl around GTech operations overseas. The firm masterminds the computer software and hardware for the UK lottery.

Oflot regulator Peter Davis resigns over accepting hospitality in the form of free flights from GTech.

April

GTech forced to sell its stake in Camelot.

1999

April

Oflot scrapped and replaced by national lottery commission.

June

First fall in Camelot's profits since launch, with total sales also falling.

July

Statement of main principles and timetable for next licence award announced.

Labour's pre-election pledge of a "not for profit" lottery is not included.

Also that month, a businessman who won £1.6m twice on the same night wins a court case bought by a gambling acquaintance who advised him on which numbers to pick, and who had claimed a share.

August

The post office is signed up by Camelot. Seen as shoring up Camelot's position.

November

Large fall in ticket sales mean £2.5m a week less going to good causes.

December

Branson uses breakfast TV appearance to announce he will bid again.

2000

January

Camelot's figures show spending on the national lottery is highest in poorest areas, which also miss out on money for local good causes.

June

Revealed that GTech software fault led to winners being paid the wrong amount of prize money, which Camelot says it was not informed about.

August

National Lottery Commission says neither bid has won.

September 30, 2001

Camelot's licence to run the national lottery expires

webTitle: Watchdog defends delay in lottery decision

fields.headline: Watchdog defends delay
fields.standfirst:
Dame Helena gives critics short shrift

National Lottery Commission
fields.trailText: The task of choosing which company would go forward as the next operator of the National Lottery fell to the five-strong lottery commission.
fields.body:
The task of choosing which company would go forward as the next operator of the National Lottery fell to the five-strong lottery commission.

Led by Dame Helena Shovelton, 55, the commission was established by the culture secretary, Chris Smith, in January 1999 to oversee the operation and regulation of the lottery. It was charged with sifting through nine boxes of submissions and 8,500 pages of information.

A formidable character, Dame Helena is a watchdog veteran. She also chairs the audit commission and is a member of the competition commission and the banking codes standards board.

Despite coming under fire for what many saw as a botched decision Dame Helena remained resolute that the commission had done the right thing in refusing both bids. A senior government source said the result had taken the Department of Culture, Media and Sport by surprise.

Dame Helena also rebutted charges that the commission had undermined confidence in Camelot for the remainder of its contract, which runs out in September 2001.

"We are not saying that we do not have confidence in them, what we are saying is that we do not have confidence in giving them a seven-year licence on the basis of today," she said.

The commission's chief executive, Mark Harris,joined from the audit commission in April last year. He is a qualified accountant and spent his early career in local government and the NHS. The rest of the commission's line-up comprises Brian Pomeroy, 55, a former senior partner with Deloitte Consulting; Hilary Blume, 55, a director of the Charities Advisory Trust; Rosalind Gilmore, 63, a director of the Zurich Financial Services Group and Moorfields Eye Hospital and Harriet Spicer, 49, who helped launch the publishing house Virago Press.

Dame Helena said that both of the bids had "many merits".

She added: "We met the bidders and gave them every chance to make improvements to their applications. But they also had important failings.

"We are disappointed about that but we would fail in our statutory duty if we granted a seven-year licence based on either bid in its present form."

fields.headline: Scandal dogs operator
fields.standfirst:
Glitches and lawsuits led to a loss of trust

National Lottery Commission
fields.trailText: Guy Snowden could have been forgiven for feeling a little cocky when he popped round to Sir Richard Branson's home in Holland Park, west London, for lunch one September day in 1993.
fields.body:
Guy Snowden could have been forgiven for feeling a little cocky when he popped round to Sir Richard Branson's home in Holland Park, west London, for lunch one September day in 1993.

The American businessman was then chairman of the world's largest operator of lottery systems and the British entrepreneur was desperate to win the contract to run Britain's national lottery.

Yet their meal quickly developed a bitter taste when Mr Snowden tried to bribe Sir Richard not to compete with Camelot for the lottery franchise.

As soon as Mr Branson made public his allegations GTech's star began to fall. Yesterday it crashed to earth leaving a company shorn of arguably the biggest lottery contract in the world, several senior directors and, crucially, the trust of the public.

Two years ago Mr Snowden was forced to resign and GTech to depart as a shareholder in the Camelot consortium after losing a protracted libel battle with Sir Richard over his bribery allegations. Following Mr Snowden was his long-term business partner, the mathematician Victor Markowicz, who had played a key role in building GTech.

The Rhode Island-based company has not fared much better in its home territory despite winning 25 of the 37 US state contracts that came up for tender between 1987 and 1993, helping it to maintain the title of the world's biggest lottery operator.

Within months of Camelot winning the UK contract in 1996 GTech's renowned head of sales, J David Smith, was convicted of accepting kickbacks from lobbyists involved with acquiring lottery contracts. He was sentenced to five and a half years in prison. GTech insisted he had acted alone and he was cast out into the cold.

Last month two top executives resigned amid recriminations about a cover-up two years ago of a software glitch which led to tens of thousands of winning players in Britain to be over or underpaid.

The cover-up only came to light when a former GTech employee went to the newspapers. Camelot was furious at the US firm's failure to tell it of the breakdown and demanded management changes.

The resignations of GTech's chairman and chief executive, William O'Connor, and chief operating officer, Steven Nowick, quickly followed.

Bruce Turner, a respected figure on Wall Street and widely seen as a safe pair of hands, was brought in as temporary chairman.

Those changes, combined with news that the company was not likely to make as much money this year as had been expected, knocked 12% off its share price. In all GTech estimates that its revenues could be down by as much as $25m (about £16.8m) on last year.

Earlier this month GTech postponed its annual general meeting saying it was still looking for new management.

Nevertheless Camelot has remained resolutely loyal to GTech, citing its record of running lotteries and its technological expertise.

"We know they have had their faults but those problems are behind them and we still have faith in GTech," a spokeswoman said yesterday. "In terms of operating lotteries worldwide no one else comes near them."

She said they were certainly as good as AWI, the lottery operator that is part of the People's Lottery consortium. "If they are not good enough to run the lottery next time, why are they being allowed to run the lottery now?"

But Thomas Graves, an analyst at Standard & Poor's Equity said: "There's the fear that other problem areas might emerge."

David Anders, an analyst at Merrill Lynch in New York who has followed GTech closely and has previously called for "drastic measures" to be taken at the company, said he was surprised by yesterday's decision. "We thought the resignation of two senior managers of GTech were meant to appease the commission," he said.

fields.headline: M&S rallies on shake-up talk
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: After hitting a 10-year low on Tuesday, Marks & Spencer shares rallied yesterday on talk that top level management changes are in the offing.
fields.body:
After hitting a 10-year low on Tuesday, Marks & Spencer shares rallied yesterday on talk that top level management changes are in the offing.

In heavy volume its shares ended 9p better at 217.5p as punters piled into the stock on the back of talk that chief executive Peter Salsbury is set be replaced.

While most dealers remained unconvinced by the tittle-tattle, they could not resist repeating the name being mentioned: Alan Leighton, formerly of Asda and now head of Wal-Mart's European operations.

Mr Leighton is the man widely credited with turning around the fortunes of Asda, which was sold to Wal-Mart for £6.7bn last summer.

Over the past months there has been widespread speculation about Mr Salsbury's future. Talk about his position heightened in recent weeks after reports that M&S had appointed headhunter Whitehead Mann to search for a senior executive.

Whitehead Mann was responsible for finding M&S's executive chairman, Luc Vandevelde, and the retailer's two new non-executive directors: Tony Ball, chief executive of BSkyB, and Kevin Lomax, executive chairman of Software group Misys.

Dealers said yesterday's sharp rise in the share price could not be justified on fundamentals. Its footwear supplier, Lambert Howarth, announced a disappointing set of interim figures and warned about the outlook for the second half because of M&S's difficulties.

Nevertheless, most feel Mr Vandelvelde is unlikely to start wielding the axe so soon after arriving.

After Tuesday's good performance, leading shares ended lower due to weakness in market heavyweight Vodafone , off 7p to 254.5p, as worries about the debt levels persisted.

At the close the FTSE 100 was down 18.6 points at 6,566.2, off its worst level of the day as Wall Street's recovery from early losses.

Rentokil Initial picked up 7p to close at 166p after positive comment from Schroder Salomon Smith Barney. In a note to clients, SSSB upgraded its rating to "outperform" from "neutral" and set a 200p price objective. SSSB believes interim results (due on August 30) should prove that the bear case against Rentokil has been overly pessimistic.

Mining stocks were again in good form. Billiton added 20p to 314p, benefiting from Tuesday's positive note from Merrill Lynch. Rio Tinto gained 18p to £11.90p and Anglo American rose 66p to £39.16.

Supermarkets group Sainsbury advanced 16.25p to 350p on news that it is examining the strategic options for its DIY chain, Homebase, including a sale, which could raise £1bn.

On the downside, BSkyB was again one of the worst blue-chip performers, its shares falling 51p to £11.70, as talk of a massive placing of shares gathered pace.

Apparently German media group Kirch is poised unload its 3.18% stake in the satellite broadcaster. As a consequence one US hedge fund is said to be selling its holding in BSkyB in the hope of buying it back in the placing at a lower price.

British Airways declined 16p to 335p, unsettled by the soaring price of crude oil.

Lower down the market, estate agent Countrywide Assured lost 18.5p to 101.5p after reporting a hefty decline in first-half profits.

Enodis , the food equipment specialist known in a former life as Berisford, eased 12.5p to 225.5p, as WestLB Panmure took the red pen to forecasts and cut its rating to "hold".

The move followed a meeting earlier this week at which the company is said to have highlighted a slowdown in the US beverage dispensing and refrigeration market. WestLB is now looking for pre-tax profits of £112m next year, down from £120m previously.

In the small caps, biotech outfit Provalis rose 12p to 32.5p after announcing approval in the US for its diabetes-monitoring product.

webTitle: Planes, trains, phones - now he'll sell you a lottery ticket

fields.headline: Planes, trains, phones - now he'll sell you a lottery ticket
fields.standfirst: National Lottery Commission
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson's long campaign to take over the running of the national lottery was on the brink of success last night after his only rival, the current operator Camelot, saw its hopes of another seven-year licence dashed by the regulator.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson's long campaign to take over the running of the national lottery was on the brink of success last night after his only rival, the current operator Camelot, saw its hopes of another seven-year licence dashed by the regulator.

After six months poring over the competing bids from Sir Richard's People's Lottery and from Camelot, the lottery commission took the surprise decision that neither was fit to win the licence as they stood. However, Sir Richard will be awarded the contract if his bid can meet conditions imposed by the commission.

In a damning judgment the Camelot bid was thrown out due to concerns over the probity of its key equipment supplier, the US firm GTech which was recently caught attempting to cover up problems with its software. It emerged that Camelot may even have breached its current licence and could be liable for fines.

Sir Richard, who was still struggling to find a route back from his hurricane-lashed private Caribbean island, Necker, was said to be delighted at the result. The commission chairwoman, Dame Helena Shovelton, told him the decision by telephone yesterday morning.

In a statement he said: "We have always said we could deliver much more for good causes and are happy that the commission has acknowledged that." He plans to return to Britain this morning for discussions with the commission. "I am hopeful that we can finally deliver to the people of Britain the lottery they want," he added.

The Camelot chief executive, Tim Holley, expressed his "bitter disappointment" at losing the contract the company won in 1994. He was also sharply critical of the commission.

"After everything we have put into the running of the lottery this is a very sad day for everyone at Camelot," he said. "It is surprising that after six months of deliberations there is still no preferred applicant for the next licence period and that while The People's Lottery has been given another opportunity to improve its bid, we have been excluded from the process."

The People's Lottery bid still needs to convince the lottery commission of a number of "legal issues" and of the financial stability of its bid. The commission is concerned that the company would not have enough cash in the bank to cover the prize money on offer in the event of sales falling below hoped for levels.

Camelot now faces a difficult 12 months before handing over the reins. The company may seek a judicial review of the commission decision. If the negotiations between the commission and the People's Lottery prove fruitless Camelot could make another bid.

Dame Helena rebutted claims that the lack of a clear outcome from a delayed announcement amounted to a fiasco and said the commission made its decision with great reluctance.

She said: "We have every hope that the outcome [of talks with the People's Lottery] will be successful. The commission believes that the reasons why the People's Lottery bid failed are remediable in the short term but that is not the case for Camelot."

She also denied any political motivation in proceeding with the People's Lottery in the context of Labour's election manifesto, which set out plans for a non-profit making lottery.

Sir Richard's venture, which will be non-profit making, has promised a £200,000 pay ceiling for its top executives in response to the fat cat accusations that rocked Camelot.

It was the problems of GTech that proved to be Camelot's achilles heel, most recently a software glitch which resulted in some players being short-changed over a four-year period to 1998. This has now been resolved. The commission was most angered by GTech's attempt to cover up the difficulties. These came to light during the bidding process when a whistleblower sent a letter to the regulator. A separate report on GTech will be published next month.

It was not the first time that GTech had sullied Camelot's reputation. Its former chairman Guy Snowden lost a libel case against Sir Richard, who alleged that GTech had attempted to bribe him to withdraw during the last round of bidding in the early 1990s.

Nevertheless Camelot has remained loyal to GTech, citing its record of running lotteries and its technological expertise. "We know they have had their faults but those problems are behind them and we still have faith in GTech," a spokeswoman said.

The decision brings Sir Richard, founder of the sprawling Virgin empire, close to realising one of his chief ambitions. When he failed to win the national lottery in 1994 he said he had been robbed of the chance to "do the most important thing in my lifetime".

The final decision though could still be damaged by the forthcoming publication of a book which questions Sir Richard's fitness to run the lottery given his less than trans parent web of off-shore companies.

Simon Burridge, the chief executive of the People's Lottery said: "We have run a marathon and are now on the final lap."

He promised a more exciting lottery which will narrow the chances of winning £1m from the current one-in-14m to one-in-3m. It also aims to raise £15bn for good causes during the seven-year run of its licence.

webTitle: Cover-up  put pay to Camelot's bid for new licence

fields.headline: How the magic went out of a legend
fields.standfirst:
It was a commercial success, but a cover-up finally put paid to consortium's bid for new licence

National Lottery Commission
fields.trailText: Its name evoked the romance of Arthurian legend, but in the end the magic of Camelot was tainted by the grubby realities of arrogance and greed.
fields.body:
Its name evoked the romance of Arthurian legend, but in the end the magic of Camelot was tainted by the grubby realities of arrogance and greed.

Some £10bn may have been raised for grateful good causes and the lives of 900 people transformed by million-pound windfalls, but the knights around Camelot's table were found yesterday to have lacked the propriety of their mythical counterparts.

Dogged by the cover-up of a major software glitch, accusations that it did not do enough to prevent lottery ticket sales to children and allegations of bribery, Camelot has gone the full length of the public relations rollercoaster. Yet so lucrative was the prospect of running the nation's biggest legal gambling operation that it came back for more, promising to raise even larger sums for good causes and harness emerging technology to boost flagging interest.

But Camelot failed at the first hurdle. The doughty Dame Helena Shovelton and her four lottery commissioners put paid to the bidder's ambitions, and it seems certain that Camelot's chief executive-designate, Dianne Thompson, will have to lay down her amulet. Her £334,000-a-year job was conditional on the bid's success.

Camelot was muttering darkly about taking the decision to judicial review last night. But it seems certain that its lottery dream is over: 800 staff, spread around 13 sites, face an uncertain future. Camelot is a one-trick pony, a consortium formed specifically to run Britain's national lottery. Without the licence to run the contest, it is game over for Camelot.

Ignominious

The end is as ignominious as the beginning was glorious. The birth of the national lottery in 1994 was one of the most successful product launches ever. With the It Could Be You slogan, devised by Saatchi and Saatchi, Camelot ensured maximum publicity and Saturday night queues at supermakets, petrol stations and corner shops around the country. It captured the national imagination and even now, after interest has waned, six out of 10 adults regularly participate.

It was not just a commercial success: the consortium was hailed as the saviour of rural retail industry. Installing thousands of simple-to-operate machines in retailers all over the country ensured a weekly influx that boosted grocery sales and saved some stores from certain closure. Soon, the cash started to flow to arts organisations and sporting groups across the nation. And later, landmark projects such as Tate Modern in London and the Dynamic Earth exhibition in Edinburgh emerged as the crowning glory of the lottery's achievements. The lottery was doing everything it said it would, delivering millions to good causes, uniting the nation in a shared philanthropic experience and, whisper it, sending huge profits the way of Camelot shareholders.

But behind the sweet successes lay bitter acrimony. Early on, there were concerns over the process of awarding the lottery to Camelot. The first lottery regulator, Peter Davis, was criticised for accepting hospitality and free trips from the Camelot partner GTech, and concerns have been raised about Camelot's profits, which have topped £70m a year.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, had an early showdown with Camelot bosses over "fat cat" pay, but the embarrassing encounter was swept under the carpet when Camelot agreed to pay an unspecified amount to charity. More recently, ICL, one of the Camelot partners, dropped its long-planned flotation on the stock exchange.

But it was, in the end, the developer of that technology that was to prove the undoing of Camelot. GTech, the most successful lottery operator in the world and in the early days a shareholder in Camelot, came up with the software that links up the network of lottery machines. From the start, there were concerns that GTech's business practices were not all they should have been. And it was GTech's cover-up of a problem with its lauded software system that eventually put paid to Camelot, despite Gtech's chief executive, president and principal PR man falling on their swords.

Since then, a new board structure has been put in place at GTech, and Camelot has pledged to exert tighter controls. But it was not enough for the commissioners. "The commission ... decided that, given the inability of both GTech's board and Camelot to ensure proper behaviour by GTech's most senior executives in the past, it could not presently be satisfied that the arrangements proposed by Camelot were sufficiently likely to secure that the national lottery would be run with all due propriety for it to accept Camelot's application and award it a seven-year licence," they said.

It is a hard pill for Camelot to swallow. The commissioners, however, are adamant they have taken the right decision. They are still to rule on what sanctions Camelot should suffer for breaching its licence over the software fiasco, and the commissioners feel they could not hand a seven-year contract to the consortium with that particular cloud hanging over it.

The conspiracy theorists have also been having a field day. One suggestion yesterday was that the commissioners wanted to delay handing the contract to Branson for a month to give them time to review the damaging allegations expected in a forthcoming book about Britain's favourite business tycoon.

As the champagne corks popped in Holland Park and the winds of Hurricane Debby eased to allow safe passage home from the Caribbean for Sir Richard, Camelot's executives were left spluttering their disgust. Camelot has said in the past that, should it lose the bid, it would not stand in the way of a smooth handover. But such is the acrimony over the way the end has been hailed, it seems unlikely that the mists will fall quietly around this Camelot.

fields.headline: Big-haired bison, Slow-witted camel and Cheeky monkey
fields.trailText: SAME AGAIN
fields.body:
SAME AGAIN

In the aftermath of England's Euro 2000 shambles, Kelvin Koogan faced a baying press-pack that smelt blood. His blood. "It's all your fault Koog!" the Fiver howled, although Brian Woolnough's lacquered bouffant was in our way and probably filtered out much of our venom. In any case, Koog ignored us. Instead, he concentrated his fire on that good-for-nothing bunch of wasters that made up his squad. "The last thing I am going to do is say anything detrimental about the players in the hotel," Koog said conspiratorially. "But we were not good enough."

At last the man has started making some sense, thought the Fiver, and we were so relieved we wept. And this time it was with joy. So imagine our shock when we found out that cuddly Kelv has named the same failures in his 28 man squad to face France next week! A whopping 20 out of the 22 man Euro 2000 squad are kept in - only Shearer and Richard Wright aren't there - and Koog's only attempt at experimentation is recalling Rio Ferdinand, Kieron Dyer, Andy Cole and the injury-free Darren Anderton. Which isn't much at all.

"I still believe we have the players," Koogan said today, deftly ignoring his Euro 2000 debriefing. "I can find good enough reasons not to experiment for this game." Thirty seconds later he found one. "This one game against France is the only one I have to prepare for the qualifiers against Germany and Finland and I need to get this right," Koog spluttered. But surely there will be some change, at left-back perhaps? Don't bet on it. "Because of the shortage of time together and the fact you never get the chance to play a settled side you don't get a chance to experiment," Koog concluded, as the sighs and moans around the country grew louder and louder.

The full squad: Seaman, Martyn, James; P Neville, G Neville, Barry, Adams (capt), Keown, Campbell, Southgate, Ferdinand, Gerrard, Dyer, Wise, Barmby, Ince, Anderton, McManaman, Heskey, Owen, Phillips, Cole, Beckham, Scholes.

PENNY DROPS ONTO CAMEL'S BACK CAUSING UNTOLD DAMAGE

It's taken Steve McManaman a while to figure out that Real Madrid don't want him any more. The Spanish giants forked out £43m for a player who plays in the same position as him, but he didn't bat an eyelid. He was told by his manager that he has little or no chance of playing first-team football this season, and he couldn't even be bothered to shrug insouciantly. When the entire Real squad was ordered to stand outside his house at three in the morning and scream "bugger off back to Liverpool you scruffy scouse get" through large paper cones, Steve did not wake up.

But now the penny seems to have finally dropped, the camel's back has been broken, etc., and so on. Because Macca has been left out of the Real squad for tomorrow's Super Cup clash with Galatasaray, and he's not happy. "I deserve respect," a seething McManaman told Spanish paper Marca this morning. "They should have to give an explanation about why I am not travelling to Monaco, but nobody has given it to me." The normally placid flopster didn't stop there, either. "I need to play," he ranted. "I want to play for England in the next World Cup and therefore my situation is very complicated. I am going to speak with my agent to study the situation and make the decision which suits me best."

Now, we could be wrong, but this may signal some frenetic transfer activity as a host of top clubs - and Middlesbrough - battle for his signature. But even though Macca looks to have accepted his situation, he's still desperately clinging on to the hope that Real will learn to love him again. "Nobody has told me that Real wants to sell me," he insisted, "and until somebody says it to me, I will not consider leaving." Let's hope he sets his alarm for 2.59am before he goes to bed this evening, or this could go on for ever.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We've got to look to professional referees. It's got to come. And I think there should be another card" - Glenn Hoddle, aka Hod, gets back into the press controversy groove.

IT'S A MAD MAD MAD MAD WORLD

Oh, what fun. Less than a week into the new Premiership season and there's excitement a-plenty. Patrick Vieira is sent off twice and nearly quits the country, Arsene's Arsenal Wenger gets hauled before the beak on an intimidation charge, He Was He Is Emmanuel Petit smells a racist conspiracy, Graham Poll smells a ref-ist conspiracy, and the Imperial Lord Ferg just smells.

Not really, United fans, but the much-respected red nose has done his best to wade into the card controversy this week. Yesterday, after United were lucky to come away from Portman Road with a point, Ferg decided that some referees were "prima donnas" only interested in grabbing the headlines. Twenty-four hours later and Ferg has completely changed his mind. "I feel really sorry for referees now," he said today having had time to think about it. "It is hard for them to determine what is a tackle and what is not a tackle. Some of the diving which is going on is ridiculous." And some of the loud-mouthed opinionating is a bit bonkers too.

However, if there is a man who can show Ferg how to behave with decorum, it is surely Arsenal Wenger. Charged with "physically intimidating" fourth official Paul Taylor (he must have been terrified) after Saturday's defeat at Sunderland, Wenger will defend himself by claiming Taylor started it. Wenger, who believes the altercation was a "minor incident", will claim that he only waded in after he saw Taylor pushing Thierry Henry, according to the London Evening Standard. No doubt the rotter was asking for his dinner money too.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Newcastle's underwhelming Spanish defender Marcelino looks set to return home soon, after opening talks with Celta Vigo. The only stumbling block would appear to be the price: Celta have offered United £2.9m but the Geordies are hanging on for £4.7m.

Ronald De Boer could be set to leave Barcelona after failing to figure in the club's pre-season plans. "I don't want to be the 16th or 17th man in the team - I'm too good for that," he said on his personal website. "If I have to, I will consider looking for another club." Arsenal have long been admirers of the versatile Dutch international.

Reports suggest that Sylvain Wiltord is in England to complete his move to Arsenal from Bordeaux. The French international striker is set to leave the former French champions after they agreed a fee of £13m.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Uefa have announced the seedings for tomorrow's Big Cup draw. Pot One: Real Madrid, Juventus, Barcelona, Bayern Munich, Lazio, Manchester United, Monaco, Valencia. Pot Two: Spartak Moscow, Paris Saint-Germain, Olympique Lyonnais, AC Milan, Deportivo la Coruna, Arsenal, PSV Eindhoven, Galatasaray. Pot Three: Dynamo Kiev, Rosenborg, Bayer Leverkusen, Olympiakos Piraeus, Panathinaikos, Leeds, Sparta Prague, Rangers. Pot Four: Sporting Lisbon, SV Hamburg, Anderlecht, Besiktas, Sturm Graz, Heerenveen, Helsingborgs, Shakhtar Donetsk.

Steffen Iversen has signed a new deal with Spurs, worth £1.5m a year, which will keep him at White Hart Lane until 2006.

Real Madrid could be barred from next season's Big Cup because of the club's massive debts, according to Uefa deputy general secretary Markus Studer. Speaking to German newspaper Die Welt, Struder claimed that a Uefa plan to discourage financial recklessness in football by banning clubs whose books do not balance from lucrative tournaments could be introduced as early as next season. "Real Madrid will have no chance then," he said.

Cameroon striker Joseph-Desire Job has turned down a chance to play at the Olympic Games in Sydney next month in order to concentrate on his Premier League career with Middlesbrough.

Sunderland have finally received international clearance for their £3.5m signing Julio Arca, and the 19-year-old will be in the squad for Saturday's match against Ipswich.

The draw for the third round of the CIS Insurance Cup is as follows: Dundee Utd v Airdrie, St Mirren v Dundee, Celtic v Raith, Dunfermline v Motherwell, St Johnstone v Kilmarnock, Livingston v Hearts, Rangers v Aberdeen, Falkirk v Hibs. Ties to be played on September 5 and 6.

Manchester City midfielder Jim Whitley has joined Norwich on a month's loan.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.20am)

Please stop shouting.

Dutch Football (12.50am)

Please stop going on and on about your relaxed drug laws.

Argentinian Football (2.20am)

Please stop beating England at football.

Argentinian Football (2.20am) *version for Scottish readers*

Nice hand ball.

Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2.30am)

Our 'Bring Back McCaff Even Though He's Already Back' campaign (email the.boss@theguardian.com) continues with Mike Docker: "Living in Germany I can't see McCaff on the telly anymore but just being reminded of him makes me realise how lucky I am. Jesus he's a geek. I know, I've met him."

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5pm, 6.30pm SS1, 11pm SS1, 1.30am SS1)

All these re-runs for a piddling football show when they could be showing old episodes of Burnside.

Sky Sports 3: Fifa TV (7.30pm)

You see, Thursday's just aren't the same without the no-nonsense copper.

World Cup Classics (10pm)

We miss Burnside. Sniff!

fields.headline: How to beat the fraudsters
fields.standfirst:
Flashing your plastic can be a risky business - last year credit card fraud in the UK cost a staggering £189m. But a range of new safety measures is about to change all that, says Steve Gold

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Flashing your plastic can be a risky business - last year credit card fraud in the UK cost a staggering £189m. But a range of new safety measures is about to change all that, says Steve Gold.
fields.body:
New security procedures may soon make it safer to use your Visa card or MasterCard online than in person. From next April, all Visa card and MasterCard holders in the UK will have to give out a three-digit security number printed on the card signature strip during online and telephone based transactions. As an additional means of identification, they will also have to give their house name or number and postcode .

The security number is calculated from your card's 16-digit number and other numeric data unique to your account. In theory, only cash machines, electronic point of sale machines and your card issuer's computer systems can confirm this number.

Credit card fraud in the UK cost a staggering £189m last year, and is rising.

Stolen till rolls or restaurant receipts are all that is needed for someone to take your card number and expiry date and then use your details for buying goods over the telephone or online. Alternatively, your card details can easily, and quickly, be copied by a less than scrupulous shop assistant using a simple magnetic strip reader costing around £50. These gizmos, when hooked up to a laptop computer - which could easily be under the checkout - can record all of the existing data on your card. But they will not be able to record the new security number as it is printed on your signature strip.

Thanks to the new security number, known as the card verification value, and the extra identification checks, Visa and MasterCard say it will be easier for online merchants and telephone mail-order houses to spot fraudulent card activity.

Some UK online retailers, most notably Quip (www.quip.co.uk), the discount telecoms company, have already implemented the card verfication value and house number safeguards, so if you do find these details requested when you make a transaction over the phone or online, rest assured that it's for your own protection. If, on the other hand, you see a shop assistant or waiter noting down the card verfication value or other data from the signature strip of your card, alarm bells should start ringing in your head. Don't be afraid of asking for an explanation and if necessary calling for the manager.

The "consumer tips" section on Visa's main website (which is at www.visa.com/ct) has a useful selection of dos and don'ts for when using your card at a retailer, online or at a cash machine.

Many recommendations are commonsense, but some are less than obvious, such as cancelling a cash machine transaction at any stage if you see anything suspicious about the machine, a simple procedure that can save a lot of hassle.

Visa also recommends that you don't let your card out of your sight in a shop or a restaurant. Although this can involve a trip to the till from your table, the minor inconvenience could save a lot of grief further down the line.

Not all problematic transactions are fraudulent. Suppose you order a product online and nothing arrives at all. Or, perhaps, the product arrives, but your bill is for more than you agreed. Unravelling these messes takes time and effort, not to mention a lot of brain strain.

Now a new web-based service aims to solve these problems by providing a service which allows you to prove to your card issuer - and to the online retailer - what really happened. The Card-Guard (www.card-guard.com) service allows all types of e-commerce transactions, including Switch and Visa Delta, to be securely recorded on a your PC for later playback.

The Card-Guard software sits in the background on your PC, recording any transactions you make. Copies of these transactions are then encrypted and saved to your hard disk.

If a dispute occurs, you simply send a copy of the encrypted transaction to Card-Guard. The firm then allows you secure access to the decrypted copy. Basically, if something goes wrong with a transaction you can prove your side of the story.

The service is free to use except when users retrieve their encrypted transaction records from the company's servers, for which it charges a modest fee.

There are currently two ways of paying for this service: a pay-as-you-go model at £5.50 per retrieved transaction or an annual subscription model for prepaid transaction retrievals.

The first charging model allows users to test the service and, if nothing goes wrong with any of your online transactions, you won't have to pay a penny.

Under the subscription model, users can pay either £17.50 or £35 a year for, respectively, 10 or 20 free transaction retrievals in that given year.

Plans are also in the pipeline for the company to develop an approved retailers programme on its site. Under the programmme, users will be assured of a basic level of service from such approved retailers. Users will get confirmation of their orders by e-mail and several other guaranteed services. These are basic features which many e-commerce sites ignore at their peril.

 Ensure that you get your credit card back after every purchase. If possible, do not let it out of your sight.

 Never give your card number over the phone, unless you are dealing with a reputable company or you have initiated the call yourself.

 If you feel pressured by a tele-marketing salesperson, be suspicious and never give out your account number unless you've decided to make a purchase.

 Do not volunteer any personal information when you use your card.

 After completing an ATM or Debit transaction, remember to take your card and, if provided, your transaction record

Make sure that anyone waiting to use a cash machine after you cannot see you entering your PIN or transaction amount.

 Never write down your PIN - memorise it. And never disclose it to anyone. No one from a financial institution or the police should ask for it. Nor should a retailer. You are the only person who should know it.

fields.headline: How much you can pay for...
fields.standfirst: ... a mouse mat
fields.trailText: ... a mouse mat
fields.body:
It's lush, it's leather and if you're into office accessories, you'll love it. The Gucci puzzle mouse mat isn't guaranteed to keep you entertained as long as solitaire. But it is one designer purchase that you can safely plonk on your desk without fear of appearing a complete poseur.

At 26cm by 19 cm with a 1.5 cm border, the 88-piece puzzle is slightly larger than the average mouse mat. The Gucci "G" is dis creetly carved into the leather shapes to form a subtle overall pattern. The pieces fit together so smoothly that your mouse will slide across the mat unimpeded by ridges.

Which leaves just one problem: putting it together. Even the most expert at jigsaw puzzles would have to concede that there are few clues to go on. Certainly the material casing bearing the same pattern as the finished mouse mat provides little guidance. But don't let your frustration get the better of you because at £135, you really can't afford to loose any of the pieces.

Contact Gucci on 020-7235 6707.

fields.trailText: How much can you pay for ... cards online
fields.body:
Christmas cards in August? High street shoppers might have balked if festive greetings had arrived in the shops last week, but these things don't matter in the virtual world.

At www.cybercard.co.uk you can buy Christmas cards, Easter cards and cards for occasions that most of us have never even heard of all year round. You also have carte blanche to invent a few occasions of your own by customising a virtual card with your choice of caption, greeting and picture. You can send the virtual version free of charge or have it made into the real thing and sent anywhere in the world for £2.50.

www.moonpig.com has around 700 of the best funny cards you can buy and also features 179 customisable cards, which allow you to insert the recipient's name. The occasions categories are fairly standard, but you can find cards tailored to a wider variety of people than usual, including "vain gits and poseurs" and "culture vultures". Cards cost £1.99 and will be printed and sent out within 24 hours. If you get your order in before 2pm it will be posted first class the same day.

www.sharpcards.com is the place to go for more exclusive card lines and gift vouchers (from Our Price, Heal's and The Sanctuary among others). There are more than 1,000 cards on the site, including voice cards, a range depicting Barbie and Ken dolls in outfits by Jean Paul Gaultier and Alexander McQueen. Another range features items from Vivienne Westwood, Janet Reger and Lulu Guinness.
