fields.headline: Riots threaten Prague autumn
fields.standfirst:
Scotland Yard and FBI called in as fears grow of huge anti-capitalist protests at IMF summit in Czech capital

IMF/World Bank programme of seminars in Prague

Bankwatch: information on Prague events

Special report: May 2K
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard has sent a team of officers to Prague ahead of next month's IMF and World Bank annual summit amid fears of violent anti-capitalist demonstrations by up to 50,000 protesters, including many of those involved in the May Day riots in London.
fields.byline: Nick Hopkins  and  Kate Connolly in Prague
fields.body:
Scotland Yard has sent a team of officers to Prague ahead of next month's IMF and World Bank annual summit amid fears of violent anti-capitalist demonstrations by up to 50,000 protesters, including many of those involved in the May Day riots in London.

Special Branch has been liaising with its counterpart in the Czech Republic and four officers from Scotland Yard's public order unit, led by Chief Supt Steve French, flew to the capital last week for two days of talks with police chiefs.

Files and photographs of demonstrators who incited the trouble in London have been offered to the Czech authorities, as well as intelligence on potential troublemakers.

Although the Czechs have insisted that they are confident of coordinating the security operation and are sensitive about asking for outside help, the republic has turned to Britain and the United States for advice because of fears the Prague demonstrations could be the worst so far.

Earlier this year 24 senior Czech officers were sent to the FBI's headquarters in Washington for training. Three months ago the agency's director, Louis Freeh, went to Prague to discuss contingency plans if violence flares. The Czechs have also been working with Interpol in the hope of identifying protesters from Germany, Poland and Scandinavia.

Concern has been mounting because of the way anti-globalisation campaigners have disrupted major conferences in recent years.

There were riots at last November's World Trade Organisation summit in Seattle, and at an IMF/World Bank meeting in Washington last April.

Even though the Metropolitan police cancelled all leave for the May Day protests and swamped the capital with thousands of officers and undercover "spotters", demonstrators managed to dig up the grassy area of Parliament Square, daub paint and graffiti on monuments, including the Cenotaph and a statue of Sir Winston Churchill. More than 100 people were charged.

The delegation from Scotland Yard, which included a specialist in media management, flew to Prague last week.

"We went over to help them, though officially Prague did not ask for our assistance. We wanted to share our experiences and our information," said a Scotland Yard source.

The British embassy in Prague yesterday also confirmed that there had been "contact" between senior detectives in both countries.

The Foreign Office is advising Britons against holiday and non-essential travel to Prague between September 23 and September 28. The US state department has also advised Americans not to visit the city at the end of September.

Although the Czech interior ministry has told Prague's residents to "relax and put your faith in the authorities", the build-up to the summit has convinced many that violence in inevitable.

Eleven thousand police have been assigned to the event and 5,000 soldiers will be on standby.

The health ministry has warned Prague's four main hospitals to prepare for the worst. They are taking on extra staff and will be stocked with drugs to combat biological and chemical attacks.

Keeping wounded delegates and protesters apart is another practical concern.

"If you have the delegates in one room and the protesters in another, they could fight in the corridor," warned a doctor at the Kralovske Vinohrady Teaching Hospital, which has set aside three luxury bedrooms for high profile financiers.

Fast food restaurants have already ordered replacement panes of glass, knowing they are likely to be targeted.

Managers of the supermarket chain, Tesco, which has a large branch in the centre of Prague, say they are considering closing during the summit.

Schools and theatres in the centre of the capital have been ordered to close and Prague residents have been advised it may be wise to leave the capital or stock up on medicines and food and stay at home.

Tabloid newspapers have added to the growing alarm by telling people to barricade their doors and windows against the "barbarian protesters."

Around 800 safety vests are to be handed out to journalists covering the summit, which is due to be attended by 23,000 delegates and politicians.

Scores of British protesters have already moved to Prague and hundreds more are expected to arrive in the next fortnight.

In the recent demonstrations in Britain and the US, police were accused of underestimating the resourcefulness and determination of the demonstrators and of showing little understanding of the loose-knit groupings suspected of masterminding the violence.

Most police attention has focused on a coalition of Czech environmental, human rights and anarchist groups, called Inpeg, Initiative Against Economic Globalisation, which plans a counter summit at the same time as the financial meeting. But Inpeg has described the police's plans as "hysterical" and insist it is preparing "non-violent activist training."

With growing trepidation, the police have also been monitoring the numerous websites that have sprung up in recent weeks urging protesters to head for Prague. One of the websites, called DestroyIMF, urges participation in S26 - the demonstrators' nickname for the event.

"We're going to Prague to make the IMF summit in September 2000 into Seattle II. The IMF summit will be protected by a Czech police operation run by the FBI. The challenge to the workers' movement is to shutdown that summit with the biggest demo Europe has ever seen."

It adds: "We don't just want to disrupt their summits - we want to scrap the profit system that allows institutions like the World Bank, the IMF and WTO to rule the world and the former Stalinist countries. We want to end debt, poverty and capitalist exploitation. This site is a protest portal." Protesters have been advised of the Czech for useful phrases such as "You fascist pig" and "Where is the nearest McDonalds?"

Police are also worried that protesters will target a new nuclear power plant in Bohemia which is due to be activated around the time of the IMF conference.

The Czech president, Vaclev Havel, has tried to downplay concern, criticising the coverage given to security arrangements. He said: "It is as if we were getting ready for a civil war."

A world of protest against the global economy

June 18 1999

Demonstrations were held in 27 cities worldwide, from the Czech Republic to Nigeria, in what was dubbed the "global carnival against capital".

In the City of London, the 3,000-strong peaceful protest turned into the worst riots seen in the capital since the poll tax demonstration of 1990, resulting in 46 people needing hospital treatment and an estimated bill of more than £5m.

November 30 1999

The biggest protest in the US since the Vietnam war took place on the streets of Seattle, where the World Trade Organisation was meeting.

An estimated 100,000 people protested peacefully until masked activists hijacked the demonstration and police in full riot gear responded with teargas and rubber pellets.

A smaller protest of 2,000 people at Euston station in London led to 40 arrests.

April 16-17 2000

Anti-globalisation protesters descended on Washington to disrupt meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. Between 6,000 and 10,000 people managed to close the American capital for six hours and the human chain prevented some finance ministers from getting to their meetings.

Largely peaceful but violent clashes with police officers - many in riot gear, which had them being compared to Power Rangers - resulted in 600 arrests.

May 1 2000

May Day protests took place around the world. In London, where 4,000 people took to the streets, activists performed "guerrilla gardening" in Parliament Square and daubed paint and graffiti on monuments. What had been planned as peaceful protests ended in ugly scenes and 42 arrests.

August 15 2000

Rubber bullets were fired by police in Los Angeles at the end of a protest concert by the band Rage Against the Machine. A total of 39 people were arrested in four days in a series of protests against corporate greed.

Sally James Gregory

webTitle: Six quizzed after loyalist shot dead

fields.headline: Six quizzed after loyalist shot dead
fields.trailText: Six people were being questioned today after a 21-year-old man was shot dead in Belfast - the latest victim of the worsening feud between loyalist terror groups.
fields.body:
Six people were being questioned today after a 21-year-old man was shot dead in Belfast - the latest victim of the worsening feud between loyalist terror groups.

Sam Rocket was visiting his girlfriend and one-year-old daughter in the Old Park area of the city when he was attacked by an unknown number of gunmen.

Rocket is thought to have been a friend of the son of Billy Hutchinson of the Progressive Unionist party, the political arm of the Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF). The attack is thought to have been carried out by the Ulster Defence Association (UDA) as revenge for the murder of two men on Monday.

Hardline loyalists warned today that they expected the feud to continue. "There are those on both sides hellbent on continuing it until they feel they have drawn enough blood," said Mr Hutchinson.

The UDA and UVF are both supposed to be observing a joint ceasefire in support of the Good Friday Peace agreement.

The Rocket family had been linked to the UDA, but were expelled in the mid-1990s. Some family members had since realigned themselves with the UVF.

Police arrested six more people last night after a chase on Belfast's Shankill Road. A submachine gun, a rifle, a shotgun and three handguns were found abandoned on the pavement.

John White, chairman of the Ulster Democratic party, warned that Rocket would not be the last to die. "This is something I was expecting. And I don't see an end to it," he said. "I'm not condemning it," said Mr White, convicted of a double murder in 1972.

webTitle: Amazon car sales face bumpy road

fields.headline: Amazon car sales face bumpy road
fields.standfirst: Can the leading e-tailer sell absolutely anything it wants? Guardian Online deputy editor Neil McIntosh doubts it
fields.trailText: Can the leading e-tailer sell absolutely anything it wants? Guardian Online deputy editor Neil McIntosh doubts it.
fields.body:
And you thought Amazon was just about books.

The giant US-based e-tailer today branched out again - this time into car selling over the internet. The new service, in conjunction with CarsDirect.com, went live this morning. It will allow US customers to choose a car, pay their deposit by credit card to Amazon, before collecting the new vehicle from a local dealership or - in truer Amazon style - have it delivered to their home.

Amazon in the UK said this week that it had "no plans" to move in to the competitive online car market in Britain, which already has high-profile competitors such as Virgin Cars and the Direct Line-backed JamJar.

The latter is importing cheaper cars from continental Europe in an effort to bypass UK dealer networks. Virgin Cars imports too, but also deals with selected UK-based dealers, putting it head-to-head with Autobytel, which launched last year and sells cars sourced from a network of net-savvy dealerships.

Amazon's move in the US may still take many net consumers by surprise, as most associate Amazon only with books, music and videos. But visit the site in the US and you will find that Amazon has turned into a giant virtual shopping mall, selling everything from kitchenware and garden furniture to health and beauty products.

Even at the UK site, you can buy computer software, DVD players and video cameras, or join in an auction for a jacket worn by Sheena Easton in The Outer Limits.

All this branching-out of Amazon's product lines is part of a strategy to develop Amazon into a one-stop shop for e-commerce. Earlier this summer Jeff Bezos - Amazon's chief executive - told Guardian Online that, although he was passionate about books, he never saw the company as only selling a handful of things. "I had a list of around 10 products that I thought Amazon could sell," he said. "If it made sense to sell kayaks rather than books I would have sold kayaks."

fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: English football fans are to be offered a customised online browser under an agreement to be announced today between planetfootball.com and US technology group EMT.
fields.body:
English football fans are to be offered a customised online browser under an agreement to be announced today between planetfootball.com and US technology group EMT.

Leeds and Southampton will be the first clubs to offer the new product, which will be distributed online or via a CD-Rom given away at matches and rolled out later this year.

Using technology provided by EMT, fans will be able to surf the web on a screen surrounded by their club's logo and related information. EMT, planetfootball.com and the teams will share the revenues.

Manchester City and Sunderland have also signed tentative agreements to offer the browser.

webTitle: Chinese ex-slave workers sue Japanese firms

fields.headline: Chinese ex-slave workers sue
fields.trailText: Former Chinese slave labourers have launched a test case in the US against two leading Japanese companies, claiming that they were submitted to inhuman treatment during the second world war.
fields.body:
Former Chinese slave labourers have launched a test case in the US against two leading Japanese companies, claiming that they were submitted to inhuman treatment during the second world war.

The claim, filed yesterday against the Mitsubishi and Mitsui groups in a Los Angeles court, revives memories of Japan's extensive use of Chinese and Korean forced labour.

Harsh conditions and lack of food in virtual prison camps resulted in perhaps hundreds of thousands of deaths, in their countries and in Japan.

The case has been launched by four Chinese-Americans now living in California, and five residents of Beijing. The US lawyer Barry Fisher said yesterday that "this is a suit on behalf of Chinese people victimised during the war. There were millions."

Last year, California passed a law allowing former prisoners of war exploited as slave labourers to file claims until 2010. Most of the Chinese and Korean slave labourers were civilians, but they were abducted by the Japanese army.

Workers from north China were mobilised in the 1930s to serve in Manchuria, north-eastern China, which was already under Japanese domination. In 1941, a plan was set up to draft 1.1m more "special workers" for Manchuria. Three years later, Tokyo began transporting Chinese workers.

A 1997 report by Japanese labour researchers to the International Labour Organisation (ILO), says that the imperial army was put in charge of a massive hunt for Chinese workers. By the war's end, more than 10% of Japan's coal output was dug by Chinese labour.

Out of nearly 39,000 Chinese workers brought to Japan, 17.5% are said to have died - many of them within three months of arrival.

 IG Farben, the German chemical company that made gas for death camps, will set up a compensation fund, starting at £155,000, for Nazi-era slave labourers. The firm, dissolved by the allies in 1952, remains as a trust to settle lawsuits from the Nazi era.

fields.headline: Gulf Air crash: 'black boxes' recovered
fields.trailText: Divers have retrieved the two "black box" recorders from the Gulf Air Airbus A320 which crashed into the sea last night, killing all 143 people on board, an airline official said today.
fields.body:
Divers have retrieved the two "black box" recorders from the Gulf Air Airbus A320 which crashed into the sea last night, killing all 143 people on board, an airline official said today.

The rescue teams, which included US Navy helicopters and destroyers, managed to reach the wreckage of the plane - lying in shallow waters a few miles off the northern coast of Bahrain - within hours, but there were no survivors.

Two Britons and 36 children are among those who died on board GF072, an evening flight from Cairo to Manama. Relatives spent the morning identifying victims of the crash from photos taken after all the bodies were recovered.

There was no immediate word on what caused the crash. Ali Ahmadi, a Gulf Air vice president, said investigations have begun, but Bahraini officials will wait for experts from France's Airbus Industrie and the US-based national transportation safety board for a more thorough probe.

The aircraft, which Gulf Air said was carrying 135 passengers and eight crew, crashed north of Bahrain airport at about 5.30pm yesterday.

Most of the passengers were Arab nationals - including 63 Egyptians, 34 Bahrainis, 12 Saudi Arabians, nine Palestinians, six United Arab Emirates nationals, a Kuwaiti and an Omani. There were also two Britons, an Australian, a Canadian, three Chinese people, one Sudanese national and a Korean. There were also unconfirmed reports that one of the passengers was a US diplomatic courier.

It is not yet known why flight GF072 crashed but an air traffic controller at Bahrain airport described watching from the tower as the plane circled the runway twice in an attempt to land, then on the third attempt plunged into the sea and exploded into flames.

The controller, who asked to remain anonymous, saw no sign of trouble before the crash and said the plane's crew had not reported anything out of the ordinary.

However, the ministry of transportation in Bahrain released a statement saying reports of an engine fire was "pure speculation".

The statement said: "It appeared that the aircraft had made two previous attempts to land and as it was turning to make another approach, it veered into the sea.

"Contrary to some initial reports, suggestions that an engine was on fire is pure speculation. The Air Traffic Control recordings confirm the crew made no distress call."

US navy helicopters based in Bahrain, the home of the US fifth fleet, joined the rescue operation last night, according to a Pentagon spokesman, Bryan Whitman. The Catawba, a US navy support ship with a dive team, is also being dispatched to the scene. About 100 US military personnel were sent to help from the USS George Washington - which usually patrols the Gulf but was in port - at the request of the Bahraini government, said Lieutenant John Perkins, a navy spokesman.

A Foreign Office spokesman could not confirm last night whether Britons were on board. Gulf Air urged worried relatives to call the information line on 0845 604 0171.

Bahrain's ruler, Sheikh Hamad bin Isa al-Khalifa, said last night that he had ordered an investigation into the crash. He also announced a three-day mourning period for the crash victims.

Paul Beaver, a Jane's defence specialist, said: "Gulf Air has been going for 40 years and has an excellent safety record. There have been a few bumps and scratches but nothing as catastrophic as losing a plane."

Gulf Air was arranging for a special flight from Cairo to Bahrain later today to take families of the deceased to the crash site and similar arrangements were being made for other families.

Gulf Air's most recent disaster came in 1983, when a 737-200 crashed during approach to Abu Dhabi after a bomb exploded in the baggage compartment. The crash killed all six crew members and 105 of 111 passengers.

fields.headline: Boy shows wizard charm
fields.trailText: Daniel Radcliffe cried when he found that he had got the part of Harry Potter, but he thinks being famous will be cool
fields.body:
Daniel Radcliffe cried when he found that he had got the part of Harry Potter, he thinks being famous will be cool, and if he really had the powers of the boy wizard who has proved such a publishing phenomenon he would turn his dog, Binker, into a wolf.

But he has read fewer Potter books than any other boy in his class - and has forgotten what happened in those. His schoolmates are furious that he has landed the role sought after by thousands of children in Britain and by the most talented boy actors in Hollywood.

"A lot of other boys know that I've only read the first one or two books, and these boys are total fanatics. They've read all four," said Daniel, 11.

Yesterday the world's press had a glimpse of the definitive Harry Potter, as Daniel, the British boy chosen from among 40,000 to play the hero of JK Rowling's books, was put before 15 camera crews and more than 100 reporters in London.

The press conference, which exposed Daniel and his co-stars Rupert Grint, 11, and Emma Watson, 10, to half an hour of questions, was unusual. It was an exercise by Warner Bros, the force behind the $100m film, to prevent press intrusion later.

Chris Columbus, the director, said he had "learned a big lesson" when he directed the child star Macauley Caulkin in the 1990s hits Home Alone and Home Alone 2, referring to the family trauma and unhappiness that Caulkin's fame and money brought him.

"Subsequently, I was concerned that when we dealt with the children who got these roles we would make sure the parents were wonderful as well, because I felt a need to protect these kids against the onslaught of publicity."

He said JK Rowling had been "very emotional. She said 'This is exactly the boy I pictured... This is exactly the face I've seen'."

fields.headline: Chocolate
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the dark, sweet stuff that is being hailed as the dentist's friend
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the dark, sweet stuff that is being hailed as the dentist's friend
fields.body:
1) Not since the news that alcohol may be good for you has a piece of scientific research so gladdened the heart. According to New Scientist, chocolate may help fight tooth decay.

2) The boffins behind this latest revelation spent months at Osaka university in Japan feeding some lucky rats a mix of sugar and cocoa extract in their drinking water. Other rats were fed a sugar-only solution.

3) After three months, the cocoa-drinking rats' teeth were significantly healthier than those of their straight-sugar counterparts.

4) Scientists concluded that chocolate contains anti-bacterial agents which fight Streptococcus mutans - bacteria that dentists have pinpointed as the cause of tooth decay.

5) Of course, some people have always claimed chocolate is good for you. You can read a page of expert research outlining the facts right here. It's funded by Mars (who make the bars), incidentally.

6) As the average Briton munches through his - or (with women accounting for 67% of chocolate consumption) more likely her - annual 10kg or so of the stuff, it's unlikely that health questions will be uppermost in the mind. Apparently, women love it, and - according to a Mori poll - they prefer to it sex.

7) This may be because chocolate has been credited with producing the same chemicals as are released in the brain by feelings of love. It is also considered by some to be an aphrodisiac. Wouldn't it be good if you could bottle and sell this Chocolate Love juice?

8) If you just want to indulge, you'll find a host of chocolate recipes online and much more besides in this a 776-site chocolate web guide.

9) You could send some guaranteed tooth-friendly "virtual chocolate" to a friend. Or even "soap yourself with chocolate lather and become the dessert in your sweetest fudge fantasy".

10) If you've got to this point, you may need help. But e-group support for chocoholics is out there. For some, it may have come a little late.

fields.headline: Shayler gets bail
fields.trailText: Former MI5 officer David Shayler was today formally charged in court with breaking the Official Secrets Act and bailed.
fields.body:
Former MI5 officer David Shayler was today formally charged in court with breaking the Official Secrets Act and bailed.

He was bailed on the condition that he lived with his brother Philip in Wimbledon, south-west London, and was also given permission to stay with a friend on Teesside so he could watch Saturday's match against Leeds United at the Riverside Stadium.

Mr Shayler appeared calm and relaxed as he stood in the dock of court one at Bow Street magistrates court, central London.

Outside the court he said he was "very glad" the legal process had got under way, adding: "I'm very glad that the magistrate was sympathetic enough to me to let go and see Middlesbrough."

He faces two charges of breaking section one of the 1989 Official Secrets Act, over an article in the Mail on Sunday in which he made allegations about his former employer, MI5.

In the article, he claimed that security chiefs had kept files on prominent Labour politicians, including Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson, Home Secretary Jack Straw - who was described as a "communist sympathiser" - and had also kept files on former Beatle John Lennon and punk band the Sex Pistols. The formal charge read: "On or before the 24th day of August 1997 within the jurisdiction of the Central Criminal Court being a person who has been a member of the security and intelligence services without lawful authority disclosed documents relating to security or intelligence which were in your possession by virtue of your position."

Mr Shayler's solicitor John Wadham, of the civil rights group Liberty, told the magistrate that the 34-year-old former agent would be pleading not guilty at a later hearing.

Mr Shayler claims that his allegations were made in the public interest and did not damage national security. New European human rights legislation, that will become part of English law in October, may provide him with a defence against the charges.

Mr Shayler, 34, was arrested by Special Branch officers at Dover on Monday after returning from three years self-imposed "political exile" in France, and immediately taken to Charing Cross police station where he was charged and released on bail.

The charges do not include the more serious allegations Mr Shayler went on to make in the media, including claims that MI6 was behind a bungled plot to assassinate Libyan leader Colonel Gaddafi that left several civilians dead.

webTitle: Cole back as Keegan sticks to his guns

fields.headline: Cole back as Keegan sticks to his guns
fields.trailText: Andy Cole has been given the chance to stake his claim as Alan Shearer's successor after he was called into Kevin Keegan's England squad for the friendly against France in Paris on Saturday week.
fields.body:
Andy Cole has been given the chance to stake his claim as Alan Shearer's successor after he was called into Kevin Keegan's England squad for the friendly against France in Paris on Saturday week.

Cole is one of the few changes from the squad that Keegan unsuccessfully took to Euro 2000. There is a recall for Tottenham's Darren Anderton, currently free from injury, and a promotion for Tony Adams who, as predicted, takes over from Shearer as England captain. David James also reclaims the position of third choice keeper ahead of Richard Wright. Elsewhere however, change is notable by its absence.

There is space in the 28-man squad for both Neville brothers, as well as old-timers like Paul Ince, Dennis Wise and David Seaman. Of the younger generation, only Gareth Barry, Kieron Dyer and Steven Gerrard have made the grade - two of whom were selected for Euro 2000.

Keegan defended his cautious selection at a press conference this afternoon. "I can find good enough reasons not to experiment for this game," he said. "This one game against France is the only one I have to prepare for the qualifiers against Germany and Finland and I need to get this right."

Keegan refused to be downbeat following England's failure in Holland and Belgium and remains confident that his team can prove their ability on the international stage. "I still believe we have the players. We didn't perform at Euro 2000 as a team," he said.

"We see the ability every week in the Premiership, playing well in excellent sides, but because of the shortage of time together and the fact you never get the chance to play a settled side you don't get a chance to experiment."

webTitle: Lippi faces the sack after Champions League humiliation

fields.headline: Lippi faces the sack after Champions League humiliation
fields.trailText: Marcello Lippi, the man who Alex Ferguson rates as the "best coach in Europe," is facing the sack today after his Internazionale side crashed out of the Champions League to Swedish part-timers Helsingborg.
fields.body:
Marcello Lippi, the man who Alex Ferguson rates as the "best coach in Europe," is facing the sack today after his Internazionale side crashed out of the Champions League to Swedish part-timers Helsingborg.

Despite losing the first leg 1-0, Inter went into the return match at the San Siro last night expecting a comfortable victory. But although they ripped through the Swedes' defensive line time and time again, they found Helsingborg's 36-year-old keeper Sven Andersson in sensational form.

He was called into action as early as the 10th minute, straining to reach a Zamorano header that crept just wide. And the barrage continued as twice in the space of two minutes Pirlo wriggled free of his markers to set up first Zamorano and then himself with good shooting opportunities.

At the start of the second half, Pirlo and Zamorano were replaced by Recoba and Keane, but Inter's onslaught continued. Keane hit the post with a back-heel in the 52nd minute and then was brilliantly denied 10 minutes later by Andersson after he followed up a fierce Jugovic shot.

fields.headline: McManaman ready to leave Real
fields.trailText: Steve McManaman may finally be ready to admit defeat in his bid to stay at Real Madrid. The England international, who has been told he is unlikely to feature in the Real first team at all this season, had pledged to fight for his place at the Bernabeu. But according to reports in this morning's Spanish press, he could be ready to change his mind.
fields.body:
Steve McManaman may finally be ready to admit defeat in his bid to stay at Real Madrid. The England international, who has been told he is unlikely to feature in the Real first team at all this season, had pledged to fight for his place at the Bernabeu. But according to reports in this morning's Spanish press, he could be ready to change his mind.

"I think I deserve some respect," McManaman was reported as saying by Spanish sports daily Marca after being left out of Madrid's squad for the European Super Cup this Friday. "They should give me an explanation as to why I'm not going to Monaco, but so far no one has spoken to me," he said.

McManaman has previously suggested that he is prepared to bide his time with the European Champions, but in today's interview he gave a different impression. "I need to play," he told Marca. "I would like to play for England in the next World Cup, and at the moment that is going to be very difficult."

If the former Liverpool star is prepared to leave the Bernabeu, it is thought that he would prefer to remain on the continent than return to England. But, as yet, the only club to make Real a firm offer is Bryan Robson's Middlesbrough. "I am going to speak with my agent to study the situation and take the best decision for me", McManaman said.

webTitle: TV viewers see Kursk relative forcibly sedated

fields.headline: TV viewers see Kursk relative forcibly sedated
fields.trailText: A grieving mother was forcibly injected with a sedative as she challenged the Russian deputy prime minister over the death of her son on the sunken Kursk nuclear submarine.
fields.body:
A grieving mother was forcibly injected with a sedative as she challenged the Russian deputy prime minister over the death of her son on the sunken Kursk nuclear submarine.

The incident - a grim reminder of techniques used by KGB officers in the Soviet era - was captured on film by Russian television, which showed the woman collapsing soon after the injection.

It happened at a meeting between relatives of Kursk sailors and government ministers at Vidyayevo, where the submariners were based.

The film shows the middle-aged woman pleading with Ilya Klebanov, the deputy prime minister, who is heading an inquiry into last week's tragedy in which 118 sailors died in the Barents Sea.

"How much longer are we going to have to endure this?" she asks Mr Klebanov. "They are there in a tin can and for £35 a month. Do you have children? Surely not!" she cries, greatly distressed.

A naval officer tries to calm her as she confronts the minister, but she does not react. She shouts at Mr Klebanov: "Take off your medals!"

Then a medic approaches her from behind and injects her with a sedative. The woman collapses.

The Russian navy told the local television station in Murmansk which captured the incident on film that such actions were acceptable and part of normal practice.

webTitle: FO report backs exiled islanders' fight with UK

fields.headline: FO report backs exiled islanders' fight with UK
fields.standfirst: Diego Garcia US Military Sealift Command
fields.trailText: The unsavoury saga of the British treatment of the Diego Garcia islanders took a new twist yesterday when an unpublished report commissioned by the Foreign Office supported their case to return home.
fields.body:
The unsavoury saga of the British treatment of the Diego Garcia islanders took a new twist yesterday when an unpublished report commissioned by the Foreign Office supported their case to return home.

The feasibility report severely undermines the position taken by the Foreign Office, which is fighting a high court action by the islanders, who were forced from the Indian ocean territory in 1973 in order to make way for a US air and naval base.

The £55,000 report, commissioned from independent consultants by the Foreign Office in March and completed in June, concludes that "resettlement of one or both of the atolls is physically possible".

That 123-page document, instead of being published, was buried in the House of Commons library at the end of July, just as MPs were disappearing for the summer recess.

In July the islanders brought an action in the high court in London, demanding to be allowed to return to two islands neighbouring Diego Garcia: Salomons and Peros Banhos.

A Foreign Office spokeswoman said yesterday she was unable to comment as the issue was still sub judice. Following a week of hearings in July, a court judgment is expected early in October.

Richard Gifford, the lawyer for the islanders, described the Foreign Office's attempt to obstruct the islanders from returning as "nonsense. We are not just talking about populating islands but repopulating them. There were lots of people living there before."

Most of the islanders were resettled on Mauritius and the remainder in the Seychelles, but both groups have had difficulty in assimilating. The Foreign Office is sceptical about how many would want to return but Mr Gifford said that of 3,800 people who responded to a questionnaire in Mauritius, only one did not want to return. A further 500 exiles live in the Seychelles.

He described the report as "a first step to implementing a return", adding: "The Foreign Office is obviously very cagey about costs but essentially it is quite possible."

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and his ministers are believed to be uncomfortable with the issue given the islands' disreputable colonial history. But they believe that they have to deal with the world as it is, rather than as it was.

The islands are among only a dozen overseas territories controlled by Britain, the remnants of the empire.

The Foreign Office is in a bind because it has leased the islands to the US for 50 years, with an option of extending. Although the base - used by B52 bombers during the Gulf war - is on Diego Garcia, the US says it does not want people on the neighbouring islands for security reasons.

The Foreign Office is also arguing that, after being uninhabited for 30 years, there are feasibility problems about resettlement. This is why it ordered the independent report.

The report, The Resettlement of the Salomons and Peros Banhos Atolls, was written by five consultants: an environmentalist, an economist, a fisheries expert, a water engineer and a natural resources expert.

They went to the islands from May 9- 14. The main concerns were whether there was a proper water supply, whether the necessary infrastructure could be built and the prospects for a viable economy.

The consultants concluded resettlement was possible, provided various conditions were met. These included confirmation that a sustainable and affordable water supply can be developed. They found fresh water but further studies would be needed to determine if there was enough. They said alternative ways of supplying water could be found.

Other conditions were: that the environment was not damaged; that public money was available to finance infrastructure; and that one or more private investors were willing to develop viable enterprises.

The report suggested various proposals for generating economic activity, including tourism. "There is some potential for low-level tourist-based development, even if an airport is not built."

This could include offering services to visiting diving safaris and yachtsmen. However, this would provide only a small number of jobs.

"Fisheries development appears to be the best potential to support a settled population," the report said. If the owner of a mother vessel in Mauritius was to switch operations to the islands, direct employment could be provided for up to 60 fishermen. Support services would provide further jobs.

fields.headline: £1.6m tag on Isaac Newton's papers
fields.standfirst: Cambridge University campaign to buy key scientific collection
fields.trailText: Cambridge University yesterday launched a £1.6m campaign to buy the most important British collection of scientific papers held in private hands.
fields.body:
Cambridge University yesterday launched a £1.6m campaign to buy the most important British collection of scientific papers held in private hands.

The Macclesfield collection - held in the home of the Earl of Macclesfield for nearly 300 years - is an archive of documents, manuscripts and correspondence of Sir Isaac Newton, the genius of Woolsthorpe, Lincolnshire, who used mathematics to unlock the mysteries of the universe.

Among the documents are letters concerning his dispute with the German genius Liebniz, over which of them first devised the calculus, the mathematical tool that has baffled generations of students, but helped solve the secrets of gravity and motion. Other papers will throw light on Newton's studies of optics, chemistry, comets - and the history of the Bible.

Cambridge already has the greater part of Newton's scientific papers, presented by the Earl of Portsmouth to the university in 1872.

The actual cost of the purchase, brokered as a private treaty sale by Sotheby's, is £6.37m. The heritage lottery fund has already promised to put up the maximum permitted, £4.79m. But the university now has to find the rest.

If it scrapes together the necessary £1.6m, it will get its hands on five metres of shelf space, containing original manuscripts in all their annotations, inscribed in quill pen by one of the most prolific thinkers of all time.

There are also letters and documents from contemporaries such as Isaac Barrow, his patron at Cambridge, Robert Boyle, the chemist, and Pierre Fermat, of the notorious Fermat's Last Theorem, who actually wrote complaining about a plague of mice.

Newton was first a poor undergraduate at Trinity College, Cambridge, and then at 26 became the Lucasian professor of mathematics, a chair now occupied by Stephen Hawking, before moving to London to become Master of the Mint.

If the bid is successful, Cambridge will stage an exhibition next year - and place some of the material on the web.

"I very much hope we can keep this collection in Britain where Newton did his work," said Prof Hawking.

If the university cannot raise all the money, it could cut other library spending to keep the Newton papers. "His contributions to mathematics are pretty much without parallel," said Peter Lipton, a Cambridge science historian.

Newton wrote several million words in his lifetime: his energy and his output, and above all his authority, astounded his contemporaries.

The Macclesfield papers, initially collected by a contemporary called John Collins, contain mathematical studies in Latin, and his dispute over the credit for the calculus. Newton could be a cold and vengeful man in later life. But scholars in search of an academic knife fight might be disappointed.

"These are very polite letters from a young man to someone who is, in a sense, discovering," said Scott Mandelbrote, a historian at Peterhouse College.

Newton lived through the religious turmoil of the 17th century. He was fascinated by alchemy and theology. Dr Mandelbrote is one of the editors of a project to publish his religious writings.

Facts and legend

 The story about the apple falling on Newton's head is probably a myth, dating from the 18th century. But Newton's head appeared on the last British £1 note, together with apple blossom.

 Newton once inserted a needle or bodkin into his eye to squeeze the eyeball and distort the lens so that he could learn about the optics of vision.

 As warden of the Mint from 1696 to 1700, Newton interrogated counterfeiters and clippers of coins, taking depositions in taverns and in Newgate. Under his regime, 19 forgers were executed at Tyburn in 1697 and eight in 1698. "They are like dogs," he said, "ever ready to return to their vomit."

 Halley, of Halley's comet, said of Newton: "Nearer the gods no mortal may approach." The philosopher Hume called him "the greatest and rarest genius that ever arose." Alexander Pope began a couplet "God said: Let Newton be." John Locke called him "the incomparable Mr Newton".

 Newton's niece, Catherine Barton, was celebrated in verse by Jonathan Swift, and called "charming" by Voltaire. The Earl of Halifax - who was believed to be her lover - left her £5,000 in cash and £20,000 in property "for the pleasure and happiness I have had in her conversation".

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the transfer talk filtered through ancient limestone to a depth of 1500m and bottled at source
fields.trailText: Chelsea are about to sign Real Madrid winger Savio, according to onefootball.com. Real want to sign Marcelo Salas from Lazio but are struggling to raise the £23m they need to prise the Chilean away from theSerie A champions. They're prepared to sacrifice Savio in order to raise £14m, and Gianluca Vialli has entered discussions with the player's representatives, having grown tired of chasing after Boudewijn Zenden.
fields.body:
Chelsea are about to sign Real Madrid winger Savio, according to onefootball.com. Real want to sign Marcelo Salas from Lazio but are struggling to raise the £23m they need to prise the Chilean away from theSerie A champions. They're prepared to sacrifice Savio in order to raise £14m, and Gianluca Vialli has entered discussions with the player's representatives, having grown tired of chasing after Boudewijn Zenden.

Ronald de Boer is unhappy at being left out of the Barcelona side which faced PSV Eindhoven on Tuesday. "I don't want to be the 16th or 17th man in the team," he wrote on his website. "I'm too good for that. If I have to, I will consider looking for another club." Arsenal are keeping tabs on the situation, and may offer Barca £6m for the 30-year-old midfielder.

Roma defender Sergei Gurenko is a target for Newcastle, according to Planet Football. The 27-year-old former Lokomotiv Moscow player would cost a minimum of £2m.

Steve Coppell and Lennie Lawrence are in the running for the vacant manager's job at Grimsby.

Ruel Fox's £150,000 move from Tottenham to West Bromwich Albion could be back on. The club has agreed new terms with the 32-year-old winger and the player could line up against Barnsley on Saturday.

Portsmouth are ready to offer Stockport £1m for striker Ian Moore.

David Platt hopes to persuade DC United winger Ben Olsen to join Nottingham Forest after the upcoming Olympic Games. The 24-year-old Olsen has won 17 caps for the United States.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Fault found?

When Paddy McCarthy of Malvern realised that his new Epson printer was wasting ink, he sent the machine back for tests. The Epson engineer declared in a written report that no fault had been found. Six months later, after he'd complained twice more, Epson wrote that a fault had been found during the original test but that he'd not requested a repair. As the machine was now out of warranty he'd have to pay for the work himself. McCarthy reminded them of the engineer's all clear and Epson then seized on this as proof that, "as previously stated", no fault had been found with the printer. Any problem must therefore be a new one and outside the warranty period. "I've reviewed all the correspondence and it is clear to me that the Epson position has been clearly stated," wrote a customer services leader without a trace of irony.

There is still a sense of dizzy bafflement at Epson. "It appears that some confusion has occured between both parties," says a spokeswoman. In fact, the correspondence shows that the confusion is Epson's alone. However, the company has now agreed to take back the machine for a free service and to loan McCarthy a replacement.

Van import nightmare

As UK vehicle prices are nearly twice as high as elsewhere in the EU, enterprising drivers are buying their cars abroad and registering them here. However, S Munjee of Hitchin in Hertfordshire will think twice before trying that ruse again. Before buying a new Renault Master in Dublin he was assured by the DVLA that, provided he obtained an EU certificate of conformity, he would have no problem registering the vehicle in the UK. He duly presented the paperwork and paid the fees - only to be told that the certificate had been rejected. No, the DVLA couldn't tell him why, but said that the vehicle certifications agency would oblige.

The VCA, alas, refuses to speak to the public and referred him back to the DVLA - which said its lips were sealed. Eventually he was directed to single vehicle approval which exists for vehicles not approved under EU manufacturing regulations and is based on a quota of 50 vehicles a year. Munjee then had to fork out an extra £60 to have his brand-new EU-manufactured van registered this way. "The inspector who carried out the test was surprised when I showed him my certificate of conformity and Renault UK confirmed the paperwork was legal and correct," he says. "Vans therefore must comply with our national type approval standards and the manufacturer must issue a certificate of conformity." Munjee apparently had just that but the DVLA says it can't comment on specific cases. Nor can car-buyers guarantee a smooth ride. "The documents for EU imports should be common to all the member states because of the harmonised standards, but in practice there are many problems with different countries or manufacturers doing things differently," says the DVLA.

Rapid u-turn

Shortly before the warranty expired on Steven Kirby's new camera, a fault developed. No problem, said our old friend Tiny: just send it back and we'll repair or replace it. Three days later another camera arrived in the post. Kirby, of North Yorkshire, was thrilled - until he examined it. "It turned out to be a refurbish job and not a very good one," he says. Tiny initially agreed to replace the flawed replacement, then Kirby received a call telling him to take it or leave it. Two letters to the managing director met with silence.

This must be the quickest u-turn in Consumer's life. At 16.10 we emailed Tiny's press office. By 17.01 the company had reviewed the case and dispatched an upgraded camera to Kirby.

More BA ticket trauma

A former airline employee was startled by our recent letter concerning the hefty fee charged if passengers want to change the name on a flight booking. British Airways declared in self-defence that such an amendment meant cancelling the old booking and making a new one, even if tickets have not yet been issued. Nonsense, says our correspondent. "Changing the name in the BA booking system takes about 30 seconds," she says, "and involves typing '-1=' to delete the old name, then '-' followed by the new name and, finally, 'E' to close the booking file."

 "The time it takes to change a name on an airline ticket is not the point," says BA. "It is industry practice that tickets are non-transferable in order to prevent a secondary market in air tickets. Unscrupulous people could buy up tickets and sell them on like sports ticket touts. In cases where a genuine error has taken place, we try to reissue the ticket for a small administration charge."

The phantom of 1st Line continues to stalk beyond the grave. W Wayne of Oxford was called by the now defunct telesales company in December and offered a trial mobile phone. He was allowed 14 days in which to cancel the agreement without charge and he duly did so. However, the service provider, Cellular Operations, claims that the phone reached them after the deadline and has repeatedly billed him despite the fact that he has sent them proof of postage.

Oh the headiness of media power! Cellular Ops suddenly sees the light the day that Consumer rings, Wayne has been recredited and the account closed.

webTitle: Next year's Test dates, and other FAQs

fields.headline: Next year's Test dates, and other FAQs
fields.trailText: To celebrate a year of Ask Steven, this week we've collected together some FAQs - Frequently Asked Questions.
fields.body:
To celebrate a year of Ask Steven, this week we've collected together some FAQs - Frequently Asked Questions.

Have next year's Test dates in England been announced yet?

Yes, they have. England start with two Tests against Pakistan, at Lord's (May 17-21) and Old Trafford (May 31-June 4). The three-way NatWest one-day competition, also involving Australia, starts on June 7, with the final at Lord's on June 23. Then England try to regain the Ashes from Australia, who have held them since 1989. The five Tests are at Edgbaston (July 5-9), Lord's (July 19-23), Trent Bridge (August 2-6), Headingley (August 16-20), and The Oval (August 23-27). Those last two Tests start on successive Thursdays, in an attempt to cram three matches into the prime holiday month of August. It will be the first time England have played back-to-back Tests at home since 1912.

I am trying to complete my collection of Wisden Almanacks. Where would be the best place to start looking, and would they be expensive?

The Wisden office in Guildford (Tel: 01483 570358) has most recent back issues dating from around 1980. If you want older Almanacks, your best bet would be to try a specialist cricket-book dealer. A list of them appears each year in Wisden - in the 2000 book it's on page 1565. You might well find that the early editions are rather expensive, and a cheaper alternative might be to contact the Willows Publishing Company (17 The Willows, Stone, Staffordshire ST15 0DE), who have produced facsimile editions of the early years of Wisden.

What are England's international dates this winter?

After the "Mini World Cup" in Kenya, England are making their first tour of Pakistan since 1987-88. They will be making a nervous return to the Iqbal Stadium in Faisalabad, scene of the ugly incident between Mike Gatting and umpire Shakoor Rana which disfigured that last tour. There will be three one-day internationals - at Karachi (Oct 24), Lahore (Oct 27) and Rawalpindi (Oct 29) - followed by three Tests, at Lahore (Nov 15-19), Faisalabad (Nov 29-Dec 3), and Karachi (Dec 7-11). After a break for Christmas, England undertake a similar programme in Sri Lanka. The Tests will be at Galle (Feb 22-26), Kandy (March 7-11) and Colombo (March 15-19), and the ODIs will all be in Colombo (March 23, 25 and 27).

When was the last time England won a Test series in Pakistan?

England have only won one series in Pakistan - indeed they have only ever won one Test there, the first one played, at Lahore in 1961-62. Ted Dexter was England's captain in that series, which England won 1-0: he finished with 66 not out as his side reached 209-5 to win by five wickets, and in the third match at Karachi Dexter made 205, his highest Test score. That 1961-62 series was a peculiar one: the first Test was played in October 1961, and the second in January 1962, after England played five Tests in India. Since then England have made five Test-playing tours of Pakistan: the 1968-69, 1972-73 and 1977-78 series were drawn 0-0, then Pakistan won 1-0 in both 1983-84 and 1987-88.

Is it true that a Test match was once left drawn because one team had to leave to catch the boat home?

It actually happened twice. The most famous occasion was the "Timeless Test" of 1938-39 at Durban, when England, set 696 to win by South Africa, had reached 654-5 on the tenth day when they had to leave to catch the train to Cape Town to meet the boat home. But it had also happened nine years before, in Jamaica. England batted first and made 849 (Andy Sandham 325, the first Test triple-century). West Indies then made 286, but England, 563 ahead, didn't enforce the follow-on: instead they batted again and made 272-9. The declaration left West Indies the little matter of 836 to win: by the end of the seventh day they had reached 408-5 (George Headley 223). Rain washed out the next two days, at which point England had to go home - so another "Timeless Test" was left drawn.

Can you please explain the many variations in the legspinner's armoury?

You have come to the right place, because I'm a legspinner, although not quite in the Shane Warne class (who is?). The flipper is a difficult-to-bowl delivery which is squeezed out under the wrist, with an action rather like that used to click the fingers. When it's bowled properly, the ball hurries on to the batsman, who can be beaten by the unexpected pace. Shane Warne has often dismissed Daryll Cullinan with this ball. Warne claims to have invented the "zooter", so we asked Mark Ray, the Australian journalist who helped write Warne's autobiography, how you bowl it. He said: "It's difficult to explain without drawings ... but basically the zooter comes out of the front of the hand, with the fingers running across it sideways, like a legbreak - but the ball is propelled more by the palm. It's not unlike a knuckle ball, but not as slow. The zooter does very little in the air or off the pitch - which is part of the point. It's not flatter like the flipper, which is under-spun - the zooter sort of wobbles down." So now we know!

Has a team ever won a Test after following on?

It has been done twice - both times by England! The only recent occasion was the famous match at Headingley in 1981, when Ian Botham turned the match on its head with a rollicking 149 not out after England, following on, had been 135 for 7 and still 92 behind Australia. Botham's heroics lifted England to 356, a lead of 129. Bob Willis, with 8 for 43, then bowled Australia out for 111 and England had won by 18 runs. The other time was in 1894-95, when England (325 and 437) came from behind to beat Australia (586 and 166) by ten runs after following on at Sydney.

Who scored most Test runs in the 1990s?

This was Alec Stewart of England, who made 6407 runs in 93 Tests in the 1990s, just ahead of Mark Waugh (6371 from 99 matches), Mark Taylor (6306 from 93), Mike Atherton (6217 from 91) and Steve Waugh (6213 from 89). In sixth place was Sachin Tendulkar, with 5626 runs from only 69 matches, at a higher average (58.00) than any of the five men above him.

How can I get hold of past issues of Wisden Cricket Monthly?

Details of available back issues are given each month in WCM: you'll find it on page 37 of the current (September) issue. The usual price (in the UK) is £2.90, but several cost only £1. You should send a cheque, payable to Wisden Cricket Magazines Ltd, to Wisden, 25 Down Road, Merrow, Guildford, Surrey GU1 2PY. Back issues should soon be available on wisden.com - watch this space.

Who has hit the most sixes in an over in a first-class match?

Two people have hit the maximum six sixes in an over: Garry Sobers, while playing for Nottinghamshire against Glamorgan at Swansea in 1968 (the bowler was Malcolm Nash), and the Indian Test allrounder Ravi Shastri, who struck Tilak Raj for six sixes for Bombay v Baroda at Bombay in 1984-85. In contrived circumstances at Christchurch in 1989-90 the future New Zealand captain Lee Germon actually hit eight sixes in one over from Wellington's Bert Vance, but he was bowling deliberate no-balls (the over lasted for 22 deliveries) to encourage the batsmen to attack a target. It was a farcical situation: the scoreboard attendants couldn't keep up, while the umpires lost track of the number of legitimate balls bowled, and called "over" after only five non-no-balls. The match eventually finished as a draw with the scores level.

Where can you find cricket stats on the net?

You can find updated records elsewhere on this site (www.wisden.com). CricInfo (www.cricket.org) has an extensive archive of records and past scorecards. It also has a handy "Stats Guru" page where you can work out combinations of statistics for players against particular countries or between certain dates: the Indian site www.khel.com has a similar feature. There are lots of other cricket websites as well: just search for "cricket" and see what happens!

Where can I find the new 2000 Code of Laws?

The new laws were approved by MCC members at a recent meeting, and will come into force on October 1, after the current English season finishes. The new Laws are given in the new edition of the Wisden Almanack, and can also be found on MCC's website (click here).

How does the County Championship points system work?

The points system has changed a lot over the years - and it has changed again for the current season. The easy part is that the side winning the match gets 12 points, and both sides receive four points in a drawn game (six points each for a tie; no points for losing). The complicated bit is the bonus points, which are only available in the first 130 overs of each side's first innings. You can earn a maximum of five batting bonus points, for passing 200, 250, 300, 350 and 400. And you get bowling points - a maximum of three - for taking three, six and nine wickets. So the maximum number of points a county can score in a game is 20.

Is there a layman's guide to the Duckworth-Lewis system on the web?

The Duckworth-Lewis method of deciding targets in rain-affected one-day games is not easy to understand, but basically the system works out what resources are left to the batting side - if you have all ten wickets standing, that's 100% of your wicket resources, and if you have used up 20 of your 50 overs when it rains, that's 60% of your overs left. You put the two together, find out the overall resources available and compare that to the other team's total. You can find an explanation of the system, written by Messrs (or Professors) Duckworth and Lewis themselves, on CricInfo (click here).

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read his previous Q&A session, on rating the best Test bowling of all time, click here.

We regret that not all questions can be answered and that personal correspondence can only sometimes be entered into

fields.headline: First internet wedding goes online
fields.standfirst: Marriage room at Brent Town Hall
fields.trailText: The first wedding in England and Wales to be broadcast on the internet from a council register office was held this morning at Brent Town Hall, north-west London.
fields.body:
The first wedding in England and Wales to be broadcast on the internet from a council register office was held this morning at Brent Town Hall, north-west London.

Brent Council installed a web cam in its register office, allowing a potential global audience of millions to log on as Ravi Ram and his girlfriend Mamta Patel take their vows.

From now on, the council plans to allow all weddings in the borough's register office to be broadcast online at no extra cost.

"The idea is that if your family are abroad or cannot get to the ceremony they can see the wedding take place," said Pascoe Sawyers.

Mr Sawyers said the cost to council taxpayers will be minimal. "We have all the facilities set up - it is just the cost of a camera," he said.

About 30 non-virtual guests will attend the wedding of Ravi Ram, a psychiatric nurse from Harrow, north west London, and his girlfriend of three years Mamta Patel, 24, assistant manager at a residential home.

However, dozens more friends and family will be logging on to watch the event from Mr Ram's homeland of Mauritius. His sister, Doorga, a social work student, will watch the wedding in cyberspace from the University of Mauritius.

Mr Ram said: "Doorga is still studying, so she couldn't make it to the wedding - the web cam is the perfect way for her to be part of the ceremony.

Miss Patel however said her family in Gujarat, India, would not be able to take advantage of the on-line ceremony.

She said: "I've got a lot of uncles, aunts and cousins in Gujarat but they are all in tiny little villages.

"But I've got friends abroad, especially in the US, who will be watching the wedding on the net."

The couple's wedding ceremony comes before a full traditional Hindu wedding in Wembley at the weekend with more than 300 guests

The Chief Registrar for Brent Council, Mark Rimmer, said the idea had come from a New Zealand couple: "This couple wanted to let their families back home in New Zealand watch their ceremony and share their special day.

"At the time we didn't have web cam facilities and instead they ended up ringing home on three or four mobile phones which let the people back home listen to the marriage ceremony."

For the time being the images are still pictures, updated every 15 seconds, which are immediately transferred to the Brent Council website.

Mr Rimmer said: "At the moment it broadcasts still pictures which are refreshed about every 15 seconds, but we are looking to set it up so it will be broadcast live as it happens - with sound and everything.

Mr Ram said: "Doorga is still studying, so she couldn't make it to the wedding - the web cam is the perfect way for her to be part of the ceremony. Miss Patel however said her family in Gujarat, India, would not be able to take advantage of the on-line ceremony. She said: "I've got a lot of uncles, aunts and cousins in Gujarat but they are all in tiny little villages. "But I've got friends abroad, especially in the US, who will be watching the wedding on the net." The couple's wedding ceremony comes before a full traditional Hindu wedding in Wembley at the weekend with more than 300 guests The Chief Registrar for Brent Council, Mark Rimmer, said the idea had come from a New Zealand couple: "This couple wanted to let their families back home in New Zealand watch their ceremony and share their special day. "At the time we didn't have web cam facilities and instead they ended up ringing home on three or four mobile phones which let the people back home listen to the marriage ceremony." For the time being the images are still pictures, updated every 15 seconds, which are immediately transferred to the Brent Council website. Mr Rimmer said: "At the moment it broadcasts still pictures which are refreshed about every 15 seconds, but we are looking to set it up so it will be broadcast live as it happens - with sound and everything.

webTitle: Musketeers film short of authentic French extras

fields.headline: One for all, and all for a genuine French face
fields.trailText: So many foreigners have moved into the Gers region of south-west France that an American remake of the Three Musketeers being shot there is having trouble finding bucolic locals to fill the crowd scenes.
fields.body:
So many foreigners have moved into the Gers region of south-west France that an American remake of the Three Musketeers being shot there is having trouble finding bucolic locals to fill the crowd scenes.

"We want faces with character, faces that have been marked by a peasant life. All we can come up with here are sleek urban physiognomies," said Dominique Lafitte of Ciné 32, the French company charged with hiring the extras for the new swashbuckler, D'Artagnan.

The director, Peter Hyams, whose previous films include Timecop, Sudden Death and End of Days, has cast an American model, Justin Chambers, in the title role of the £35m epic. Tim Roth (pictured) is playing Athos and Catherine Deneuve the queen of France.

But attempts to find 700 careworn peasants for scenes to be shot next month on location in Gers and nearby Haute-Garonne have floundered.

D'Artagnan, Athos, Porthos and Aramis, the heroes of three hugely successful novels by Alexandre Dumas, originally hailed from Gascony, an ancient French duchy now divided into several administrative districts, including Gers, Haute-Garonne and Lot.

According to the latest census, more than 700 Britons, 400 Dutch and 300 Germans live permanently in the Gers, while hundreds - possibly thousands - more own holiday homes. Meanwhile the native population has fallen by as much as 50% over the past half-century.

fields.headline: A320: State of the art
fields.trailText: The A320 was the state of the art in airliner design when it entered service in April 1988 as the world's first fully computerised civil aircraft.
fields.body:
The A320 was the state of the art in airliner design when it entered service in April 1988 as the world's first fully computerised civil aircraft.

The 150-seat short- to medium-haul aircraft was the first commercial airliner to employ fly-by-wire technology using a computer to optimise the plane's performance.

The computer control prevents the plane from going too fast or making dangerous manoeuvres as well as ensuring efficient use of fuel.

The A320, with a range of 3,000 nautical miles, boasts 840 planes in service with 82 operators worldwide.

By the end of March 2000, the fleet had accumulated over 10.5m flight hours in over 6.1m departures.

It is the fastest-selling commercial aircraft in the world alongside the Boeing 737.

David Learmount, operations and safety editor of Flight International magazine said: "There were three fatal accidents in the first three years of the A320's life which had more to do with crews getting used to the new control systems than anything else."

In one accident, 87 people were killed near Strasbourg, in eastern France, when the aircraft flew into a mountain.

Mr Learmount said: "It was not because the control system went wrong, but because the pilots were not used to it."

Previous accidents

1988 An A320 crashed at the Mulhouse-Habsheim air show in eastern France, killing four people.

1990 Ninety-two people died when an Indian airlines A320 crashed near Bangalore airport in February 1990.

1992 87 killed when A320 crashed in Strasbourg

1995 The pilot of an Excalibur Airways A320 jet carrying 185 holidaymakers and seven crew could not turn left because British Airways engineers failed to reconnect controls after maintenance. The plane made a high-speed crash landing at Gatwick.

1998 Three killed when A320 crashed on landing in the Philippines.

1998 A Monarch Airlines A320 made two emergency landings at Luton airport on its way to Verona, Italy, from Manchester. None of the 156 passengers and seven crew were injured.

1998 A Spanish-bound Airtours A320 carrying 149 passengers from Gatwick had to divert to Stansted after engine panels fell off.

webTitle: It circled twice, then plunged into the sea

fields.headline: It circled twice, then plunged into the sea
fields.standfirst: Traffic jams around airport as relatives plead for news of passengers
fields.trailText: Gulf Air flight GF072 was on its scheduled afternoon service from the Egyptian capital Cairo. It is a relatively short hop, a two-hour flight. At this time of year the route is used by expatriate workers and families returning to Bahrain as the stifling summer heat begins to ease.
fields.body:
Gulf Air flight GF072 was on its scheduled afternoon service from the Egyptian capital Cairo. It is a relatively short hop, a two-hour flight. At this time of year the route is used by expatriate workers and families returning to Bahrain as the stifling summer heat begins to ease.

More than 200 relatives and friends had crowded into the airport terminal to welcome passengers. But as the Airbus A320 descended, the aircraft did not come straight in to touch down.

Instead, an air traffic controller at the airport described seeing the plane circle the runway twice, in an attempt to land, then on the third approach plunge into the sea and explode into flames.

He gave the time of the crash as 5.20pm BST; a statement by Gulf Air later gave the crash time as 5.30pm. The controller, who did not give his name, said he saw no sign of trouble before the crash.

A similar account came from two Bahrainis from the residential area of Al-Fodha close to the airport. They reported seeing the Gulf Air flight come in over their heads at a very low altitude heading to the runway. The plane then made a sharp turn out towards the sea.

Giving only their first names, Riyadh, 24, and Sobeih, 27, said the plane returned minutes later flying even lower but headed into the sea where it crashed. There were noises coming from the engines, but they too saw no flames.

A traffic jam quickly built up along the five-mile road from the capital, Manama, to the airport, which is on a small island east of the city.

The clamour of weeping relatives pleading to be let through echoed around the terminal but policemen threw a security ring around the airport.

In Manama, dozens of ambulances were seen heading toward the airport soon after the crash. Bodies retrieved from the scene were ferried to Salmaniya hospital, the country's largest medical centre.

Ibrahim Abdullah al-Hammar, under-secretary for civil aviation, later told Bahrain television that the pilot of the doomed plane had asked for a second approach after failing to land the first time.

"The aircraft... was conducting a normal approach into [the runway] at Bahrain international airport," he said. "Approximately one nautical mile from touchdown and at about 600 feet above sea level the aircraft commenced a go-around. During the go-around the aircraft impacted the sea approximately one nautical mile north of the airport."

US navy helicopters were on the scene quickly because Bahrain is the regional base of the US navy fifth fleet. The US also sent two destroyers and an ocean-going tug with a ten-ton crane to help the recovery operation.

Airbus Industrie, which assembles the planes in Toulouse, last night dispatched a team of specialists to Bahrain to help with the investigation. The Airbus A320 plane that crashed had been delivered to Gulf Air in September 1994. It had accumulated about 17,177 flight hours, Airbus said in a statement.

At Bahrain international airport late last night, a Gulf Air official read out to grieving relatives the names of people who had been aboard the plane. Some interrupted him with demands for more details, especially when he read out first names with only initials of surnames. "That's it, he's gone," said a Saudi man calmly, then fainted.

"This is the end of me," wailed an Egyptian woman, who was overcome with grief and could not say which of her relatives was on the plane.

"I want my son," another Egyptian women screamed.

A handful of relatives also began gathering at Cairo airport in search of information about the fate of their loved ones and friends. There were angry scenes when a relative tried to attack news cameramen and complained about the lack of information on the fate of the passengers. "Tell me this is not true," one man said before he broke down in a flood of tears.

The plane crash was the second in less than a year which has claimed a large number of Egyptian victims. Last October, an EgyptAir plane crashed into the ocean soon after taking off on a flight from New York to Cairo, killing all 217 people on board.

Gulf Air is owned by Bahrain, Oman and Qatar, as well as Abu Dhabi, the largest of the seven sheikhdoms making up the United Arab Emirates. Based in Bahrain, it flies to 53 international destinations.

webTitle: Man dies in loyalist feud shooting

fields.headline: Man dies in loyalist feud shooting
fields.trailText: The bitter feud between rival loyalist factions in Belfast is threatening to escalate further after another man was shot dead last night.
fields.body:
The bitter feud between rival loyalist factions in Belfast is threatening to escalate further after another man was shot dead last night.

The shooting came 27 hours after the re-arrest of Ulster Freedom Fighter boss Johnny Adair, who vowed to fight the decision to send him back to jail.

The victim, 21-year-old Sam Rocket, was gunned down last night just a few hundred yards from the scene of a double murder by the UVF on Monday.

Bobby Mahood, a close associate of Adair, and fellow militant Jackie Coulter, were shot in Belfast's Crumin Road. Mr Mahood will be buried today.

Mr Rocket was was shot as he sat in the living room of his girlfriend's home in Summer Street, off Cliftonpark Avenue on the north of the city, and died in hospital a short time later. His young daughter was also believed to have been in the room at the time of the attack. His family were reportedly expelled from the Ulster Defence Association - aligned to the UFF - in the mid-1990s and had switched allegiance to the rival Ulster Volunteer Force. The finger is already being pointed at the UFF, who blamed the UVF for the murders of Mr Mahood and Mr Coulter.

Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson condemned last night's murder as a "cowardly act bringing the loyalist feud to new depths".

Mr Mandelson yesterday stood by his decision to send "Mad Dog" Adair back to prison.

The UFF leader is planning legal action to overturn the decision and met his legal team at Co Antrim's Maghaberry prison to make preparations for a possible high court judicial review.

Mr Mandelson promised to fight any court action. He said: "I will maintain my decision in whatever forum I have to. I am entirely confident I was right.

"There is always a risk that maverick individuals will want to pursue this blood feud and we must be on our guard. But over time I believe the removal of Mr Adair will cause tension to subside.

"The Shankill community leaders I have been speaking to have said things are calm on the ground. There is no sense of any backlash."

He insisted recent violence did not mean the loyalist ceasefires had been broken, because he argued, an individual's wrongdoing was not necessarily directed by an organisation.

"By no means do all the UDA or UFF support or subscribe to the actions of Johnny Adair," he said.

Police yesterday questioned a man in connection with the double murder but released him without charge.

John White, of the Ulster Democratic Party, the UFF's political wing, said: "I have been trying to encourage people to start talking again. I have been told in no uncertain terms there will be no talking. The UFF want to extract their retribution."

Progressive Unionist Billy Hutchinson, whose party represents the rival Ulster Volunteer Force, said: "I think both organisations need to take a step back and look at where they are going but I would be concerned there will be more attacks.

"I understand that people will want revenge but there will have to be mediation eventually between the two organisations.

The sentence review commission will now examine Mr Mandelson's decision, taking written submissions from both the secretary of state and Adair's legal team. It will give a preliminary finding which either side can challenge at an oral hearing, which could lead to a high court judicial review if it is contested. If Adair loses, his earliest release date will be May 2002.
