fields.headline: Waiting for the telephone man
fields.standfirst: No one can believe how terrible the phone services are in the US, as   Jane Martinson in New York discovered
fields.trailText: Thursday 11.30am: No one can believe how terrible the phone services are in the US, as Jane Martinson in New York discovered.
fields.body:
Hell Atlantic they called it, before America's largest telecommunications company changed its name.

But the name change from Bell Atlantic to Verizon in June has done little to end the local telephone company's customer service problems.

This week, the company more or less settled a damaging 15-day fight with its largest unions.

During this time, 90,000 repair requests piled up and at least one customer did the company a favour and voluntarily removed herself from its 200,000 backlog waiting for services or new lines to be installed.

After more than four months of waiting for an ironically named high-speed network, I gave up.

Few foreigners arriving in America can believe how awful the telephone services are in some of the most developed cities in the world.

We are not talking about mobile phones, which everybody knows work better in a Mongolian yurt than on Madison Avenue. Just basic telephone services.

One friend working in Washington this summer had to wait weeks to be allowed to make international calls from home. Another in Brooklyn had to wait in for six consecutive days until they returned her dial tone.

My own problems started in April when I knew I had to do something about running a phone, fax and computer from one line at home.

Opting for for a digital subscriber line, or DSL, which is meant to offer a speedier web connection over an ordinary telephone line, I half hoped that choosing Mindspring, the internet service provider, to deliver the service would make a difference.

But I failed to realise that because Bell Atlantic, like all the former US telephone monopolies, operates the copper wires into homes and offices, it insists on sending its own engineers to make sure they work.

The initial email from Mindspring warned that the installation of a DSL line needed two engineering appointments.

The first would involve a Bell Atlantic technician working on something called a network interface device. This appointment would be an "all-day" one, meaning that somebody had to wait in from 8am to 6pm, just in case.

I worked at home all day and saw nobody. I went back to the initial jolly email and saw the warning that Bell Atlantic offers a "no-show" rate as high as 50 per cent on their installation appointments. So much for America, the home of service culture.

That was in May. Twice since then, Bell Atlantic has offered dates that neither myself nor my husband could make, once with just a day's notice.

I have seen one engineer during this odyssey. I refused to let him leave the apartment until he told me that our interface, or whatever it was, was working.

The company subsequently denied any such torture-induced promises and said that our line was still not ready for stage two of the installation nightmare.

Finally, we were told to expect a visit on 8 August and once more, nobody showed up.

This time, the fact that 86,000 of the company's workers had gone on strike two days earlier at least provided an excuse.

Then I phoned Time Warner, the local cable operator. There are complaints about its high-speed internet access service but at least I was given a weekend appointment with a wait time of just four hours.

Verizon, as it is now called, has admitted to some problems with its DSL services.

It has blamed the east coast's ageing infrastructure and dense population for some of them.

Earlier this month, it teamed up with a dedicated high-speed company called Northpoint communications to improve its DSL service.

A company spokesman said this week that most customers of this service had to wait just 15 working days from order to installation.

The strike had doubled this "average" waiting time for new customers this week. He said waiting more than four months without being much closer to delivery was unusual.

Companies such as Mindspring, which have had some success with their DSL services, have complained about the local telephone companies.

Some have threatened legal action while others have offered self-installation services to try to stop potential customers behaving the way I did.

One woman recently wrote to the New York Times saying she now made her cheques out to Hell Atlantic. She was hardly surprised that they still seemed to get cashed.

I wonder what would happen if she wrote Derision instead of Verizon?

fields.headline: Typhoon
fields.standfirst:
11 die as storm engulfs Taiwan

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Taiwan was hit by a ferocious "super-typhoon" yesterday which killed at least 11 people, injured 78, uprooted trees and hurled cars across the streets.
fields.body:
Taiwan was hit by a ferocious "super-typhoon" yesterday which killed at least 11 people, injured 78, uprooted trees and hurled cars across the streets.

Typhoon Bilis, the strongest in Asia this year, spun with devastating results right across the island, its 375-miles diameter more than Taiwan's entire length.

Seven women and a child died when they were buried by a mudslide. Three others were killed by collapsing walls or debris. Others remained missing as the typhoon moved on to mainland China.

Gusts of up to 160 mph were registered. Hundreds of Chinese fishermen were allowed ashore to escape waves up to nine metres (30ft) high.

More than 600,000 houses lost power. Government offices, banks and the stock market were closed, airline flights cancelled.

President Chen Shui-bian urged the military authorities to help, conscious of recent criticism of his new government when some workers were swept away by floods while rescuers argued.

fields.headline: Hammers lose with Styles
fields.trailText:
West Ham 0 - 1 Leicester
The dismmissal of Igor Stimac knocked the stuffing out of West Ham as they went down to a Darren Eadie goal.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin at  at Upton Park
fields.body:
It was business as usual for the Premiership here last night: a red card, a referee departing to a crescendo of abuse and both managers indignant with the official. The only surprise was that Patrick Vieira was not involved.

Instead the statutory early bath was taken by Igor Stimac, whose sending-off seconds before half-time helped Leicester to an unlikely win. Until then West Ham, inspired by Paolo di Canio, had looked irresistible. In the end they bowed to Darren Eadie's goal and are bottom of the table.

Harry Redknapp was less than impressed by Stimac's dismissal for a bodycheck on Robbie Savage after being booked earlier for hurling the ball down. West Ham's manager claimed Savage "makes a meal of everything" but saved most of his ire for the referee Rob Styles.

"Igor's not hurt anybody," he said. "He's not gone over the top or nearly broken someone's leg. It's nothing incidents they're sending people off for and suddenly it's not a game. It's one fighter with an arm tied behind his back.

"People want to watch a contest between 22 players, and they should be trying to keep it like that. But referees won't listen or change. You're dealing with people who've never played football."

At first glance it seemed Stimac could have little complaint, though even Leicester's manager Peter Taylor felt the Croatian was unfortunate. "I thought it was a harsh caution," he said. "I suppose the referees are under orders but I would have been disappointed to lose a player for that. Every time there's a free-kick there seems to be a caution these days."

Seven yellow cards were brandished by Styles, and Di Canio was fortunate to stay on after typically volcanic dissent near the end which continued long after he had been booked. At half-time he had to be dragged away from the referee.

Initially the Italian mesmerised with his skills as West Ham swarmed forward, forcing Tim Flowers into several excellent saves. But when Stimac saw red the tide turned. West Ham sacrificed Davor Suker and lost their momentum, Frédéric Kanoute to a hamstring injury and ultimately the match. Eadie's first goal for Leicester was smartly taken, his shot beating Rio Ferdinand on the line after a Gerry Taggart flick-on. West Ham poured forward in search of their first point but a Stuart Pearce free-kick cannoned off the bar.

fields.headline: Roussel ends Coventry's famine
fields.trailText:
Southampton 1 - 2 Coventry
Coventry managed at the first time of asking this term what they had failed to do all of last season.
fields.body:
Hillsborough, April 3 1999. That was the last time Gordon Strachan's Coventry won a Premiership game away from home. Until last night, at the first time of asking in this new season. After 23 brooding journeys, laughter was finally heard on the team coach home.

"I had mixed feelings on the final whistle," said Strachan. "I was happy at the win but then you think what have we been doing for a year. At least it takes the embarrassment away."

Misplaced passes and slipshod defending gave Coventry early reassurance, and they took full advantage on 20 minutes when Tahar El Khalej came across to make a tackle on Craig Bellamy which looked innocuous but resulted in the referee Paul Taylor pointing to the spot. Bellamy duly fired home his first goal since joining for £5m last week. Southampton's problems were compounded by the loss of Kevin Davies with a cracked toe after only 17 minutes. And at half-time Chris Marsden was replaced by Jo Tessem as Glenn Hoddle sought to inject some life into his flagging team.

It worked a treat: seven minutes after the restart the Norwegian dispossessed Paul Williams and made a weaving 20-yard run which ended with a curling shot into the top corner, a rare moment of class in an uninspiring game.

Coventry lived on their nerves as Southampton pressed forward but the home side undermined their comeback with further sloppy defending. On 62 minutes Paul Telfer swung in a corner, Paul Jones missed his punch and Cédric Roussel's header restored City's lead.

The other point of note was referee Taylor's Premiership debut. The official at the centre of the Arsène Wenger allegations not only awarded a dubious penalty but managed to hand out eight yellow cards.

fields.headline: 143 feared dead in Airbus crash
fields.trailText: A Gulf Air Airbus A320 flying from Cairo to Bahrain with up to 143 people on board, including two Britons,  crashed into the sea last night.   Rescuers managed to reach the wreckage of the plane, lying in shallow waters just four miles off Bahrain,  within hours but there were no reports of survivors.
fields.body:
A Gulf Air Airbus A320 flying from Cairo to Bahrain with up to 143 people on board, including two Britons, crashed into the sea last night. Rescuers managed to reach the wreckage of the plane, lying in shallow waters just four miles off Bahrain, within hours but there were no reports of survivors.

A Bahraini civil defence commander told state television that more than 70 bodies had been retrieved within the first few hours of the rescue effort. Airline officials said late last night that 110 bodies had been retrieved. Most of the dead are thought to be children. Divers will search for the flight's voice cockpit and data recorders at first light.

The aircraft, which Gulf Air said was carrying 135 passengers and eight crew, crashed north of the airport at about 5.30pm BST. Most of the passengers were Arab nationals - including 63 Egyptians, 34 Bahrainis, 12 Saudi Arabians, nine Palestinians, six United Arab Emirates nationals, a Kuwaiti and an Omani. There were also two Britons, an Australian, a Canadian, three Chinese people, one Sudanese national and a Korean. There were also unconfirmed reports that one of the passengers was a US diplomatic courier.

It is not yet known why flight GF072 crashed but an air traffic controller at Bahrain airport described watching from the tower as the plane circled the runway twice in an attempt to land, then on the third attempt plunged into the sea and exploded into flames. The controller, who asked to remain anonymous, saw no sign of trouble before the crash and said the plane's crew had not reported anything out of the ordinary.

US navy helicopters based in Bahrain, the home of the US fifth fleet, joined the rescue operation last night, according to a Pentagon spokesman, Bryan Whitman. The Catawba, a US navy support ship with a dive team, is also being dispatched to the scene. About 100 US military personnel were sent to help from the USS George Washington - which usually patrols the Gulf but was in port - at the request of the Bahraini government, said Lieutenant John Perkins, a navy spokesman.

A Foreign Office spokesman could not confirm last night whether Britons were on board. Gulf Air urged worried relatives to call the information line on 0845 604 0171. Bahrain's ruler, Sheikh Hamad bin Isa al-Khalifa, said last night that he had ordered an investigation into the crash. He also announced a three-day mourning period for the crash victims. Paul Beaver, a Jane's defence specialist, said: "Gulf Air has been going for 40 years and has an excellent safety record. There have been a few bumps and scratches but nothing as catastrophic as losing a plane."

fields.headline: Channel 4 TV crew refused bail
fields.trailText: Four members of a Channel 4 television crew held on spying charges in the West African state of Liberia were yesterday denied bail by a judge in the capital, Monrovia.
fields.body:
Four members of a Channel 4 television crew held on spying charges in the West African state of Liberia were yesterday denied bail by a judge in the capital, Monrovia.

Judge Timothy Swope's ruling in the criminal court came as defence lawyers claimed the men - two Britons, a Sierra Leonean and a South African - had been threatened with torture and abused after being held overnight in the national security agency's compound.

Britons David Barrie and Zimbabwean-born Timothy Lambon, South African Gugulakhe Radebe and Sierra Leonean Sorious Samura were later seen by a US embassy doctor and reported to be in a satisfactory condition.

"Espionage is a first degree felony. It is not bailable," the judge said.

Liberia has accused them of filming in areas where they were not permitted to work, and of trying to damage Liberia's image and falsely link President Taylor to diamond smuggling and gun running.

webTitle: Another Protestant man slain, but Britain says cease-fire holds

fields.headline: Another Protestant man slain, but Britain says cease-fire holds
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: An unidentified gunman shot to death a Protestant man at a house on Summer Street in a Loyalist area of north Belfast late last night, in what appeared to be the latest blow in a vicious feud between rival pro-British gangs.
fields.body:
An unidentified gunman shot to death a Protestant man at a house on Summer Street in a Loyalist area of north Belfast late last night, in what appeared to be the latest blow in a vicious feud between rival pro-British gangs.

Although no group claimed immediate responsibility, the fatal shooting happened only a few hundred yards from the spot where the outlawed Ulster Volunteer Force shot dead two Protestant militants on Monday, among them a prominent member of the rival Ulster Defense Association. The UDA had vowed to retaliate by killing UVF supporters in the area.

Despite the rising violence, Northern Ireland minister Peter Mandelson, insisted that a joint UDA-UVF cease-fire remained intact. Speaking before the latest shooting, Mandelson said he had no doubt that most commanders of the UDA and UVF did not want their feud to degenerate into a total breakdown of their 1994 truce, a pillar of Northern Ireland's shaky peace accord.

"It is possible for an organization to be on cease-fire but for individuals associated with it to be involved in unlawful activity," he said.

Mandelson also defended his decision on Tuesday to order the immediate arrest and reimprisonment of the most notorious militant, Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair, who was seized at police gunpoint and delivered by helicopter back to prison. The brawny UDA commander was paroled early from prison last year under terms of the 1998 peace accord, but he had been accused of stoking up an increasingly violent turf war with UVF members, particularly in his Shankill Road power base.

Adair led a raucous UDA parade up the Shankill Road last weekend, inspiring gun attacks on a UVF-linked pub and several leading UVF members' homes. The UVF retaliated on Monday by fatally shooting two men, one of them an Adair subordinate, as they sat in a parked car on the nearby Crumlin Road.

Britain deployed police and troops into the Shankill district to deter an expected UDA counterstrike. Last night's shooting on a residential street just off the Crumlin Road happened not far from a joint police-army checkpoint. No arrests were reported in response.

Meanwhile, a Protestant man being questioned about involvement in Monday's lethal shootings was freed late Wednesday without charge. Detectives continued to question five others arrested on Monday during police raids on houses that contained eight guns and ammunition. Two were scheduled to appear in court today to face charges of illegal arms possession.

Had Mandelson ruled that the joint UDA-UVF truce had broken down, he could have ordered more than 150 convicted members of both groups to be returned to prison to continue serving their suspended sentences. Instead, he focused criticism on Adair, calling him the leading member of a small group of "gangsters and thugs who operate on the black side of Northern Ireland society."

He said Adair had been "given a chance to go straight," but had instead "whipped up the feud." The viability of the Good Friday peace accord depends in part on the maintainance of cease-fires by the Irish Republican Army, which draws support from the most militant Catholic areas, and Protestant-based gangs such as the UDA and UVF. Before calling their joint cease-fire, those two Protestant groups were responsible for slaying more than 800 Catholic civilians.

The cease-fire period has seen rivalry rise between the two groups, particularly once Adair returned home to the Shankill last year. Adair, 36, was convicted in 1994 of "directing terrorism," a previously unheard-of charge, after being taped by undercover police officers bragging about his pivotal role in terrorizing Belfast Catholics. He served just five years of his 16-year sentence.

Adair's close friend in the UDA-linked Ulster Democratic Party, John White, said Wednesday that lawyers had been hired to challenge Mandelson's reimprisonment order on grounds of lack of evidence.

Adair's wife, Gina, insisted her husband was being unfairly singled out. "There's loads of people out there inciting violence. Why just John?" she said. "Because of who he is."

But Mandelson said he didn't expect Adair to get back out any time soon. He said senior police and army commanders agreed Adair "poses too great a threat to public safety to be allowed to roam around and spread the sort of mayhem and terror that we have seen in recent days and weeks."

fields.headline: Whose line is it anyway?
fields.standfirst:
Festival reviews are being distorted to promote ailing shows. Critic Dave Simpson reports

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Festival reviews are being distorted to promote ailing shows. Critic Dave Simpson reports.
fields.body:
Walking around Edinburgh during the festival is like being haunted by every piece of junk mail you ever received. Everywhere there are posters and flyers trying to get you into their shows - and this year seems worse than ever. But more importantly, are these quote-splattered promotional come- ons - "Brilliant! (The Scotsman)", "Hilarious! (The Guardian)" - exactly what they seem?

One of the more prominent PR campaigns at this year's Edinburgh festival promotes Lee Mack. You can't avoid Mack's posters - they're bright yellow and feature a picture of the grimacing comic. Mack's show New Bits is the follow-up to 1999's Bits, which was described as "wickedly funny" in the Guardian. Remember that? No, neither do I, and I reviewed the show. Looking back at my original review, I read: "Mainstream comedy can be wickedly funny." Followed by: "And, in this guise, so can Mack." Not exactly a wholehearted recommendation, but there was more: "By compromising, Mack has nobbled what he's good at." Then: "This is far too hit-and-miss... Mack has blown his cool." It hardly amounts to "wickedly funny".

"The audience fell about and cheered," the Guardian supposedly said about black comic Valentine Flyguy. Did we really? No. We actually said: "Flyguy made jokes about black Americans. The audience - young, drunk and all white - whistled and fell about." Hmm.Worse still, some of the quotes are well past their sell-by date. "Such a nice boy" might still apply to comic Chris Addison, but surely even the most ardent publicist should ditch an old quote comparing the currently below-form Stewart Lee to "a great, like Bill Hicks". Still, at least Lee's people have the nous to include a critical comment - Mark E Smith's: "If I end up like Stewart Lee, cut my head off." Indeed, some acts use their negative reviews as selling points. No harm in that.

More disturbing is the fact that many "review" quotes (especially, incidentally, those in the official fringe guide) are taken from previews - the blurbs journalists write before the shows have even opened, relying on the PR companies for advance information. Thus, what is described as " apparently the best thing since Elvis" has subsequently become "The best thing since Elvis!" Thus the unfunny fringe "comedy" Papa Was a Bus Conductor came to be described in the Guardian as "awesome_ hard-hitting" despite the fact that it was never actually reviewed in this newspaper.

Another spin is to attach a recommendation from another comic - who may well be a) a friend or b) a member of the same management company. Thus many shows on this year's fringe are described as "Fantastic!" by Harry Enfield.

But journalists are fighting back. Some are insisting that the offending passages are removed... but only after bums have been successfully put on seats. Others have attempted to construct pieces without a single positive, quotable word. One irate hack was even said to have pounded the Edinburgh streets at night, tearing down "his" quotes.

We should all be on the lookout for misleading PR guff. And lest there be any lingering doubt, I cite the Guardian theatre critic who said a play at the fringe in 1999 "could be wonderful... unfortunately it isn't". Within hours, the review was seized upon by a delighted publicist. The quote? Yes, you guessed it: "Wonderful (The Guardian)."

webTitle: Analysis: The North needs regional assemblies not just money

fields.headline: Beyond the divide
fields.standfirst:
This week's trio of economic reports add weight to the argument that what the north needs is not just more money, but more power
Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: This week's trio of economic reports add weight to the argument that what the north needs is not just more money, but more power.
fields.body:
The north-south divide is back in the headlines this week, with the publication of three separate reports, but as usual it comes with another division: that between truth and myth. The truth is that England's northern regions generally underperform economically compared with their southern neighbours. The myth is that this is new and that it portends doom; at worst an egg-timer island with everyone trickling south.

Each of the reports is actually a welcome and subtle mixture. Monday's Oxford Economic Forecasting survey left no doubt about the divide, but showed progress rather than reversal in the weakest regions. A growth rate of 2.7% is something to be thankful for in the north-east, particularly when combined with a greater recent reduction in unemployment than in much of the south. You can look at the south-east growth rate of 3.7% and say "Oh dear". But you can also look at the target of One North East, the regional development association, of average 3% growth over the next 10 years and conclude: "We're getting there."

Likewise yesterday's long-awaited list of the government's new indices of local deprivation, the national ward-by-ward survey of poverty and wealth, proved the overall north-south division, but also had bundles of examples of Tony Blair's belief in intra-regional contrasts. Sheffield has four of the country's poorest wards but two of the wealthiest. The same applies to Manchester and Leeds, and down south to Bristol and, of course, London.

The third set of mixed statistics comes out today. These are the most interesting because they emphasise the huge and perhaps uncontrollable effect of the capital on the national economy. The Joseph Rowntree Foundation took a closer look at the basic fall in population in the north and increase in the south. It asked, particularly in the booming, house-building south-east, where everyone was coming from and going to.

The key factor turns out not to be a southerly drain across the Trent and the Severn, but a bursting out of people from London, in search presumably of greener suburbs and fresher air. They account for a remarkable 50% of population growth in the south between 1991-98, while incoming northerners (together with "immigrants" from the Midlands, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland) make up only 8%.

Parallel to this, Rowntree's data-crunchers found a similar but predictably smaller process at work in the north. The northern regions are full of a healthy, upwardly mobile migration from inner - or inner-ish - cities to dormi-toryvilles. The inner-ish distinction is important because in the most thriving regional centres like Leeds and Manchester, as in London, the wealthy are paying unheard-of sums for canalside apartments or urban lofts.

This is evident in even the darkest places statistically: the Blyth Valley constituency of Ronnie Campbell, the chair of the northern group of Labour MPs and an eloquent voice for regional financial aid, has lots of dinky new houses inhabited by people who are prospering as a result of the relative renaissance of Newcastle upon Tyne. This is all very comforting and explains why philippics about the grim north read like Greek to many of us; but the London phenomenon is more important.

It has always been there, contrary to the romantic belief in a wealthy 19th-century north promoted by Lord Young, Mrs Thatcher's trade and industry lieutenant, who said in 1987 that the north "is where all the great country houses are, because that's where the wealth was. Now some of it is in the south. It's our turn, that's all."

No one can deny the all-too-solid existence of Castle Howard or Cragside, the battleship-builder Lord Armstrong's lair, but their regional economies never matched those of London and the south-east. From 1859-69, the north-east and Yorkshire scored 93 and 82 on a per capita income on which London scored 122; in 1879-80 the figures were 84, 90 and 147; in 1911-12, when every pit, pottery and steelworks was going full tilt, they were 81, 78 and a towering 331 for London.

New Labour's palpitations over what to do about this are not new either. Regional subsidies were invented by Stanley Baldwin's establishment of the Industrial Transference Board in 1928. Given New Labour's tactical need to hold on to its southern gains, the hard-headed prophet will be sceptical about the likelihood of special measures for the "heartlands" up north.

There is, though, a pointer which ties in with Ronnie Campbell's important second demand, in reaction to the Oxford report. The northern regions don't just need money, he said; they need regional assemblies with power. This is old Lib Dem policy and something which is anathema to the Conservatives. Can those two thoughts budge the strong (and very traditional, old Labour) section of the party which still believes in centralised power? Scotland's growth rate of 2.9% is better than the north's, and Wales scored 3.2% in the Oxford survey.

The two countries' parliament and assembly are increasingly coveted in the three English northern regions, and this week's trio of reports add grist to that mill. A virtual monopoly of governance has always been the great back-up of London's economic dominance. Jack Straw in Blackburn and John Cunningham in Cumbria must know that what really infuriates northerners is the sense that their region is where things happen, rather than where decisions are made.

 Martin Wainwright is the Guardian's northern editor.

fields.headline: Arthur Smith's daily dose
fields.standfirst:
News from the fringe

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: News from the fringe
fields.body:
When I first came to the Edinburgh festival, no one had heard of improvised comedy or, as it is now known, "impro". It was hard to believe that you could go on stage and say whatever came into your head and call it entertainment. And yet impro shows generate much more laughter than the average sketch show. The definitive TV impro show is still Whose Line Is it Anyway? - presided over by the brilliantly amateurish Clive Anderson.

There are numerous impro (or possibly "improv" shows in Edinburgh this year, and I have just been sacked from one of them. The core of the Comedy Store Players, London's premier ad-libbers, are doing a show up here and, as a guest, I disgraced myself by being drunk and announcing during a sketch involving schoolgirls that I was a Belgian paedophile. Yes, I apologised. I know it was bad. For a nanosecond, it seemed funny. Alas, for the rest of the session it was humiliating, and I have taken my punishment like a man.

Today, as the sun shone on the Grassmarket, I had lunch with friends and I fell into conversation with Dr Derek and his wife Rosie, who live 42 minutes from Edinburgh. I write this because they will be amazed to see their names in the paper. The Guardian should fire me as well.

This is Arthur Smith's final column.

webTitle: Arms deals and terrorist displays landed Adair back in jail, says RUC

fields.headline: Arms deals and terrorist displays landed Adair back in jail, says RUC
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The loyalist paramilitary leader Johnny Adair was thrown back into jail after the RUC drew up a damning intelligence report that accused him of exchanging weapons with the outlawed Loyalist Volunteer Force and organising terrorist displays in Belfast.
fields.body:
The loyalist paramilitary leader Johnny Adair was thrown back into jail after the RUC drew up a damning intelligence report that accused him of exchanging weapons with the outlawed Loyalist Volunteer Force and organising terrorist displays in Belfast.

As Adair's supporters announced plans for a legal challenge against his imprisonment, details emerged last night of an RUC dossier linking the Ulster Defence Association commander to recent paramilitary violence.

The report, which was used by Peter Mandelson as the basis for jailing Adair on Tuesday night, accused Adair of exchanging weapons with the LVF in Portadown. Adair colluded with the LVF during a high profile visit to the Co Armagh town in July at the height of the Drumcree disturbances.

Adair is also accused in the report, which was released by security sources to BBC Northern Ireland, of orchestrating vigilante patrols on the Shankill road and sectarian violence on the boundaries between Protestant and Catholic communities. He is also accused of running drugs rackets.

Mr Mandelson refused to be drawn on the specific allegations. However, the Northern Ireland secretary said: "He has been pursuing and associating himself very directly with acts of violence. It is unacceptable violence, it is unacceptable incitement of terrorist activity and that is a clear breach of the conditions on which he was released from prison."

Adair, who was released from prison early last year under the Good Friday agreement, was hauled back into jail after three days of loyalist feuding which left two men dead. Over the weekend Adair appeared in the company of UDA gunmen at a Belfast rally and he taunted police up until his arrest.

Adair's supporters said he was confident his legal challenge would succeed. John White, the chairman of the UDA's political wing, said: "Johnny Adair feels he's been made a scapegoat. Johnny Adair lives a charismatic life, verging on flamboyancy, but he has done nothing illegal."

On his first day in Maghaberry jail, outside Belfast, Adair held talks with lawyers to draw up plans to overturn Mr Mandelson's decision, which could keep him in prison until May 2002. That was the date he was due to be released before the Good Friday agreement came into being.

If the Northern Ireland sentences review commission, which oversees the early release of paramilitary prisoners, upholds Mr Mandelson's decision, Adair will be entitled to an oral hearing. If the commission still finds against Adair, he will then be able to apply for judicial review.

Mr Mandelson said he was confident that Adair's appeal would fail. "He hasn't a leg to stand on," the Northern Ireland secretary said.

Mr Mandelson voiced the hope that Adair's arrest would provide loyalist paramilitaries with a chance to end the feud.

"I think the removal of Johnny Adair now opens the way for [loyalists] to consider where this violence is leading and to find ways instead of mediating the differences between them," he said.

However, hardline supporters of Adair were reported to be pressing for more protests on the Shankill Road and for the feud with the UVF to be stepped up. The inner council of the UDA was due to meet in Belfast last night to discuss a response to Adair's arrest. Moderates are believed to be pushing for a breathing space.

One senior source was reported as saying: "There are people who will privately be breathing a sign of relief that he has been lifted. But the complicating factor is the feud. There is a UDA man dead and he has not been avenged."

Police yesterday questioned a man about the murders of Bobby Mahood and Jackie Coulter, who were gunned down by the UVF on Monday. Mr Coulter was linked to the UDA. The man was released without charge.

webTitle: Revealed: plot to kill Lloyd George

fields.headline: Revealed: plot to kill Lloyd George
fields.trailText: A mysterious group of "fanatical Turks" threatened to assassinate the former prime minister David Lloyd George, according to a secret police report released yesterday at the public record office.
fields.body:
A mysterious group of "fanatical Turks" threatened to assassinate the former prime minister David Lloyd George, according to a secret police report released yesterday at the public record office.

The report, dated January 1923, warned that two men had declared "their willingness to act as assassins" at a little-known Conference of Orientals in Munich. They were identifed as "Ali Bey and Haidar".

The initial proposal at the bizarre gathering was even more extreme. Indian representatives were reported to have favoured "violence and the extermination of all Englishmen on one day".

This motion was regarded as a little strong for some of those present, in particular the Egyptians. They pointed to the danger of the plan misfiring "as the English would then have the moral support of the whole world in refusing to evacuate Egypt".

The proposal was finally rejected by a majority, according to the report, based on information from what the special branch described as "Indian sources".

Instead there was "general approval" that "sentence of death" be passed on Lloyd George who "represented unhappiness for the whole of the Orient".

Similar sentences were passed on two others, including one Colonel Maxwell. "Have you any idea who Colonel Maxwell can be?" asked Colonel Carter, a senior special branch officer, to his colleague, Inspector Randall.

The documents released yesterday shed no further light on the matter. However, Carter advised Randall, the prime minister's protection officer: "I think you ought to be most careful to keep an eye open for the Turks or lower-class Greeks who may be wandering about and endeavouring to get too near to Mr Lloyd George".

That was not the only plan to assassinate Lloyd George. An earlier report of a plot to kill the prime minister was sent to special branch by Sir Mansfield Cumming, a monocled retired naval officer who was the first head of MI6.

The letter is signed in green ink, then as now the practice of the Chief, as he is officially called, of MI6.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Reward to net Sarah's killer
fields.body:
Reward to net Sarah's killer

A reward of more than £150,000 is now on offer to catch the killer of schoolgirl Sarah Payne, police said yesterday. Detectives appealed for photographs taken on July 1, the day of her abduction in West Sussex, on the beach where she played with her family.

ITV to fight news schedule ruling

ITV has won permission to appeal against an order by the independent television commission to reschedule its late evening bulletin. A judge will rule next month whether the network must move the 11pm Nightly News to an earlier slot.

GM crop safety margin widened

The company running this autumn's trials of GM rape seed has increased borders surrounding conventional crops to reassure the public over fears of cross-fertilisation. Aventis CropScience said GM crops at the 25 sites would be planted at least 100 metres from commercially grown rape, twice the minimum permitted distance.

UN investigates Briton's death

The United Nations has launched an investigation into the death of a British-born worker who was found dead in a hotel room in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Joseph Comerford, 42, was found dead on Friday in the eastern town of Kisangi.

Online wedding a British first

Britain's first online wedding will be broadcast live over the internet tomorrow. Brent council in north London has installed a webcam in its register office so that absent relatives can watch the ceremony on the net.

Leeds fans held over Nazi chants

Thirteen Leeds United fans were arrested in Munich on Tuesday for allegedly giving the Nazi salute and shouting "Sieg Heil". The fans, who missed their team's Champions League match against Munich 1860, were held under a German law which bans Nazi slogans.

Potter joins arts council

The renowned potter and crafts lecturer Emmanuel Cooper has been appointed to the arts council of England. Mr Cooper, who joins sculptor Antony Gormley and installation artist Anish Kapoor, will hold the post for three years from September.

Albino lobster 'probably eaten'

A rare albino lobster stolen from an aquarium has probably been barbecued and eaten, curators said yesterday. Ariel, the 15-year-old lobster, was found to be missing from Newquay's sealife centre on Monday. A crate which also disappeared was found later next to a fire on the beach.

Record jams caused by rain

Heavy rain earlier this summer caused the worst day of traffic jams for three years. The AA reported more than 2,000 traffic jam incidents on Friday June 9, after a heavy downpour caused havoc on the roads.

webTitle: Conductor creates discord over dig at female musicians

fields.headline: Conductor creates discord over dig at female musicians
fields.trailText: The conductor Leonard Slatkin bowed to take his punishment yesterday after a glib after-dinner remark about the size of musicians' posteriors struck a bum note with female colleagues.
fields.body:
The conductor Leonard Slatkin bowed to take his punishment yesterday after a glib after-dinner remark about the size of musicians' posteriors struck a bum note with female colleagues.

The American, who is due to take the baton of the BBC Symphony Orchestra in October, suggested that for amply endowed female musicians, trouser suits were best avoided.

Female violinists, he felt, should also cover their arms. "You don't want to see too much flapping about," he said. "Then there's the problem of women in trousers. If you're slightly heavy in the rear end department, it does not look too good. Of course, not everyone acknowledges that, which is why we need an across-the-board rule."

Slatkin, who admits to being a stone overweight himself, said his views were not meant to be confined to women. Men like himself, he said, with more expansive waistlines, should avoid cummerbunds at all costs.

Speaking yesterday from his home in Washington DC, Slatkin said the remarks reported in Classic FM magazine had been misconstrued.

"I have no problem with women wearing trousers on stage, it is just that on some people they don't look so good. I am traditionalist only in that I think an orchestra is a unit and there should be a uniform look to reflect that, so the audience is not distracted by any one particular member.

"What people forget is that going to a concert is a visual as well as an aural experience."

Despite his protestations of innocence, Jane Glover, who will conduct the BBC Concert Orchestra at the Proms on Saturday, said a regimented look was not necessary. "Musicians are athletes, not tailors' dummies. They sweat a lot. They work hard. It is terribly important that they should be comfortable."

The brouhaha hides the thornier issue of sexism in the male-dominated world of classical music. Two women musicians, who would not go on the record, said that discrimination was still "alive and kicking" in British orchestras, with male members often jealous of the attention their younger female colleagues get from audiences.

"When they talk about not standing out, it is often a codeword for women. If there is only two or three women among 80 men, you will stand out."

Despite his protestations of innocence, Jane Glover, who will conduct the BBC Concert Orchestra at the Proms on Saturday, said a regimented look was not necessary. "Musicians are athletes, not tailors' dummies. They sweat a lot. They work hard. It is terribly important that they should be comfortable." The brouhaha hides the thornier issue of sexism in the male-dominated world of classical music. Two women musicians, who would not go on the record, said that discrimination was still "alive and kicking" in British orchestras, with male members often jealous of the attention their younger female colleagues get from audiences. "When they talk about not standing out, it is often a codeword for women. If there is only two or three women among 80 men, you will stand out."

webTitle: George Monbiot: Traditional farming methods are the best

fields.headline: Biotech has bamboozled us all
fields.standfirst:
Studies suggest that traditional farming methods are still the best
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Studies suggest that traditional farming methods are still the best.
fields.body:
The advice could scarcely have come from a more surprising source. "If anyone tells you that GM is going to feed the world," Steve Smith, a director of the world's biggest biotechnology company, Novartis, insisted, "tell them that it is not... To feed the world takes political and financial will - it's not about production and distribution."

Mr Smith was voicing a truth which most of his colleagues in biotechnology companies have gone to great lengths to deny. On a planet wallowing in surfeit, people starve because they have neither the land on which to grow food for themselves nor the money with which to buy it. There is no question that, as the population increases, the world will have to grow more, but if this task is left to the rich and powerful - big farmers and big business - then, irrespective of how much is grown, people will become progressively hungrier. Only a redistribution of land and wealth can save the world from mass starvation.

But in one respect Mr Smith is wrong. It is, in part, about production. A series of remarkable experiments has shown that the growing techniques which his company and many others have sought to impose upon the world are, in contradiction to everything we have been brought up to believe, actually less productive than some of the methods developed by traditional farmers over the past 10,000 years.

Last week, Nature magazine reported the results of one of the biggest agricultural experiments ever conducted. A team of Chinese scientists had tested the key principle of modern rice-growing (planting a single, hi-tech variety across hundreds of hectares) against a much older technique (planting several breeds in one field). They found, to the astonishment of the farmers who had been drilled for years in the benefits of "monoculture", that reverting to the old method resulted in spectacular increases in yield. Rice blast - a devastating fungus which normally requires repeated applications of poison to control - decreased by 94%. The farmers planting a mixture of strains were able to stop applying their poisons altogether, while producing 18% more rice per acre than they were growing before.

Another paper, published in Nature two years ago, showed that yields of organic maize are identical to yields of maize grown with fertilisers and pesticides, while soil quality in the organic fields dramatically improves. In trials in Hertfordshire, wheat grown with manure has produced higher yields for the past 150 years than wheat grown with artificial nutrients.

Professor Jules Pretty of Essex University has shown how farmers in India, Kenya, Brazil, Guatemala and Honduras have doubled or tripled their yields by switching to organic or semi-organic techniques. A study in the US reveals that small farms growing a wide range of plants can produce 10 times as much money per acre as big farms growing single crops. Cuba, forced into organic farming by the economic blockade, has now adopted this as policy, having discovered that it improves both the productivity and the quality of its crops.

Hi-tech farming, by contrast, is sowing ever graver problems. This year, food production in Punjab and Haryana, the Indian states long celebrated as the great success stories of modern, intensive cultivation, has all but collapsed. The new crops the farmers there have been encouraged to grow demand far more water and nutrients than the old ones, with the result that, in many places, both the ground water and the soil have been exhausted.

We have, in other words, been deceived. Traditional farming has been stamped out all over the world not because it is less productive than monoculture, but because it is, in some respects, more productive. Organic cultivation has been characterised as an enemy of progress for the simple reason that it cannot be monopolised: it can be adopted by any farmer anywhere, without the help of multinational companies. Though it is more productive to grow several species or several varieties of crops in one field, the biotech companies must reduce diversity in order to make money, leaving farmers with no choice but to purchase their most profitable seeds. This is why they have spent the last 10 years buying up seed breeding institutes and lobbying governments to do what ours has done: banning the sale of any seed which has not been officially - and expensively - registered and approved.

All this requires an unrelenting propaganda war against the tried and tested techniques of traditional farming, as the big companies and their scientists dismiss them as unproductive, unsophisticated and unsafe. The truth, so effectively suppressed that it is now almost impossible to believe, is that organic farming is the key to feeding the world.

fields.headline: Perrier snub for prime contender
fields.standfirst:
Controversy clings to judges' decision

Edinburgh Fringe Festival
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: The Perrier award rediscovered its touch for controversy last night by snubbing the comedian who has garnered the best reviews and the most headlines at the Edinburgh Festival.
fields.body:
The Perrier award rediscovered its touch for controversy last night by snubbing the comedian who has garnered the best reviews and the most headlines at the Edinburgh Festival.

Scott Capurro, whose insistence that even the Holocaust can be joked about has sparked a series of walkouts from his shows, was pointedly left off the shortlist of five for the £5,000 prize, traditional ticket to the big time for struggling stand-ups.

The gay American comic leads a procession of holy cows to the slaughter every night in his show at the Pleasance theatre, and his taste for confrontation and for challenging the orthodoxies has on occasion left more sensitive audience members in tears.

With nothing to match the unholy row kicked up last year by the exclusion of Al Murray, and his eventual triumph after a u-turn by the Perrier committee, many critics have been complaining about how bland, safe and TV oriented most of the acts on the Fringe this year are.

A contest between Dave Gorman, Capurro, and Rich Hall's country and western singing ex-con creation, Otis Crenshaw, had been widely predicted.

In the event, Capurro was left out in favour of the talented surrealist Sean Locke, Lee Mack's sketch show, and Garth Marenghi's Fright Knight, a Stephen King spoof. Only Hall has ever been shortlisted before.

But Perrier director Nica Burns insisted there had been no behind the scenes rows.

"There was no plot against Scott Capurro, the judges simply found five shows that were funnier. There was quite a long discussion about Scott before the final five were decided, but the judges' feelings were clear."

She said that for her Garth Marenghi's Fright Knight had been the real find of the festival. "They are what the Perrier is all about, finding fresh, exciting talent.

"No one had heard of them when they came to Edinburgh. They had no organisation behind them and now they are in there with a chance of the Perrier."

They leave, however, having been snapped up by Avalon, the management company who now dominate the comedy scene.

Capurro, a previous Perrier best newcomer, was doing his yoga yesterday when the news came through and did not want to ruin his karma by carping. "I think they are all great choices. Maybe they wanted someone who would be good to promote the product [Perrier], and I guess I wouldn't be their first choice for that," he said.

"Primarily, I think they are looking for someone who will translate to TV, so you get these surprises. Something similar happened a few years ago with Johnny Vegas when everyone thought he would win but he didn't."

Capurro said that for him the biggest shock was that the highly rated Belfast stand-up Colin Murphy did not make the final five.

Nor was there a nomination for the cult football comic, Bob Doolally, who has been persuading hundreds of native Edinburghians to break the habit of a lifetime and actually go to something on the Fringe.

With a few exceptions, such as Ben Keaton and Brown Blues who won in the late 1980s, a Perrier award is a guarantee of much wider fame and all the riches that go with a TV deal.

In Lee Evans's case, it brought him to Hollywood.

fields.headline: Fewer Scots gain university places
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited
Scottish Qualifications Authority
Scottish Executive
Scottish Universities Online
fields.trailText: The number of Scottish school leavers being accepted for places in universities has dropped by 6.6% as the exam results delay continues.
fields.body:
The number of Scottish school leavers being accepted for places in universities has dropped by 6.6% as the exam results delay continues.

Officials at Ucas, the university admissions service, expressed concern at the figures, which contradict assurances by Scottish ministers that pupils will not lose out in the race for a place.

The Ucas chief executive, Tony Higgins, said universities were trying to be flexible with students disadvantaged by the results debacle, and they hoped the numbers accepted would rise in the coming weeks.

Scotland's first minister, Donald Dewar, told parents and students that everything possible was being done to address the situation, which has left thousands of students with incomplete or incorrect certificates.

He said the ultimate responsibility for the crisis lay with him, and he again gave his backing to the education minister, Sam Galbraith.

The Scottish qualifications authority, which is responsible for the marking and distribution of results, has blamed data management problems and claimed that only 5% of students are affected.

But concerns about the standards of marking are growing, with schools across Scotland reporting unusually poor results and markers themselves questioning the validity of the system.

David Cooney, a teacher and exam marker with 24 years experience, said inexperienced markers had been drafted in at the last minute, the number of papers to be marked had increased and the time in which to mark them had been reduced.

"There were a lot of irregularities this year," he said.

At St Columba's school in Kilmacolm, Inverclyde, the rector, Andrew Livingstone, said teachers had been stunned by the grades awarded.

The school had expected 95 grade A passes among fifth year pupils, but the final figure was 60. "We are an accurate school," he said. "The drop is so marked that there must be some reason for this to have occurred."

Mr Galbraith has continued to insist that he will not resign over the issue, despite repeated calls by opposition parties for him to stand down.

The qualifications authority has said that more than 5,000 students received incomplete or erroneous certificates, and 2,000 of them are still waiting to learn their true grades, two weeks after they should have been issued.

Officials said their cases would be dealt with in a matter of days but they have been unable to say exactly when.

fields.headline: TV ad breaks 'over the limit'
fields.trailText: Viewers who complain that commercial breaks are getting longer had their suspicions confirmed yesterday with the publication of a report which claims the gaps between programmes have grown.
fields.body:
Viewers who complain that commercial breaks are getting longer had their suspicions confirmed yesterday with the publication of a report which claims the gaps between programmes have grown.

Research published yesterday by media analysts the Billett Consultancy shows that a combination of advertising, sponsorship, promotions and trailers have been stretching ad breaks on ITV and Sky One to unprecedented lengths.

"The amount of clutter between programmes is getting enormous," said John Billett, the report's author. The study monitored output on commercial channels for two weeks in September 1999, the beginning of the autumn season.

Mr Billett's team measured the complete length of commercial breaks, including the three second freeze frames with which they usually end. He found that when in-house promotions and trailers were added to paid-for ads, ITV and Sky One were often exceeding the peak limits set by the independent television commission.

"The research shows that viewers see self-promotion and paid-for spot ads as the same thing. We also know that the more messages there are in a break the less effective they become. The situation we have now is a raw deal for advertisers, whose message is diluted, and for viewers," said Mr Billett.

Both commercial channels yesterday contested the findings, claiming that had they exceeded the limits consistently, they would have been censured by the ITC.

The ITC declined to comment.

webTitle: Stillborn baby left on rubbish tip

fields.headline: Stillborn baby left on rubbish tip
fields.trailText: Police are trying to find the mother of a stillborn baby boy whose body was found on a council refuse tip by a man dumping garden rubbish.
fields.body:
Police are trying to find the mother of a stillborn baby boy whose body was found on a council refuse tip by a man dumping garden rubbish.

Officers in Leeds are worried about the health of the mother, thought to be a teenager, after finding signs of possible complications in the birth.

The baby's body was discovered wrapped in a towel in a skip normally used for household waste at the drive-in depot on Grangefield industrial estate at Pudsey, near Leeds.

The bundle also included a cot, a baby's blanket and scraps of paper with names scribbled on them.

Detective Chief Superintendent Grahame Bullock, leading the inquiry, said the body showed no sign of injury but it was likely the mother had undergone the delivery on her own. The baby had gone to full term and was white, weighing 7lb.

A postmortem examination at Leeds general infirmary yesterday confirmed he was stillborn.

Det Chief Supt Bullock said the mother should feel safe about coming forward and it was "imperative" for her health that she made contact.

Security camera footage at the depot is being examined by detectives who believe the mother had local knowledge and chose to visit the dump when it was quiet.

The body was found on Tuesday evening by a man who was curious about the bulky towel and unwrapped it to find the child's naked body. Police said he was traumatised and they had offered him counselling.

Police are checking hospitals and ante-natal clinics in an attempt to match the find with a young mother seeking help before the birth.

fields.headline: Flying machine to help police
fields.trailText: Police may one day be swooping on criminals from the air using a strap-on helicopter, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Police may one day be swooping on criminals from the air using a strap-on helicopter, it was revealed yesterday.

The SoloTrek is a personal flying machine that can whizz a person over rooftops and traffic jams at 75mph.

It is powered by two fans enclosed in casings attached to a structure the pilot stands up in. The fans allow the device to take off and land vertically, and can be tilted to provide forward thrust.

Millennium Jet, based in Santa Clara, California, is developing the SoloTrek with technical support from Nasa.

Next month the space agency will put a prototype machine through its paces in a wind tunnel.

The machine, which has a range of 155 miles on one tank of petrol, is initially intended for use by the armed forces, police and rescue workers.

But its inventor, former US navy pilot Mike Moshier, told New Scientist magazine he expected recreational use to develop later.

William Warmbrodt, of Nasa Ames research centre at Moffett Field, California, who is working on the project, said: "It may turn out that the SoloTrek is not feasible, yet it will help us take a step towards a more feasible system."

fields.headline: Shame for kerb crawlers 'working'
fields.trailText: A policy of naming and shaming of kerb crawlers has led to a reduction in the number of people seeking prostitutes in Manchester, according to police.
fields.body:
A policy of naming and shaming of kerb crawlers has led to a reduction in the number of people seeking prostitutes in Manchester, according to police.

Eight men were fined by magistrates this week after they were found guilty of soliciting a woman. Their names and addresses were released by police.

Greater Manchester police launched the campaign - pioneered by police in Cleveland - early last month in an attempt to clear the area around Canal Street of kerb crawlers. Anyone arrested is being named and shamed. It followed complaints from businesses, residents and women who were being harassed by men in cars.

A police spokesman said: "All these names and addresses were a matter of public record anyway. The only difference is we put the men together before the court. The initiative is already working extremely well."

The men taken to court, ranging from a 21-year-old to a middle-aged businessman, were less pleased. One man was near to tears as he told magistrates: "I will lose everything because of this. I have not told my wife, let alone my kids, and I will lose my job. I realise what I did was stupid, but I had no idea my name and details would be there for public consumption."

Inspector Mike Schofield said he had no sympathy for those prosecuted: "Before we introduced the policy, we ran a big press campaign to warn people we were going to be doing it, and a few said they had seen the campaign."

He said police had taken into consideration the Human Rights Act, but they believed that the benefits of naming and shaming outweighed an individual's right to anonymity.

webTitle: Nurse hurt in hospital knife attack

fields.headline: Nurse hurt in hospital knife attack
fields.trailText: Calls for better protection for doctors and nurses intensified last night after a male nurse was robbed and stabbed with his own surgical scissors in a night-time attack in a busy teaching hospital.
fields.body:
Calls for better protection for doctors and nurses intensified last night after a male nurse was robbed and stabbed with his own surgical scissors in a night-time attack in a busy teaching hospital.

Health professionals said the attack at St George's hospital in Tooting, south London, highlighted the dangers hospital staff and GPs face each day and said it was time the NHS "learned the lessons" prompted by a proliferation of assaults.

While there are no figures for the number of attacks against hospital doctors, 40% of GPs and half of all nurses have been assaulted while at work, according to surveys by the British Medical Association and the Royal College of Nursing.

The attack happened on August 8 at around 2am as Paul Trotman, a 28-year-old auxiliary nurse, returned from a break.

As he made his way down a corridor, a woman screamed for help and he rushed to her aid. Her accomplice then hit him over the head and stabbed him five times before snatching his credit cards.

Mr Trotman managed to call for help before being taken to the accident and emergency department, where he was treated and sent home. Police are hunting for the woman and her accomplice.

The government last year launched a campaign against violence towards NHS staff. But yesterday health professionals said not enough was being done to counter such attacks.

Describing the attack as "shocking", Tom Sandford, of the RCN, said: "It is vital that employers take these dangers seriously and look at how safety can be improved."

fields.headline: 'Suspect' in Tokyo case found dead
fields.trailText: The case of the disappearance of the Briton Lucie Blackman took a further turn yesterday after a Japanese magazine claimed that a suspect in the case had been found hanged in his flat surrounded by photographs of the 21-year-old, who has not been seen for almost two months.
fields.body:
The case of the disappearance of the Briton Lucie Blackman took a further turn yesterday after a Japanese magazine claimed that a suspect in the case had been found hanged in his flat surrounded by photographs of the 21-year-old, who has not been seen for almost two months.

The Shukan Hoseki (Weekly Jewel) said police questioned the man, 52, whom it did not name, on August 5 about Ms Blackman's disappearance. Three days later his body was found in a one room rented flat in Kanagawa, south of Tokyo.

Posters of Ms Blackman appealing for information on her whereabouts were found on the walls, according to the magazine.

It said police also discovered stacks of sado-masochistic magazines and videos, many featuring western women, and similarly hardcore images downloaded on the man's computer.

A spokesman at Azabu police station in Tokyo refused to confirm the magazine's claims. The Weekly Jewel has a reputation for sensationalism.

Ms Blackman, a former British Airways flight attendant from Sevenoaks, Kent, disappeared on July 1 from an apartment in the Shibuya ward of Tokyo, which she shared with her friend from childhood Louise Phillips.

Police have made little progress in the investigation, despite the efforts of Ms Blackman's father, Tim, and his daughter Sophie, 19.

On Tuesday Mr Blackman, 47, offered a reward of 1.5m yen (£9,200) for information leading to discovery of his daughter's whereabouts.

webTitle: Crush in south 'due to London exodus'

fields.headline: Crush in south 'due to London exodus'
fields.standfirst: Joseph Rowntree Foundation
fields.trailText: The belief that overcrowding in southern England is caused by migration from the north is scotched today by a fresh analysis of population trends from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, an independent research body.
fields.body:
The belief that overcrowding in southern England is caused by migration from the north is scotched today by a fresh analysis of population trends from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, an independent research body.

It shows that the most powerful motor of population growth in the southern counties is the flight of relatively prosperous families from suburban London.

People moving out of the capital were responsible for 50% of the population growth elsewhere in the south between 1991 and 1998, whereas migration from the north, midlands, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales accounted for only 8%, the researchers said.

Other factors explaining a 623,000 increase in the southern population outside London over the period were a higher than expected birth rate and immigration.

The report said an extra 4.3m households would need accommodation in the UK by 2021. The demand for homes would fall disproportionately on the south-east, where the population was expected to grow by 50,000 a year, putting pressure on greenfield sites.

But a continuing middle class exodus from London would not reduce its population, because it had a high birth rate and it was the main destination for migration from within and beyond the EU.

London's migrant population was expected to increase by 31,000 a year for the foreseeable future and would include extremes of rich and poor. This would put pressure on central London house prices and increase demand for affordable "social" housing for rent.

The report accepted that there had been some population drift from north to south. Net migration from the north and west midlands was about 30,000 people a year during the 1990s, although this was expected to fall.

A more significant trend was a move in all regions from towns and cities to the suburbs and rural areas. This had not been one-way traffic. Typically 500,000 left the cities each year and 400,000 moved in.

"There is a clear life cycle feature, with net movement by people aged 15-19 out of almost all regions and into London," the report said. "However, London is shedding people in all other age groups, and this net outward movement is on a much bigger scale than any other kind of migration."

Those moving out tended to be relatively wealthy families with children, or retiring couples.

Richard Best, the foundation's director and joint editor of the report, said: "The decline of great cities is a national problem demanding action to regain and retain economically active people on the scale urged by Lord Rogers and his urban task force.

"But our analysis shows that attempts to achieve an 'urban renaissance' by blocking migration from north to south would be misconceived. Most movement from cities only takes people as far as the suburbs and surrounding areas.

"There is no escaping the conclusion that population pressures will remain intense in the southern regions, and that London will be unable to meet all its housing needs within its own boundaries."

On the Move: Housing consequences of migration, edited by Richard Bate, Richard Best and Alan Holmanis; Joseph Rowntree Foundation; £13.95

fields.trailText: • New drive Online retailer Amazon.com will introduce a car buying service today, the company said.
fields.body:
 New drive Online retailer Amazon.com will introduce a car buying service today, the company said.

The service - part of ongoing expansion away from Amazon's bookselling business - will be backed by a network of car dealers affiliated with Amazon partner and online car seller Greenlight.com. webTitle: Met refused ex-king's plea to stop smears

fields.headline: Met refused ex-king's plea to stop smears
fields.standfirst: Yard chief unmoved by 'surprisingly accurate' attack on Mrs Simpson
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard secretly refused a demand from ex-king Edward VIII that they investigate the source of anonymous allegations which branded his future wife, Wallis Simpson, as a "scheming adventuress" and "a Delilah and a harlot" who had caused "more grievous harm to the British empire than any other foreigner".
fields.body:
Scotland Yard secretly refused a demand from ex-king Edward VIII that they investigate the source of anonymous allegations which branded his future wife, Wallis Simpson, as a "scheming adventuress" and "a Delilah and a harlot" who had caused "more grievous harm to the British empire than any other foreigner".

Metropolitan police special branch files released yesterday at the public record office show that the most senior Met officers turned down the exceptional request for action from the Duke of Windsor only five months after his abdication on the grounds that the allegations were "rather well done and as far as we know... surprisingly accurate".

The first batch of special branch papers to be released show the anonymous attack claimed that "British citizens had rather King Edward married a respectable shop girl whom he could have enobled" than a woman "having divorced two husbands in 18 years" and "before she was free was planning to get a third husband".

Even more damagingly, the article, which was circulated in May 1937, claimed Mrs Simpson was surrounded by a social set of German-American "social climbers" who had done everything possible to force the king to marry her. It said the cabinet was told there was evidence that she friendly with Nazi agents.

The anonymous author appeared to have inside knowledge of the relationship between Edward and Mrs Simpson, referring to details such as the fact she used to wrap him up in a scarf each morning before he went to play golf.

The abdication crisis of December 1936 was a world-wide scandal, which was kept secret from the public as it unfolded, ended when Edward VIII announced that he was stepping from the throne "to marry the woman I love". The attitude of the rest of the royal family to Mrs Simpson was made plain in a letter which the Queen Mother wrote three years after the crisis in which she described her as "the lowest of the low". The file contains no encouragement from Buckingham Palace to the police to help the Duke of Windsor in any way.

The ex-king, who became the Duke of Windsor, left England for Austria to wait for Mrs Simpson's divorce to come through. The decree absolute came through on May 3, 1937 and he joined her at a chateau in France owned by a pro-Nazi American businessman Charles Bedaux, where they were to marry on June 3, 1937.

The file includes a letter from the ex-king's detective, Chief Inspector Storrier, to the head of special branch dated May 13, 1937, saying that Edward had handed him the document, Public Opinion - the truth about Mrs Simpson, which had been received by Herman Rogers, an American financier and adviser to Mrs Simpson, and asking the police to do something about it.

The attack on Mrs Simpson, written by a "British citizen who has lived on the continent for 10 years", said she had "acted as an enemy rather than a friend of peace by dragging King Edward off his throne at a moment when the nations were trembling on the brink of war". Those who surrounded her, such as Herman Rogers, were German-Americans who posed as the friends of Edward and had chaperoned her on her visit to Balmoral.

"Instead of the king keeping his four months old engagement to open Aberdeen's completed royal infirmary, he went to Aberdeen station to meet his guests. That night was chalked on Aberdeen walls: 'Down with the American Harlot'."

The author alleged that the charms of "this scheming adventuress" were not sufficient to "keep the affection of either husband for any length of time" and that she was a woman who was without, heart, scruples or principles, whose scandalous efforts to gain the title of queen of England jeopardised the very existence of the monarchy.

At Scotland Yard, Sir Norman Kendal, the assistant commissioner in charge of special branch, greeted the allegations with equanimity: "It is rather well done and so far as we know it is suprisingly accurate."

Scotland Yard officers decided that since there was no one else - presumably the palace - pressing them to do anything about the document they would tell Chief Inspector Storrier and by way of him, the ex-king, that it was unable to trace the author and had no knowledge of his identity.

fields.headline: Missile system was damned in 1962
fields.trailText: Anti-ballistic missile systems of the kind now being proposed by the US were dismissed as unworkable by a Ministry of Defence adviser nearly 40 years ago, documents released yesterday at the Public Record Office show.
fields.body:
Anti-ballistic missile systems of the kind now being proposed by the US were dismissed as unworkable by a Ministry of Defence adviser nearly 40 years ago, documents released yesterday at the Public Record Office show.

"It would always be cheaper and more effective for the offence to deal with whatever defence the opposition put up, eg by drenching the defence by decoys," warned Sir Solly (later Lord) Zuckerman, chief scientific adviser to the MoD in 1962.

He reported that Sir William Penney, deputy chairman of the Atomic Energy Authority, agreed. Penney said the chances against achieving a successful defence was "probably a thousand to one or a million to one against".

Another government adviser, Sir Robert Cockburn, chief scientist at the Ministry of Aviation, is reported as saying: "In the last resort, the offence would have advantage over the defence through the simple processes of surprise and saturation."

The views echo growing criticism now of US plans to build a multi-billion dollar national missile defence shield.

President Clinton is expected soon to make a decision about whether to go ahead with the project which has been dogged with technical problems.

Russia, China, and most of Washington's allies are strongly opposed to the plan, which, they say, will be deeply destabilising.

In 1962, Zuckerman noted that an anti-ballistic defence system "if achievable, could undoubtedly be critical in disturbing the strategic balance". The Zuckerman documents were drawn up at a time when the US was considering resuming nuclear tests, partly to try out such a system and partly to raise the morale of nuclear scientists - "an issue", Zuckerman noted, "which obviously could not be raised in public".

Documents released yesterday also reveal how another prominent government adviser questioned the purpose of Britain's nuclear deterrent. "The United Kingdom can be effectively eliminated as a viable country by a mere 10 [Russian] nuclear bombs", warned Lord Victor Rothschild.

Ten bombs dropped on 10 large towns would kill 13.6 m people, up to 70% of their combined population, he said.

Since it could not distinguish between a US or a British nuclear missile, he added, Russia might respond to a US attack by attacking Britain.

"Whatever the US may say or believe about the acceptability of megadeaths in the US", he said, "the effective elimination of the UK by a small number of H-bombs must raise very serious doubts about the desirability of our having Polaris missiles at all."

Rothschild, then chairman of research for the Shell oil company, and with strong links to the Whitehall establishment, made his comments in a minority report in 1968 on the future of the atomic weapons research establishment at Aldermaston, Berkshire.

The future of Aldermaston depended on "a political decision about the strategic advantage, whether real or imaginary, of our having atomic weapons at all", he wrote.

fields.headline: Chocolate helps stop tooth decay
fields.trailText: Japanese researchers have good news for chocoholics. Not only can a bar of the stuff damp down cholesterol levels and raise the spirits, it can also help prevent tooth decay.
fields.body:
Japanese researchers have good news for chocoholics. Not only can a bar of the stuff damp down cholesterol levels and raise the spirits, it can also help prevent tooth decay.

The researchers report in the Archives of Oral Biology that parts of the cocoa bean - chocolate's main ingredient - can thwart mouth bacteria. Streptococcus mutans bacteria make a sticky molecule, glucan.

They use this to anchor themselves to teeth and form plaque. With help from other bacteria, they convert sugars to acids which eat away the tooth's surface.

Chocolate is not as bad for teeth as many other sweets, perhaps because antibacterial agents in cocoa beans offset the sugar in chocolate.

Takashi Ooshima and colleagues at Osaka University found the husk of the cocoa bean produces even more of these antibacterial agents.

New Scientist magazine today reports that she and colleagues added husk extract to bacteria and stopped glucan production. The group plans to test it on human teeth.
