webTitle: 200 Muslim rebels holed up outside Uzbek capital

fields.headline: 200 Muslim rebels holed up outside Uzbek capital
fields.trailText: Muslim rebels fighting to create a hardline Islamic state in central Asia were yesterday closing in on the Uzbek capital, Tashkent, after battling their way across three countries.
fields.body:
Muslim rebels fighting to create a hardline Islamic state in central Asia were yesterday closing in on the Uzbek capital, Tashkent, after battling their way across three countries.

Up to 200 gunmen, who crossed into the country at the weekend, fought their way to within 60 miles of the capital, killing several Uzbek soldiers.

Last night they were hiding in Bostanlyk, a holiday resort north-east of Tashkent. Health spas in the town have been emptied of holidaymakers and the roads to the capital are under heavy guard.

Government artillery and troops were being moved into the resort.

"The area has been surrounded, but we have so far failed to locate the gunmen," an Uzbek government source said yesterday.

The rebels are believed to be members of the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan, which opposes the secular government of the Uzbek president, Islam Karimov, and wants to create an Islamic state in the rugged mountains of Central Asia.

They are thought to have crossed from their bases in Tajikistan through mountain passes into Kyrgyzstan, where they fought fierce battles with government troops in the past fortnight, leaving at least 18 soldiers and 40 rebels dead.

Last week the Kyrgyz president, Askar Akayev, said 50 gunmen were engaged in heavy fighting with government troops after entering the country from Tajikistan, where he said more fighters were massing.

"Another group of over 150 is right by the border," he said. "We know that around 800 well-armed bandits are operating from the Tajik border region."

Leaders of the central Asian states accuse Afghanistan's fundamentalist Islamic Taliban regime of training the men, who include well-armed snipers, among them Arabs, Pakistanis, Chechens, Russians, Ukrainians, Kyrgyz, Uzbeks and Tajiks.

The Taliban, who have imposed a brutally strict interpretation of Islamic law across most of Afghanistan, says they only give the rebels moral support.

Russia keeps several thousand troops in a border security force along the Tajik-Afghan border to counter what it sees as a threat from terrorism and religious extremism, spreading north into the former Soviet states of central Asia.

Russian border guards killed six gunmen who were trying to cross from Afghanistan late on Tuesday. Many of those crossing are smuggling drugs. Last week, Russian guards shot dead 10 smugglers on the border and recovered 118kgs of heroin.

webTitle: Putin tries to woo families with honesty

fields.headline: Putin tries to woo families with honesty
fields.standfirst:
President pulls out of public ceremony as Kursk tragedy reveals growing strength of public opinion

Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: The relatives of the dead crewmen of the Kursk yesterday forced President Vladimir Putin to abandon what was to have been the centrepiece of the bereavement rites as Russia marked a day of official mourning for the 118 lost submariners.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor in Murmansk and Jonathan Steele in Moscow
fields.body:
The relatives of the dead crewmen of the Kursk yesterday forced President Vladimir Putin to abandon what was to have been the centrepiece of the bereavement rites as Russia marked a day of official mourning for the 118 lost submariners.

While flags were flown at half-mast on all government buildings, special services of commemoration held in churches throughout the country, and light entertainment cancelled, Mr Putin returned to Moscow from the Arctic circle abruptly early yesterday, calling off plans to go out to the site of the disaster in the Barents Sea to cast funeral wreaths on to the water.

The sudden cancellation of the ceremony followed several hours of tense, deeply emotional, and at times hostile discussions between the president and the grieving families at the Kursk's base of Vidyayevo outside Murmansk.

The abandoning of the Barents Sea ritual was unique for Russia. It marked the first time that analysts could recall a Kremlin chief cancelling an official ceremony under public pressure, highlighting the scale of the popular outrage gripping Russia at the loss of the seamen and also the increasing role public opinion is playing in Russian politics.

Hundreds of relatives crowded into the Vidyayevo naval officers' hall for Mr Putin's belated first appearance in the far north 10 days after the submarine sank in still unexplained circumstances.

He listened intently to the bitter complaints of the navy widows. For the first time in a crisis that has dealt a severe blow to his authority the president emerged with his reputation relatively intact, according to some of those present.

But despite the widespread public disgust with the navy commanders, a senior admiral yesterday sounded unrepentant at the conduct of his peers throughout the Kursk tragedy.

Admiral Vladimir Yegorov, the chief of Russia's Baltic fleet, insisted there had been no failure to supply information, that the navy was in sound financial shape, and that its rescue personnel and equipment were second to none.

By contrast, the defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, the navy chief, Vladimir Kuroyedov, and the commander of the Northern Fleet, Vyacheslav Popov, have all offered to resign, but Mr Putin refused to accept their resignations.

Mr Putin was supposed to lead the national mourning yesterday by going out to sea with the relatives to cast flowers at the scene of the tragedy, but many of the wives refuse to accept that their husbands are dead and feared that such a ceremony at sea would absolve the government of responsibility to bring out the corpses.

"The grief is immeasurable, there are not enough words of comfort. My heart hurts, but yours hurt even more," Mr Putin told the families. They were promised compensation payments amounting to 10 years' salary.

On one of the rare occasions when the authorities have been frank and direct with the families, Mr Putin told them it would take months to raise the stricken submarine and bring out the bodies, even if it was possible.

In a letter leaked to the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda and which they gave the president's entourage, more than 20 widows and mothers called for the defence minister and the three top navy officers to be put on trial.

In a further sign of their mistrust of officialdom the widows demanded that the search for the bodies in the sunken vessel be carried out in the presence of independent witnesses.

Mr Putin's trip to Vidyayevo marked his first serious attempt to claw back some moral high ground after his catastrophic decision to stay on holiday at the other end of Russia for the first week of the drama.

The scale of his miscalculation emerged clearly from a poll published yesterday in the largest circulation paper, Trud. It found that 28% of those surveyed thought worse of him now than before the tragedy. Based on a sample of 500 Muscovites, it also found that 22.5% blamed him for the sailors' deaths.

Another 35% put the blame on the naval high command.

The All-Russian Public Opinion Centre, which polled 1,574 people across Russia in its regular monthly survey, announced yesterday that confidence in the president had fallen by 8%.

Emerging from a special memorial mass in Moscow's cathedral of Christ the Saviour, Yevgeni Levlampiyev, a 20-year-old history student, said he had not voted for Mr Putin because he had no confidence in the president's commitment to free speech and democracy.

"But he got to power by exploiting the very strong nostalgia people have for the past, their national sense of humiliation, and the Chechen issue. I never thought he would betray the armed forces."

"His mistake will cost him dearly," said Natasha Lemyagova, his 16-year-old companion. "He should have gone to Murmansk on the first day."

fields.headline: Vauxhall benefits from sterling's strength
fields.trailText: Vauxhall yesterday became the first British-based car manufacturer to bless the strength of the pound when it became clear the exchange rate will avoid it having to pay 10,000 workers a bonus this year.
fields.body:
Vauxhall yesterday became the first British-based car manufacturer to bless the strength of the pound when it became clear the exchange rate will avoid it having to pay 10,000 workers a bonus this year.

Unions had agreed in a three-year wage deal signed in 1998 to a 3.3% increase with a special top-up above the level of inflation if the pound fell below DM2.70 (83p) for two consecutive months. With sterling continuing to soar above that level salaried and hourly workers at Luton and Ellesmere Port working on Vauxhall Vectra cars and Astra vans will not each receive a £100 bonus.

Management and unions defended the original deal and said the workforce accepted the pay formula was tough but fair. "The workers are not up in arms about this", insisted a spokesman for the TGWU, one of the negotiating unions.

Nick Riley, chairman and managing director of Vauxhall Motors said senior management were not included in the wage deal had already made their sacrifice. "The whole executive group had a pay freeze and in fact the directors of the company took a 5% cut in the first year so they made their contribution quite a long time ago.

"Although half a per cent is significant and it is £100 to an employee, our manufacturing costs have been hit a lot harder than that because of the strength of the pound. So it is a sharing of the pain."

There is still a chance that the workers could still get their extra 0.5% if there is a serious weakening of sterling over the coming months but trends suggest this is unlikely.

Mr Riley said tying wages to the pound might be part of future wages deals. "If we are going to keep competitive and keep jobs in this country we have to recognise it, so it may be an appropriate element of a wage deal going forward."

Vauxhall produced 315,205 cars and vans last year and exported 60% of them. Like Nissan and other firms producing in Britain, the high pound has dented their ability to sell abroad.

webTitle: Enterprise Asia board tries to discredit predator

fields.headline: Enterprise Asia board tries to discredit predator
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: The battle for control of internet incubator Enterprise Asia turned nasty yesterday when the directors of the company circulated a note to shareholders which painted a damning picture of their predator's track record.
fields.body:
The battle for control of internet incubator Enterprise Asia turned nasty yesterday when the directors of the company circulated a note to shareholders which painted a damning picture of their predator's track record.

Construction entrepreneur Stephen Dean, a 21% shareholder in Enterprise through his building firm Artisan, is demanding a shake-up at the company and wants to join the board. However, he is described in the report by Enterprise as having "a history of disregard for independent shareholders' rights".

Enterprise said allegations that it had used private investigators to compile the report were "rubbish" but admitted it had hired a business analyst to trawl over Mr Dean's career.

Mr Dean was refusing to comment last night. However a spokesman said that he will be issuing a statement shortly. He believes Enterprise should use its cash pile to invest in established UK net ventures rather than firms in the Far East.

Enterprise's directors allege that Mr Dean has been a director of a company that bore his name and went into receivership, and that Mr Dean was "obliged in June 1997 to admit to a number of breaches of law" while a director of Dean Corporation. They document other instances where they allege he did not have the interest of independent shareholders at heart.

An extraordinary general meeting will be held on September 20 when shareholders will be asked to vote against Mr Dean's proposal to oust two members of the board and replace them with three representatives (including himself) from Artisan. A statement from the board yesterday said: "The effect of these resolutions would be to give control of your company to a minority shareholder, Artisan, which is not prepared to make any offer for your shares."

Earlier in the year Mr Dean had suggested to the board of Enterprise Asia that it merge with VoyagerIT.com, a company of which he is chairman and a shareholder. The board rejected the plan as unnecessary to the company's future but invited him to put "serious" business suggestions.

Phill Brown, a director of Enterprise Asia, said last night: "The only conclusion we can draw from Mr Dean's refusal to take up any of our offers to demonstrate a genuine interest in the strategic direction of the company is that he wants to grab the cash and run."

fields.headline: Trade gap hits record
fields.standfirst: Britain's exports to EU improve despite yawning global deficit
fields.trailText: Britain's trading gap with countries outside the European Union widened last month to its highest recorded level, official figures showed yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's trading gap with countries outside the European Union widened last month to its highest recorded level, official figures showed yesterday.

Imports from non-EU countries outstripped British exports by £2.8bn in July, according to the Office for National Statistics. The non-EU deficit over the last quarter stands at £6.2bn, also a record.

While the trade gap with countries outside the European Union is deteriorating, ONS data for European trade suggests that performance with EU countries has been surprisingly robust, given the ongoing strength of sterling against the euro. The trade gap with EU countries for June stood at £131m, its narrowest since March 1997.

Analysts said robust growth in the euro area is helping to close the deficit with the EU, while the slowdown in the US appeared to be the force behind the widening trade gap with the rest of the world.

On a volume basis, which strips out price changes, non-EU exports fell by a massive 5.7% in July, as imports continued to rise. With the EU, the position was reversed, with exports rising 5% in June, while imports fell by 1%.

"The main feature of the latest data is the surge in EU export volumes," said Neil Parker, UK economist of Royal Bank of Scotland.

However, he warned that exporters were improving their performance to the EU by cutting prices. Other analysts said that surveys of business order books suggested the position is likely to deteriorate.

"Although the figures show little sign that the strong pound is providing a drag on export growth, weakening export orders suggest that this might not last," said Jonathan Loynes, UK economist with Capital Economics.

The better than expected performance on trade to the EU helped stabilise the whole world goods deficit in June at £2.3bn, the same as the previous month.

However, the more up to date figures for non-EU countries point to there being a record whole world deficit when the July figures are published next month.

Separate ONS data showed that the economy grew by 0.9% in the second quarter of the year, the same figure published in their initial estimate.

More detailed expenditure information, available for the first time showed a pickup in household spending, from 0.6% in the first quarter, to 0.8% in the second, a figure which could alarm members of the Bank of England's key rate setting committee.

"[This is] not particularly good news for interest rates," said Adam Chester, economist at the Halifax bank.

But other analysts said it merely reflected a bounceback after the first quarter's millennium induced slump.

"Domestic demand in the first half was dramatically slower than in the second half of last year," said Jonathan Loynes at Capital Economics. "The 0.8% increase in household spending was surprisingly weak."

Much of the overall growth in the second quarter was a result of higher demand for energy supply and extraction. The ONS said bad weather and higher oil prices explained much of the strength in these sectors. Without it, overall growth in the second quarter would have been 0.6%.

The GDP deflator - the widest measure of inflation - fell to 1.8%, the lowest for five years, a further encouraging sign for those hoping interest rates have peaked.

The household consumption deflator, a measure of the inflation facing households, fell to its lowest level for 37 years.

fields.headline: At this price?  Sainsbury
fields.trailText: Sainsbury's new boss, Sir Peter Davis, reckons he has enough on his hands turning around the fortunes of the supermarket chain without devoting management time to Homebase, the company's do-it-yourself sideline.
fields.body:
Sainsbury's new boss, Sir Peter Davis, reckons he has enough on his hands turning around the fortunes of the supermarket chain without devoting management time to Homebase, the company's do-it-yourself sideline.

Confirming speculation yesterday, Sir Peter said he was "considering alternatives" for Homebase - either a £1bn sale of the business, an alliance or a joint venture with another DIY specialist.

The prospect of offloading Homebase sent Sainsbury's shares up 16.25p to 350p. The logic is sound - Homebase is very firmly second in the British market, behind Kingfisher's B&Q.

Homebase needs investment either to close the gap or to expand on to the continent. Sainsbury needs to use all of its cash to heal the problems left behind by former boss Dino Adriano, so Homebase is better off under different ownership.

There should be plenty of interest - Sir Peter has already had talks with both trade and venture capital buyers. HomeDepot of the US, continental chain LeRoy Mulin and Britain's Wickes were all mooted as possible bidders yesterday.

After lagging behind the industry throughout 1999, Sainsbury's supermarkets are looking a little healthier, with a 3.7% rise in underlying sales in the first quarter of the year. Sir Peter admits, though, that it will take three years for complete recovery.

The real problems involve Sainsbury's warehouses, delivery systems and computers.

Sainsbury is lagging behind Tesco and Iceland in internet shopping and home delivery. Profit per square metre is about 30% lower than Tesco's. Meanwhile, the results are due soon of the government's inquiry into "rip-off" supermarket prices. High street trading is not getting any easier.

Sir Peter, who joined from the Prudential, is widely respected. But the man from the Pru is no magician - improvement will take time. The shares are unattractive.

webTitle: BT insists mobile customers will pay for its German spending spree

fields.headline: BT insists mobile customers will pay for its German spending spree
fields.trailText: BT went on the attack yesterday, rebutting claims it had paid too much for a third-generation mobile phone licence in Germany by saying it would raise customer tariffs to recoup the cost.
fields.body:
BT went on the attack yesterday, rebutting claims it had paid too much for a third-generation mobile phone licence in Germany by saying it would raise customer tariffs to recoup the cost.

Pat Gallagher, BT's group director of strategy and development, said tariffs would have to be increased. "We are not the welfare state," Mr Gallagher told the German magazine Focus Money.

Analysts, however, said it would be suicide for BT to push through price increases because Germany is likely to become the most competitive European market for mobile phones.

BT shares were hit hard yesterday by worries that credit-rating agency Standard & Poor's will downgrade the telecom company to below single A. Although S&P rushed out a statement denying that, BT shares ended the day 14p lower at 796p.

Last week the German government issued six licences to telephone operators in its auction of mobile spectrum, raising £31.8bn. It is the largest number of third-generation licences yet issued in a European country.

BT also agreed to pay £9.3bn to double its stake in its German subsidiary Viag Interkom to 90%.

Viag Interkom is Germany's third-ranking player with 2m mobile customers and is still upgrading its network for next-generation mobile services.

Stephen Pentland, partner at Spectrum Strategy Consultants, said entrenched competitors such as Vodafone's Mobilfunk and Deutsche Telekom's T-Mobile would make it difficult for BT to adopt a premium price position in Germany.

"In terms of cost and value the German customer has never had it better. It's an enormously risky strategy for BT given they are not the main player," he said.

Mobile operators will be seeking to recoup the cost of their licences through revenues from access, content, e-commerce, advertising and location-based services.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: More bad news for Big Brother's "Nasty Nick". First he lost his chance of winning £70,000 when he was booted out of the house, and now it looks like he's lost a similar amount from the Sun
fields.body:
More bad news for Big Brother's "Nasty Nick". First he lost his chance of winning £70,000 when he was booted out of the house, and now it looks like he's lost a similar amount from the Sun.

Two female journalists from The Mirror tracked Nick to a hotel in Surrey (where the Sun had hidden him after signing him up for £70,000) and got him to unwittingly spill the beans for nothing.

As it happens, Sun executives are grumbling that Nick hasn't been worth the money, as he has had nothing of interest to say... which is not surprising really, since everything has already been on TV.

By yesterday the Sun was scraping the barrel by "revealing" that Bateman was at the same school as Prince Edward... zzzzz.

Noises from Wapping suggest the exclusive hasn't made the Sun fly off the news-stands - so the Mirror's spoiler gives News International a perfect excuse to refuse to pay up, on the grounds that Nick broke his confidentiality agreement when he fell into the Mirror's honey trap.

It really couldn't have happened to a nicer guy.

Cockney rhyming slang has added so much colour to the rich tapestry of the English language. So let's welcome the latest addition to the argot doing the rounds on the streets of London: "I'll meet you by Euan at 8.30." Euan Blair - Leicester Square!

Letters continue to flood in on the subject of the Keswick Pencil Museum. At a rough estimate I'd say that half of the Guardian's readership have visited the museum at some time or another.

One of them was Claire Milhench, who tips another top tourist attraction in the Lake District. "I have strong memories of a rainy afternoon in the Stott Park Bobbin Mill at Newby Bridge," says Claire.

"The presentation was basically a shed with boards explaining how bobbins are made, in mind-numbing detail."

Admission is charged, although dogs get in free.

And yet, as in so many other things, Europe leads the way in museums of this sort. Even the Yelverton Paperweight Centre is put in the shade by Belgium's Musee de l'Eau, "almost bordering Lake Genval" according to the leaflet sent to us by Patrick Kirby. "The museum is also fun for children; a working model with 'real' water brings the whole water cycle to life."

'Real' water, eh? Fancy that.

A judge in the Punjab recently sentenced a man to be hanged twice, for killing his mother and father-in-law. The man's accomplice got off somewhat more lightly - he will only be executed once.

From the letters column of the latest issue of the BBC's in-house magazine, Ariel: "Have any other sad people out there," writes Alan McAllister, "noticed that the first three notes of The Corrs's Breathless sound exactly the same as a Beta SP machine syncing up to 1kHz tone on playback?"

webTitle: Julia Langdon: Conservatives' press secretary is hardly a good advertisement

fields.headline: Amanda Platell said one thing then. And another now
fields.standfirst:
The Conservatives' press secretary is hardly a good advertisement
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Conservatives' press secretary is hardly a good advertisement.
fields.body:
The Conservative party is currently torn by disagreement about the nature and content of its forthcoming election programme. There have been a series of changes in different areas of policy and in the party's approach to winning its way back into public esteem. There are furrowed brows in Conservative Central Office and long faces among the party's MPs. And no wonder. The Tories are in a mess and nothing that they are doing at the moment is likely to improve things.

One reason why this should be has come my way. It is not - alas - another sensational leak. It is not even a particularly impressive document. It is the transcript of part of a Question Time programme on BBC Television and it is the contribution to that programme by Amanda Platell, press secretary to William Hague. It was released by the Labour party to at least one other newspaper some days ago but very little attention was paid to it. I cannot imagine why not - it is extraordinarily revealing, in a number of different ways, about the nature of the political process. And about Ms Platell.

First, an explanation which itself says much about the issues involved. Why was the Labour party in possession of this transcript? Perhaps they had asked the BBC for a copy because some bright spark at the party's headquarters in Millbank remembered that Amanda Platell had appeared on the programme and thought it might be worth finding out what she said in the hope of embarrassing the Tories? Wrong. The Labour party had this material because when Ms Platell was a guest on Question Time she was the Managing Editor of the Mirror Group of Newspapers and, in that responsible position, was briefed for the programme by the appropriate department within the Labour party itself. They made a recording and kept the transcript.

But why did the briefing occur? Why would someone deemed smart enough to be the managing editor of anything - let alone a mass circulation tabloid newspaper - need to be briefed about what she thought about any area of current affairs? It might perhaps have been understandable if she had asked the public affairs department of MGN to furnish her privately with the up-to-date political position on the coal industry, care in the community or proportional representation before the programme. All of these subjects were among those discussed and were clearly in the news at the time. But it says something very bizarre about public affairs and the way current news issues are handled on television that it should be necessary for such a briefing to be offered by the Labour party and, even more, that it should be accepted by a high-profile public figure.

It is known and understood by journalists that in the hermetic conditions of today's clinically controlled politics, most MPs are briefed to the eyeballs. Their bleepers tell them what to think and say about everything. Should they be invited to express their views in public and if, of course, their appearance is approved by their minders at HQ, they will secure a run-down from their own parties on the correct line to take on every subject before daring to tiptoe before a microphone. Anything to avoid the shame and horror of having to risk expressing any kind of individuality or personal political commitment.

Yet it is rather odd to discover that this also extends to executives of the once great Mirror. The obvious implication is that Amanda Platell was expected to express views consistent with those supported by the Labour party, which was then in opposition. There is no date on the transcript but it seems evident from the context that the programme was broadcast some time in early 1993. But whenever it was, it will have been a relief to those involved on the party's side that Ms Platell performed her role to perfection.

She spoke with sympathy about the problems of striking miners, forced to work extra hours for less pay by a (Conservative) government seeking to sell off their industry. She spoke powerfully about the Mirror's support for the leftwing. "As long as we have breath," she said of her newspaper, "it will continue to support the Labour party." She spoke of "fighting against social injustice", for the views of "our readers" who were Labour supporters. Later she boasted of the newspaper's coverage attacking the closure by the (Conservative) government of Westminster Hospital and how they had exposed the "outrageous" expenditure by Peter Lilley, the then (Conservative) secretary of state for social security on his travel to and from his home in France.

She was a bit woolly about PR but said that "you would not have had the poll tax in a million years if there had been any chance - if we'd had proportional representation." And she spoke about being "terribly terribly worried" walking down any street in this country and seeing "people in doorways who obviously should be in hospitals, who should be in institutions and who've been kicked out by this (Conservative) government because they didn't have the funds to keep them in the hospitals."

Now I have no idea whether Amanda Platell believed what she was saying when she said it, but I rather suspect that she cannot possibly have done so. She doesn't express herself particularly well or fluently and there is no indication that she has actually thought through any of the points that she made on the programme, let alone believed them.

What really is astonishing is that we have a political system which makes it possible for someone who was, relatively recently, prepared to go on television and mouth ill-considered thoughts on behalf of one of our major parties, shortly before she was to become the press secretary to the leader of the other. Admittedly William Hague was only joint parliamentary under-secretary at the Department of Social Security in 1993 - the job politicians laugh about as arguably being the least desirable on offer - but he was only two years away from promotion to the cabinet and only four from the leadership.

The metamorphosis of Amanda Platell is a small but depressing episode. One of the truly surprising things about the state of our political parties at present is the lack of serious attention that any of those involved in running affairs seems to pay to the important business of sincerity.

It is difficult to under-estimate how much this matters to the electorate. Time and again opinion polls demonstrate that what chimes best with the public is a politician who is palpably honest and human and who tells the truth. It may not be about something with which everyone will necessarily agree. That doesn't matter at all. It is the sincerity that matters. But people like Amanda Platell treat such matters with careless disdain. Since she is now running press relations at Conservative Central Office, is it any wonder that they are in such a mess?

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Crossing Continents/The Material World
fields.body:
As Julian Pettifer discovers in Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4), millions of Chinese are beginning to discover the drawbacks of affluence. It's not yet a problem on the mainland, but their offshore cousins in Taiwan find more and more of their children suffering from chronic obesity. In part it's their addiction to Western junk food, but the island's incredible population density doesn't help. The lack of open spaces and frightening volume of traffic mean that youngsters get little if any opportunity to exercise.

By contrast, Quentin Cooper and various experts from the Southampton Oceanography Centre spend their afternoon happily gambolling along the beaches of Hayling Island, east of Portsmouth. The scientific excuse for the outing, as they explain in The Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4), is to explore methods of slowing the erosion of the shoreline. They're also investigating why the waves hitting the island are 25 per cent larger than they were just a decade ago.

fields.headline: Live and kicking
fields.standfirst: Tomorrow night, Channel 4 is screening a live drama. It may sound eccentric - but there was a time when all TV plays were shown this way. Is it anything more than a headline-grabbing gimmick? By  Richard Vine
fields.trailText: Tomorrow night, Channel 4 is screening a live drama. It may sound eccentric - but there was a time when all TV plays were shown this way. Is it anything more than a headline-grabbing gimmick?
fields.body:
Live television, as anyone from Noel Edmonds to Chris Evans to Nasty Nick will tell you, is a risky game at the best of times. With the added pressure of lines to remember, cues to miss, and the constraints of just a week in which to put it all together, tomorrow night's episode of ALT-TV, Play In A Week, is packed with drama before the actors even open their mouths.

For the final instalment of the experimental ALT-TV series, writer Nigel Forde has been set the task of writing, casting and directing a half-hour play in a week - the first drama to air live on British television in a long time.

On Monday he scoured the papers for a newsworthy story to base his script on. Tuesday, the cast was booked and thrown into rehearsals. Yesterday a composer was found to write the soundtrack, while Norman Stone, director of the TV version of Shadowlands, prepared to direct the cast and crew through what has the potential, at least, to be one of the more interesting half hours in this summer's TV schedules.

Of course, in the days before edit suites and videotape existed, this was how all TV drama was made, filming what were essentially live theatre productions straight to camera. In the mid-60s, Dennis Potter cut his cathode teeth writing a bold series of live Wednesday Plays like Where The Buffalo Roam or The Confidence Course, packed with British actors like Yootha Joyce and Stanley Baxter. Some of these are lost gems which weren't even taped on transmission as the film stock was considered too expensive to be used for creating a huge library of material - a broadcasting strategy that seems bizarre in our era of endless chances to see stuff we didn't want to watch first time round.

In the States, shows such as 1956's Playhouse 90 gave directors like John Frankenheimer an hour and a half of live television every week in which to adapt works from heavy weights Ernest Hemingway, George Bernard Shaw and William Faulkner, as well as nurturing young writers like The Twilight Zone's Rod Serling. The series is still regarded as one of the highpoints of the golden age of American television, which may explain the small but growing trend towards live TV drama in recent years.

ER was the first to pull off the live show stunt, with the opening episode of the 1997 season featuring a documentary crew shooting the bloodthirsty chaos of Chicago's most famous hospital for a day. The cameramen jumped out of the way of bodies on gurneys, captured a few intimate moments between Carol and Doug, and generally contrived ways to film the high-paced drama in a continuous stream. Because of the five-hour time difference between the east and west coasts, the cast even had to repeat the performance after a two-hour break.

It's an experience that the show's then star George Clooney obviously enjoyed, as he decided to repeat the endeavour in April this year by throwing his Hollywood clout behind a remake of his "favourite film".

Originally broadcast live in 1964, Fail Safe is a cold-war nuclear paranoia thriller about an airforce bomber that has inadvertently been given the order to nuke Russia. Hardly a burning contemporary issue, but given the bonus thrill of live transmission, one that commanded a respectable enough audience. Clooney roped in his ER pal Noah Wyle alongside Richard Dreyfuss, Harvey Keitel, Don Cheadle and James Cromwell, with Stephen Frears directing 18 cameras across two soundstages. Fail Safe was such an extended exercise in repeating the past, they even went so far as to shoot it in black and white and broadcast it with a letterboxed picture.

Both ER and Fail Safe were met with enthusiastic reviews, full of praise for the energy and vitality of the live experience - something of a novelty in today's culture of endless retakes and technical perfection. Both were also pulled off without any glaring mistakes from the cast, something which may have disappointed the rubbernecking section of the audience. It's undeniable that a major part of the thrill of live drama is waiting for someone to fluff their lines, especially in a format like television, where the audience is far enough removed from the cast to be able to revel in, rather than cringe at an actor's amnesia.

This live aesthetic has spread to film, with Lars von Trier's Dogme 95 school of intimate wonky-cam directors offering a hardcore modern interpretation of cinema verité alongside the real-time experimentation of Mike Figgis's current Timecode - itself essentially a play that was filmed live, albeit from four different perspectives.

It's an old idea, and one that used to be the only possibility available to TV directors. But the very fact that a show is being broadcast live still has the power to add an element of risk that's hard to match. And, if tomorrow night's Play In A Week is a success, it's a safe bet that it won't be the last time you see live and direct drama on TV.

ALT-TV: Play In A Week, tomorrow, 7.30pm, Channel 4.

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Gina Newson, film-maker
fields.trailText: Gina Newson, film-maker.
fields.body:
For the last year we've been making a documentary called Movie Virgins, following Leon Herbert and Alex Jovy (pictured) trying to get their first feature films off the ground. Leon's is a no-budget domestic drama, Alex's is a clubland thriller with a £3m budget. We've followed them writing scripts, raising money (or not), casting (or getting turned down), getting nowhere, getting somewhere, then the momentous, almost unbelievable first day on set... the shoots, the escalating costs, the tantrums and the traumas of seeing if what was in the script worked in the cutting room.

Movie Virgins was allocated a prime-time 9pm slot by Channel 4, and we wanted, above all, to make it accessible. In the cutting room we were ourselves trying to weave hours of documentary footage into a four-part story. It was a challenge in the first place to start filming unknowns with incomplete scripts and no budget, just hoping to get them from script to screen. As Leon and Alex were trying to complete their features and meet deadlines, our own transmission date was looming. So where to end the documentary? Their stories were still going on. Then a fax arrived from Channel 4. The Sunday movie was being moved to the earlier 9pm slot, with Movie Virgins to follow. And with a different start time each week, which makes it hard to build an audience. We protested - to no avail.

Still, Movie Virgins had good reviews ("I'm hooked", "compelling as a car crash", "enthralling") and doubled its audience from week one. Strangers approached in the street - to commiserate with Alex about being snubbed by Jude Law in Cannes, and even to offer Leon tenners to help him finish his film. People were saying they'd stay up to watch what happened next instead of videoing. There was a buzz. Then last Friday we summarily received a call from the Channel 4 schedulers. Movie Virgins, we were told, was being ejected from the schedules to make room for a repeat of an update on Nasty Nick's own eviction...

Movie Virgins, Sunday, 10.55pm, C4

fields.headline: The man with no name
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Starstruck/The Lipstick Years/Crimewatch UK: Solved
fields.body:
After seeing Nick Moran on Movie Virgins a couple of weeks back acting like a spoilt Brit-flick brat on a Cannes rooftop terrace with Jude Law, the prospect of watching his nobody-ness in Hollywood seemed unmissable, his just desserts. But, as the excellent Starstruck (C4) continued its exploration of fame and fortune with a programme focusing on the price of celebrity and success, poor Nick's plight made him positively sympathetic.

A koi carp in a swimming pool here, in LA he was a minnow in an ocean, just another British actor reading for bit parts in duff action movies. He may have got a free suit from Prada for the American premiere of Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels, but he was small fry nonetheless. And he knew it. Like All Bran, humbling experiences may not taste great but they are good for you.

With a supporting "cast" including Anjelica Huston, Adrian Lester and Billy Bob Thornton all giving insiders' critiques of the business we call show, Starstruck once again probed the inner workings of celebrity like a master surgeon. While all had interesting points to make - Rufus Sewell's anger at his cooperation with his own humiliation at auditions was particularly memorable - it was to Sienna Guilroy that Starstruck belonged. Nick Moran's girlfriend, she spoke candidly of how awful it is going out with someone everyone wants to know while you slowly turn invisible, three steps behind them.

Incidentally, if that room in which Fay Ripley is interviewed for Starstruck is actually in her house - and not some swanky hotel suite - wouldn't it be great to be her flatmate? With all that space and nice coloured cushions, you could cartwheel from the dining table to the front windows at least three times without fear of smashing any ornaments.

Unlike Lowri Turner's, which - if it is her house from which she presents The Lipstick Years (BBC2) - is jam-packed full of hideous ornaments culled from a jumble sale at Lady Tavistock's country pile.

This week, concentrating on housewives, there were moments of The Lipstick Years which were surely cues for country and western songs. There was Shirley Conran's "No One's Going To Strangle You If The Mantelpiece Is Dusty", Nigella Lawson's "I'm No Scrubber But I Bake A Mean Biscuit", and my personal favourite, "Feed The Baby, Load The Twin-Tub And Pass the Mogadon". (Actually, there is a country song - by Mary Chapin Carpenter - called "He Thinks He'll Keep Here", which would have made a very good theme tune for this episode).

The drum beats to which the righteous march, the synthesised trumpet noises suggesting heroic institutions, the urgent bass line hammering home an evangelical cause: the music for Crimewatch would prompt even Mad Dog McGough and Razors Robinson to phone in and say "Keep up the good work." For fitting its programme like a comfy cardigan, Crimewatch comes second only to Casualty. And, just as Nick Ross saying "Don't have nightmares. Do sleep well" has absolutely no periaptic properties but is still oddly comforting, so the Crimewatch music irrationally stirs one's civic conscience. A call to arms, no less.

These are the dog days of August however (the dogs having eaten the salad days) and there is no crime, so Crimewatch UK: Solved (BBC1) was dedicated to crimes "you, the public" helped solve. The happiest endings you could expect from some thoroughly nasty crimes (child abuse, murder, armed robbery and football hooliganism), it was part self-congratulatory and part public relations exercise for the police. This reconstruction-fest was full of cheeky, charming, non-swearing, non-racist, non-sexist policemen who must listen to the theme tune from Crimewatch on their personal stereos - after a chorus of Zip A Dee Do Dah - on their way to work. Knowing that the public probably wouldn't accept stations full of happy clappy coppers, there were - in a unique concession to reality - a couple of gruff types. They were Scottish, naturally.

Whatever this bunch of officers were investigating, their gravitas was tempered by humour and their determination by concern for their victims. Naturally, one doesn't expect The Cops-esque drug-taking and corruption during Crimewatch, but this was The Bill on Prozac. Join the police - everyone's nice.

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which of these films - if any - will be the biggest US box office success in 2000?
fields.trailText: Which of these films - if any - will be the biggest US box office success in 2000?
fields.body:
Castaway 3-1

Unbreakable 5-1

Traffic 5-1

Moulin Rouge 10-1

Dancer In The Dark 20-1

It's that time of year. The summer season has been puffed full of blockbuster and now it's the turn for real hot air, the season of wannabe Oscar nomination films. Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler Sean Boyce looks at the titles that are likely to make it past the hype and rock the box office.

Tom Hanks and Castaway head the list. "We've been tempted to bet against Tom Hanks before, particularly in our Oscars markets, and it's definitely a case of once bitten twice shy", warns Sean. "This looks a complex and demanding movie, but the combination of Hanks and Zemeckis means that it could strike gold."

With Bruce Willis back on board, young director M Night Shyamalan is after a repeat of the success of The Sixth Sense. "But the track record of young directors' second films is not great", says Sean. "My spies tell me that that young Mr Shyamalan has given free reign to his creativity here, and I fear a self-indulgent flop could be the result."

Steven Soderbergh has been describing Traffic as "The French Connection meets Nashville". It is a political film about the war on drugs in America that is bound to court controversy. "This is a movie that could be the toast of critics and film buffs everywhere. It deals with a tough subject matter, though, and I'm not convinced that the US public have the stomach for a moral debate during their popcorn."

Hanging on in there with an outside chance is the latest by Australian director Baz Luhrmann. "The presence of Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman in Moulin Rouge guarantees at least half a chance of success. But it's hard to see this one troubling the year's real blockbusters in the rankings.

"As for Dancer In The Dark, while few people dislike the elfin Nordic songstress Björk, how many people will like her enough to sit through a Lars von Trier musical? Nuff said."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Jour De Fête/Fallen/The Silence Of The Lambs/Cyrano De Bergerac
fields.body:
Jour De Fête

(Jacques Tati, 1948)

6pm, FilmFour

Tati shot his rumbustious portrait of French rural life in both black and white and colour, but the lab couldn't process the colour film and it lay dormant for decades until being touched up and completed as he had planned Here's that rare version, with lurid colours complementing the riotous story of a village postman who sees a film about the US postal service and decides to clean up his act.

Fallen

(Gregory Hoblit, 1997)

10pm, Sky Premier

Intriguing blend of crime thriller and ghostly chiller, reminiscent of Alan Parker's Angel Heart. Denzel Washington (pictured) is a Philadelphia cop on the trail of a serial killer: in the murk it's hard to see that supernatural elements are at work. Lowering atmospherics and a strong cast keep things interesting when the plot flags.

The Silence Of The Lambs

(Jonathan Demme, 1990)

10pm, Carlton Cinema

Anthony Hopkins is evil personified as serial killer and people- eater Hannibal Lecter, locked in a hi-tech gothic dungeon and called on to help the FBI trace another multiple murderer known as Buffalo Bill. Jodie Foster as fledgling Fed Clarice Starling, fighting to stay with the job and keep her sanity in the face of horrors, is every bit as good, and both actors won Oscars. There were three others too: best film, director, and adapted screenplay. Hollywood knows a meaty, sharp-toothed thriller when it sees one.

Cyrano De Bergerac

(Jean-Paul Rappeneau, 1991)

11.45pm, FilmFour

Surely the role that Gérard Depardieu was born to play: his Cyrano has the heart of a lion, soul of a poet and face of a buffoon. The 17th-century swordsman with the rapier wit adores his beautiful cousin Roxane (Anne Brochet) but, cursed with an unfeasibly large nose, is too shy to declare his love, and instead woos her on behalf of handsome-but-dim comrade-in-arms Vincent Perez. Rappeneau directs on the heroic scale, with huge battles and a fine eye for lush settings and costume.

fields.headline: Medical exercise
fields.trailText: Shares in Medical Solutions, the digital diagnosis and pharmaceuticals firm, rose 1.5p to 37.5p in heavy volume yesterday after its broker, Teather & Greenwood, cleared a line of stock overhanging the market.
fields.body:
Shares in Medical Solutions, the digital diagnosis and pharmaceuticals firm, rose 1.5p to 37.5p in heavy volume yesterday after its broker, Teather & Greenwood, cleared a line of stock overhanging the market.

The clearance followed the conversion of warrants by Mike McDonald, a director and former chairman of the company.

Although the sale of shares by directors is normally a bad sign, in this case it might prove to be beneficial.

Medical Solutions' stock price has been marking time in recent months, unsettled by the number of warrants waiting to be exercised. Mr McDonald agreed to exercise his warrants to help counter these fears.

According to sources close to the company, the shares were snapped up by new and existing investors at 35p, a minimal discount to Tuesday's closing price. A very encouraging sign.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: New ATMs will revive fees row
fields.body:
New ATMs will revive fees row

Another 2,000 cash machines are to be installed across the country, under a roll-out programme announced yesterday by computer firm NCR and US cash machine specialist TRM. The machines will not belong to any bank or carry their branding.

In the first stage, 1,500 cash machines will be opened at "convenience" locations, where hole-in-the-wall machines are not yet situated.

The new machines are expected to rekindle the controversy over the cost of withdrawing money. Banks are planning to axe all charges for customers, but non-bank cash machine providers such as NCR are expected to need to levy a charge to make it worth their while installing the machines.

Brokers may defeat iX plan

The plan to form a pan-European stock exchange, iX, could be defeated unless more details are given before crucial votes on September 14, Britain's retail brokers said yesterday.

Smaller brokers' lobby group the Association of Private Client Fund Managers and Brokers said the London stock exchange and its German counterpart, Deutsche Börse, had not yet given enough information for members to be able to vote iX through.

The lobby group members hold one-third of London stock exchange shares and the exchange needs 75% of shareholders to approve the merger.

"The feeling from our members is that they don't have enough information to make a decision, and if they don't get enough information to make an informed decision then they are not likely to vote in favour," said lobby group spokesman Brian Mairs.

Guinness bids for Staveley

Guinness Peat Group said yesterday it was offering to buy the remaining shares it did not own in British support services company Staveley Industries, with a basic offer of 60p per share.

The offer values Staveley at around £69.8m. Guinness already owns 29.9% in the firm and has made an offer for the whole of Staveley.

Guinness said the offer was final and would not be amended unless a third party came up with a bid.

Ashcroft foils US recruiters

Michael Ashcroft, Conservative party treasurer, has blocked the takeover of a US human resources company and might launch his own bid for Nasdaq-listed Professional Staff.

Professional Staff received a management buyout offer from First Saddle last month.

The team offered $8.3 per share, valuing the company at $72.3m.

The bid was conditional on the management buyout team, advised by Granville Baird, receiving undertakings from at least 90% of shareholders.

However, Carlisle Holdings, the company headed by Mr Ashcroft, has a 7.2% stake and Mr Ashcroft also has 2.8% in his own name.

fields.headline: 1 Find cake recipe 2 Climb Everest
fields.standfirst: Women make them, men make them - but there's a difference.  Anita Chaudhuri  looks at lists
fields.trailText: Women make them, men make them - but there's a difference.  Anita Chaudhuri  looks at lists.
fields.body:
Can there be any piece of prose more hopeful, more suffused with a sense of romantic destiny, than a wedding list? Anthea Turner's turned up in yesterday's Daily Mail and its contents would set even the hardest heart aflutter. Dinner settings for 15 (with steak knives costing £21.50 each). Cream throw by Ralph Lauren, £199. Five sets of Arthur Price cutlery, £152.50 each. (Maybe they don't like washing up.) Tanzanian tablecloth, £102. And so on.

Funnily enough, a list of an entirely different kind grabbed headlines yesterday, too, one that also concerned itself with a romantic destination of a sort. Rod Baber, a 29-year-old telecoms consultant, spoke of a travel itinerary that included such exotic names as Gran Paradiso, Monte Titano, Olympus. On closer inspection, these were found to be not chic five-star hotels but names on a 47-strong list of Europe's highest peaks. And for those of you for whom these things matter, he cut four years off the previous tour record. Yes, astoundingly, someone had tried it before.

Now, let's be agreed on this: mountains are great things, sexy and life-affirming and compelling, in a way that perhaps Anthea Turner is not. But the notion that someone would one day wake up and make a list of every top peak in every European country, then climb each and every last one of them until the list was ticked off, smacks of dull-minded obsession.

The motivation for going somewhere just because it is featured on a list is hard to comprehend. While women's lists are about desire and acquisitiveness, men's tend to be about being master of all they survey. The fact is, men don't make the same lists as women, as anyone who has read or seen Nick Hornby's High Fidelity will know. Theirs are sturdy, lovingly fact-checked mini versions of the Guinness Book of Hit Singles.

"I'm sorry but, at the risk of becoming a Hornby-esque cliché, I really do lie awake at night trying to remember whether it was The Fall who made the most appearances in the top 10 of John Peel's Festive 50 since 1980," confesses one male friend. "And another thing, I just don't understand why you carry around little lists of things like 'Buy lampshade' and 'Find cake recipe', which you then never do."

I'm not entirely sure why I do it either because writing a list of things to do, as with new year resolutions, is no guarantee that you're going to take action. There was a time when I used to keep a diary but now I don't bother, I just make lists, which I keep and laugh about at a later date.

Frankly this is worrying since the nadir of all female list-making is Bridget Jones' Diary. That book is basically a diary in list form. The compulsive daily bulletins on weight, calorie, alcohol and cigarette intake, as well as the odd time inventory featuring moments wasted in the pursuit of unavailable men, amount to a journey with no destination.

Helen Fielding's list-making is curiously male in its obsessive precision and accuracy. The most engaging women's lists are like mini narratives, the sorts of lists you read in the journals of exotic adventurers like Amelia Earhart or Anais Nin. Some women's lists have been transformed into works of art - look at Tracey Emin's patchwork creation Everyone I've Ever Slept With 1963-1995. Video artist Jenny Holzer, who has an installation at Tate Modern, also thrives on lists, in her case alphabetical lists of mocking self-improvement slogans such as Boredom Makes You Do Crazy Things and Protect Me From What I Want.

Gender experts would doubtless posit that this difference in approach is rooted in biology. In their excellent book Why Men Don't Iron (And Women Can't Map Read), Anne and Bill Moir explore the reasons why women tend to seek order over their environments and men just want to go out there and stake out their territory. Yes, you've guessed it, they agree that a Darwinian theory is the only one that makes any sense.

Men apparently have a biological need to go off and conquer various aspects of nature (and by "nature" we can include odd anoraky terrain such as railway platforms), while women are left at home making sad lists about cake mix and plants. This is helpful at least when it comes to understanding why it is that in general men are incapable of making shopping lists; now we know it's because they are biologically programmed to go out and conquer the shelves, filling the trolley with as many useless items as possible, rather than making a list of things that might actually make a meal.

In their excellent book Why Men Don't Iron (And Women Can't Map Read), Anne and Bill Moir explore the reasons why women tend to seek order over their environments and men just want to go out there and stake out their territory. Yes, you've guessed it, they agree that a Darwinian theory is the only one that makes any sense. Men apparently have a biological need to go off and conquer various aspects of nature (and by "nature" we can include odd anoraky terrain such as railway platforms), while women are left at home making sad lists about cake mix and plants. This is helpful at least when it comes to understanding why it is that in general men are incapable of making shopping lists; now we know it's because they are biologically programmed to go out and conquer the shelves, filling the trolley with as many useless items as possible, rather than making a list of things that might actually make a meal.

fields.headline: Take 5
fields.standfirst: At last, the key to men's desires has been revealed: a handful of biological life stages.  Cosmo Landesman reports on why the boys can't help it
fields.trailText: At last, the key to men's desires has been revealed: a handful of biological life stages.  Cosmo Landesman reports on why the boys can't help it.
fields.body:
It seems that with every passing month there appears a new piece of "scientific research" that proves what some feminists have been saying since the 70s: all men are awful. Just look at the cutting edge of recent gene research and what you will see is men being cut down to size and revealed as moral pygmies biologically programmed to behave badly.

Name your favourite male vice (rape, crime, promiscuity) and someone somewhere has the research to prove your point. Well, you know what they say: there are damn lies, statistics and "scientific research".

This week sees the publication of a curious piece that belongs to that growing body of what could be called Aren't Men Awful Research. This one is from a Professor Willy Pasini of the Institute of Psychology in Rome. It's curious because it appears to contain both good and bad news about men. Put simply, the bad news is Pasini proves that the old cliché about randy middle-aged men having a midlife crisis and leaving their wives for younger, more attractive women is true. The good news - at least for the much-maligned middle-aged man - is that he can't help himself.

Pasini concludes, from interviews with 3,000 Italian men, that married men in their 50s are biologically programmed to pursue new romantic attachments. Yes, contrary to what we imagine, such men aren't in fact looking for office flings or one-night stands. It seems the lusty middle-aged lothario is really, at heart, a young romantic looking for love.

Thank God for science! At last here is empirical proof that we middle-aged guys can be more interested in a new soulmate than a sordid shag.

OK, when you finish laughing, I'll continue. Here, you might think, is the perfect alibi men have longed for: "Honestly, darling, I couldn't help sleeping with my secretary. It's my genes wot made me do it. And anyway, this is true love, not tawdry lust!"

Well, roll over Casanova and tell Michael Douglas, Phil Collins, Grant Bovey and Nick Faldo the news: dumping your wife is part of your biological destiny, one of the five stages of love men experience in a lifetime. It seems the mystery of men's emotional DNA has finally been revealed.

According to Pasini, Stage One is the teenage years when males experience a surge of romantic passion that is really a form of puppy love. Real love turns up in Stage Two, when men in their 20s form the kind of emotional bonds that lead to marriage. Come their 30s and men enter Stage Three, known as the libertine phase, which means exploring sex inside and outside of marriage.

Between 40 and 50, men hit Stage Four, start getting restless and are ripe for the middle-aged crisis. Thoughts of death and disappointment with life set in. Then along comes Stage Five; 50-year-old men discover that love is wasted on the young and they want to get a fresh fix of it before they die.

But hold on. Isn't this just pathetic middle-aged lust trying to pass itself off as true love? No, Pasini says: "Men experience not a passing lust but a general resurgence of their emotional life. In other words, they fall in love." Well, at least a third of the Italian men Pasini interviewed had fallen in love again in their 50s.

Unfortunately, Pasini forgot to mention Stage Six in a man's life - the stage at which he's old enough to know that studies like this should be taken with a pinch of salt. Men are not programmed like washing machines to go through certain definite emotional, erotic and romantic cycles. I know men in their 40s and 50s who have experienced the puppy love passion of a teenager - and I have known teenagers who have experience the quiet desperation and disappointment of the middle-aged man with the midlife crisis.

As for the "libertine impulses" that supposedly kick in around the 30s and 40s, I suspect for most men they first surface in puberty and stick around till death do part them from a lifetime of erotic desire.

But while Pasini's study may seem like a piece of Aren't Men OK Research, it is in fact just the opposite. For in putting men in these nice, neat stages of emotional development, he ends up perpetuating the idea that the midlife crisis and longing for romance is a predominantly male phenomenon.

Women who snigger at the suggestion that middle-aged men fool around because they are looking for love are actually falling for a neo-Victorian idea about women. The unstated subtext of their snigger is this: women in their 40s and 50s don't get restless and long for romantic passion. No, these sexually contented women stand by their men, no matter what! So while men are biologically programmed to fall in love at 50, women are built to stay faithful.

Now, that's something worth laughing at. Of course some women do, but then so do many men. To his credit, Pasini's study does make the important and often forgotten point that some men faced with a midlife crisis feel a surge of passion and fall in love with their wives all over again.

What his research doesn't reveal is that there are many women who have a Fifth Stage of their own and it's called: I'm Bored With This Marriage, Goodbye! I know because that's what my wife said to me one day and that's fair enough. What's wrong is the assumption that it is always poor little women who are getting dumped by their dirty-minded old husbands. It is a view that has become the common wisdom of our age, simply because of high-profile celebrity splits like that of Michael Douglas and his wife Diandra.

But for every fiftysomething male star who found love with a younger woman, there is a woman's tale, too. Take Francesca Annis, who dumped her long-term partner in favour of the younger Ralph Fiennes. If you think only men are prone to the midlife crisis sex fling, well, you should tell that to Meg Ryan who recently left her husband of many years, Dennis Quaid, to go off and make whoopee with Russell Crowe.

And let us not forget the tabloids' favourite tale of the middle-aged man in search of young crumpet, Grant Bovey and Anthea Turner. What people forget is that not only did Grant, who was only 38 and thus should have been in Stage Four, leave his wife of seven years, but Anthea Turner left her husband, too.

The real issue Pasini's study raises is not about how long-term marriages can survive men's biological drives. Rather, we have to deal with the fact that increasingly both men and women are no longer prepared to put up with the boredom and familiarity that comes when the fireworks of love have faded from a marriage. For when it comes to discovering true love or the reality of getting dumped, men and women are for once truly equal.

fields.headline: Doocot detectives
fields.standfirst: Cadboll, Highlands
fields.trailText: It was like a history lesson as we passed the 12th-century abbey at Fearn, the name derives from the Gaelic Fearnn meaning alder tree. Then, nearer the east coast, the remains of Cadboll Castle that was probably built around the same time although it could have been earlier. Cadboll means "dwelling of the wildcats" although I doubt very much whether there any true wildcats in the area these days.
fields.body:
It was like a history lesson as we passed the 12th-century abbey at Fearn, the name derives from the Gaelic Fearnn meaning alder tree. Then, nearer the east coast, the remains of Cadboll Castle that was probably built around the same time although it could have been earlier. Cadboll means "dwelling of the wildcats" although I doubt very much whether there any true wildcats in the area these days.

The very impressive Glenmorangie House, now a hotel, adjacent to the castle was started in the 17th century but the reason for our visit was to see a much smaller structure in the grounds and built comparatively more recently. The doocot is a rectangular lectern type with a single sloping roof and the date on the lintel of the lower door indicated 1805 with the initials GR. This type of doocot superseded the older beehive type in the 16th and 17th century and they are unusual in that they are only found in Scotland and France.

It was good to see doos flying in and out. The presence of two doors, one above the other, may indicate that the bottom part was used for another purpose such as keeping poultry or pigs. A much smaller hole in another wall was probably for taking out dung which was modified to make a form of gunpowder. The two walls on either side of the sloping roof project upwards above the slates to protect the doo entrance holes. Three of the walls had a double rat course which are projecting ridges to stop rats climbing up to the entrance holes.

On the top of the doocot were five decorative round stone balls known as finials but the most striking feature was a three feet high metal silhouette shaped like a country gentleman in colourful breeches, boots and black hat and carrying a gun. One source said the figure was a weathervane whilst another said it was a scarecrow but my guess is that it was to scare off the birds of prey.

Considering its age and apart from a few dislodged slates the doocot was in good condition and it was exciting to add it to our own inventory of doocots in the Highlands.

webTitle: Real Lives: Ex-MP and Polish ex-electrician find love

fields.headline: We have nothing to hide
fields.standfirst: He was an 83-year-old former Labour MP. She was a 33-year-old Polish ex-electrician. Together, they found love among the passionflowers. Now Leo Abse and Ania Czeputkowska talk to  Julia Langdon
fields.trailText: He was an 83-year-old former Labour MP. She was a 33-year-old Polish ex-electrician. Together, they found love among the passionflowers. Now Leo Abse and Ania Czeputkowska talk to  Julia Langdon.
fields.body:
It is almost like a cliché from a Mills & Boon romance, but there is no escaping the reality that it was the passionflower cascading down the front of his handsome house beside the river Thames that changed the life of Leo Abse so completely and so unexpectedly. The old man was on his doorstep above the public towpath in Chiswick one sunny afternoon a couple of years ago when a beautiful young woman stopped to admire and ask about the flower.

He is the wealthy retired solicitor and former Labour MP who was once the author of much private member's legislation on homosexual, marriage and family law reform. More latterly, since leaving the House of Commons in 1987, he has written books about the psychology of politics. He is 83 years old.

She is Ania Czeputkowska, a former electrician from Gdansk in Poland, who came to Britain without a word of English, acquired a diploma in general arts and design, took a degree and got a first while working as a cleaning lady, won a bursary to the Royal College of Arts to study printed and textile design and has now just been awarded her master's. She has sold designs for fabric production in New York and to one of Britain's best-known wallpaper firms. She is 33 years old, and three weeks ago in the rather unglamorous surroundings of Hounslow register office she married Leo Abse. They have returned from honeymoon in a castle at Sintra in Portugal; they are tanned and happy, and exude a delighted contentment in each other. It is an unusual and enchanting story.

Leo Abse was widowed five years ago. Marjorie, his wife of more than 40 years and the mother of his two grown children, died and left him desolate. He cut a sorry, bereft figure. "Although I was holding on, it was tough," he says. "It was an arid period. You behave stoically, but not happily." He has two brothers: the poet Danny and an elder brother, Wilfred, a distinguished psychoanalyst in the United States who rather shocked him by suggesting that he should snap out of himself and find a young woman. "I had thought, 'I'm going to die a widower and this is the way of life I have to endure until my death.' " Wilfred changed his thinking, and shortly afterwards Ania strolled into his life.

In some ways the attraction was a classic one. Her father died of cancer when she was just one year old. Her mother, an administrator with the Polish national transport system, never remarried and raised Ania and her elder brother alone. As a child, Anya was a brilliant mathematician but an undiagnosed dyslexic until the age of 18. She found her Polish examinations, in subjects except maths, incredibly difficult. She fled them one year to come to England with a friend and spent two happy months picking strawberries near Colchester, living in a tent.

Although she went home and worked as a precision mechanic, repairing irons and hair dryers, then as a technical demonstrator in the physics department at Gdansk University, she wanted to return to Britain. She supplemented her income at home by working as a florist, or selling vegetables, or being a parking warden, and eventually came to study art and learn English in London. She had one or two boyfriends, but they were not serious or didn't work out. Leo, she says, was the first man to make her feel like a woman.

She was fascinated by him when they met. She knew nothing of British politics and little of psychology. He invited her and her girlfriend for tea to talk about passionflowers, he asked them round for a meal and then again. Her girlfriend teased her that he was "after her", and she became suspicious. He took her to the Savile Club, bought her wine, sent her perfume and lent her books, and she became more uneasy. She turned down further invitations, sent the perfume back and returned the books with a note which read: "I don't think I am the woman you are looking for."

Three weeks later she telephoned him again, and this time allowed a relationship to develop. After a while, exhausted from cycling between her job, her flat, her college and his house, she decided to move in. He suited her. She wanted to look after him. "I let go of all the suspicion and I started listening to him," she says. "We have made an effort. We somehow understand each other and there is a friendship that has been built up in the last year - to know each other you have got to live with each other, to see each other every day."

"She is an all-or-nothing woman," says Leo, admiringly. He remembers the moment when he realised they were going to have to get married. "Here was this woman who is enormously creative, who has an ability to battle through and to stand on her own feet, who is formidable and who has won her way to the most prestigious art college in the country and yet who has time to notice that my socks had holes in because my toenails needed cutting. It was when she was cutting my toenails that I realised I would have to marry Ania."

They laugh delightedly at how prosaic this is. Neither of them is embarrassed about their love. Leo says that he is far too old to care what anybody else thinks and Ania is a woman who knows her own mind.

Their homecoming has been a little marred, perhaps inevitably, by the excessive interest of the tabloid press. Leo Abse, with his fascination with psychoanalysis, understands this better than Ania, who has been tidying up the garden since they got back to Chiswick, filling nine bags with weeds and clippings rather than going out to face the intrusive lenses that have appeared from time to time on the doorstep. "They really want a picture of her in a bikini," says Leo, chuckling with undisguised delight and mischief at his capacity to stir up controversy yet again.

She, however, was a little upset and greatly astonished by the fact that in their absence on holiday the press pursued their friends and relatives across the continent. "What disturbs them is the intergenerational relationship," says Leo. "It can stir up fears. It is too near incest and the great taboo, of course, which has to be maintained to have an acceptable society is against incest. Freud said ..." and he is off and away on his favourite subject. Ania listens with a commendable serenity for a while, until she starts to disagree. "Hold on, Leo," she says. "Hold on," she repeats when he doesn't hear her, for he is quite deaf. Then, if he still persists, she will put a restraining hand on his arm or raise her hand to him across the room in order to interrupt his flow and make a point.

They disagree, for example, about babies. "If it happens, it happens," he says. It is improbable in any case that they will start a family, he says, but Ania will be able to cope, just as her mother did; he means when he is not around to see any children of hers grow to adulthood. Ania says that she is more interested in her career, in sorting her priorities with the exciting possibilities that she has ahead. She is less certain about raising children on her own, however capable she is.

In the meantime, there are other, more immediate hurdles: Leo's children need to get used to the idea of his changed circumstances; her mother has needed reassurance. And she wants to be able to emerge from her front door without being photographed. They chose to talk to the Guardian because they don't want their relationship sensationalised. They have nothing to hide and just wish to be free to continue walking hand in hand down life's towpath.
