And she wants to be able to emerge from her front door without being photographed. They chose to talk to the Guardian because they don't want their relationship sensationalised. They have nothing to hide and just wish to be free to continue walking hand in hand down life's towpath.

webTitle: Zapatistas wait for proof of new Mexican order

fields.headline: Zapatistas wait for proof of new Mexican order
fields.standfirst: Chiapas rebels remain wary of the politicians replacing the old guard
fields.trailText: A few years ago the derelict building just down the road from the market place in this small highland town in Chiapas was a focus of world attention. Today it decays silently, ignored by all but a scavenging stray dog, with nothing to show that it housed the last serious attempt to negotiate an end to the Zapatistas' battle for indigenous rights.
fields.byline: Jo Tuckman in San Andres Larrainzar
fields.body:
A few years ago the derelict building just down the road from the market place in this small highland town in Chiapas was a focus of world attention. Today it decays silently, ignored by all but a scavenging stray dog, with nothing to show that it housed the last serious attempt to negotiate an end to the Zapatistas' battle for indigenous rights.

The San Andres accords, signed here in February 1996, promised Mexico's indigenous communities political and cultural autonomy in partial redress of the centuries of discrimination and violence which lay behind the Zapatista uprising, which took the state by storm on New Year's Day 1994.

But President Ernesto Zedillo shelved the agreement before the year was out, Sub-Comandante Marcos took his masked rebels back to their jungle hideouts, and the unarmed Zapatista faithful in San Andres were left to experiment with self-government on their own.

Four years later they are still there, occupying the old town hall on the opposite side of the square from the official town authorities, and waiting to see if their world is about to be shaken once again now that the old political order dominated by the PRI, the Institutional Revolutionary party, has collapsed.

"We just don't know what to think yet," said the mayor, Marcos Gonzalez, a small earnest man who insisted that the Zapatista authorities had a lot to do, despite having no resources to do it with and consequently dwindling support.

"Things could get better, or things could get worse," Felipe Diez said as he sat behind an old cast-iron pedal sewing machine in his tailor's shop just off the square, his world-weary smile betraying a hint of excitement.

A political earthquake shook Mexico's foundations on July 2 when Vicente Fox of the National Action party won the presidential election and ended the PRI's 71-year monopoly of national government.

The aftershock came on Sunday, when the PRI lost the Chiapas state governorship to Pablo Salazar, who has the support of a broad alliance.

Both men have announced a new peace drive for Chiapas. Mr Fox promises to dust off the San Andres accords and reconsider the military's role in the state, and Mr Salazar has committed himself to going after the local PRI bosses and the paramilitary groups associated with them.

They hope this will bring the Zapatistas back to the negotiating table to end the conflict, which has brought its supporters nothing but more poverty and harassment.

"They say they will be different but seeing is believing, and we haven't seen it yet," Mr Gonzalez said.

"They've got to prove they are serious," said Mr. Diez.

Both said it was that realistic scepticism which was keeping Sub-Commandante Marcos from reacting to the new situation.

He is usually given to long poetic communiques on national issues, but has yet to utter a word on the collapse of the PRI, for so long the rebels' primary enemy.

"He's not going to fall into a trap," Mr. Diez said.

"The uprising took place because the government is only interested in exploiting us. Maybe the new ones are different and it can be resolved, but it will need 10 or 15 years at least, and it will never be solved if the people continue [to be] so poor they can hardly afford their daily maize and beans."

The mayor said that for the talks to resume the villages and towns in the conflict zone would have to be demilitarised and the San Andres accords put back on track.

The situation in San Andres is unusual in that most Zapatista autonomous municipalities were formed in smaller settlements with no rival official authority. But somehow the two sides manage to coexist.

"San Andres is a singular case. It's not exactly a model of reconciliation, more of an example of reluctant tolerance," Francisco Gallardo of the civil rights group Alianza Civica said.

But the delicate balance here will have to adapt to the PRI's collapse. No one seems to know how, and many fear that tension will return.

"There are rumours that the paramilitaries are getting ready to attack if the PRI loses," Mr. Gonzalez said, recalling the massacre of 45 people by a PRI-linked group in Acteal, just a couple of hill tops away, three years ago.

"They are only rumours, but it has happened before in other places so it could happen again."

 Four people were killed and up to 38 injured in the isolated Chiapas hamlet of Pena Limonar, 90 miles north-east of the city of San Cristobal de las Casas, on Tuesday, the Televisa network reported.

Officials said the state prosecutor's investigators had not yet reported from the scene, a five-hour drive from the nearest town, adding that the clash appeared to concern a land dispute between Zapatista and PRI supporters.

webTitle: Sir Clive earns £963,000 in a bad year

fields.headline: Sir Clive earns £963,000 in a bad year
fields.trailText: Sir Clive Thompson, chief executive of the royal ratcatcher Rentokil Initial, had one of the worst years of his career but still picked up a healthy £963,000, writes Andrew Clark .
fields.body:
Sir Clive Thompson, chief executive of the royal ratcatcher Rentokil Initial, had one of the worst years of his career but still picked up a healthy £963,000, writes Andrew Clark .

Until recently, Sir Clive was known as "Mr 20%" for his record of consistent profits growth. That tag disappeared abruptly as the business services group managed an underlying increase of just 6.3%, triggering a decline in the shares to a four-year low.

The sluggish nature of markets for plant hire, distribution and personnel finally caught up with the company, and the slowdown was aggravated by tough conditions in some Asian markets. Sir Clive reacted by ordering a disposal programme to clear out unexciting operations, but the proceeds have fallen short of target.

Sir Clive, 58, did suffer a fall in his remuneration, having received £1.45m in 1998. However, his income was still higher than two-thirds of FTSE 100 bosses, thanks to his unusually large basic salary of £950,000 - the fifth highest for any director of a British company.

This was despite a 22% fall in total shareholder return - the company's shares began the year at 450p and ended it at less than 250p, although the dividend was still raised 11%.

Rentokil's annual report gives no explanation of the level of Sir Clive's salary, except to say it "takes into account the size, complexity and international nature of the company's operations".

Under a new, more generous, bonus scheme, if Sir Clive achieves growth in earnings of 20% once more, he will receive a performance payout equivalent to 180% of his salary - half in deferred shares, and half in cash.

A former president of the Confederation of British Industry, Sir Clive has traditionally been one of the City's most popular businessmen. He has been a staunch defender of boardroom pay rates, arguing against the government's efforts to allow shareholders a vote on remuneration policies. He explained away his rough ride last year, saying he had been "a reasonably successful chief executive for 16 years and not so successful for one year".

Sir Clive has shares in Rentokil worth £9.2m. Since the end of the company's financial year in December, the share price has fallen further - it slipped as low as 130p in March. The company's remuneration committee is headed by non-executive director Brian McGowan - whose day job is as executive chairman of the electronic components group Umeco.

fields.headline: Save our seeds
fields.standfirst: Peter Crane is a man with a mission - to rescue the planet's plants from extinction. The director of Kew gardens tells  Tim Radford why Britain's new £80m seed bank is the keeper of all our futures
fields.trailText: Peter Crane is a man with a mission - to rescue the planet's plants from extinction. The director of Kew gardens tells Tim Radford why Britain's new £80m seed bank is the keeper of all our futures.
fields.body:
If all flesh is grass, then it makes sense to take care of the lawn. And all flesh truly is grass. If you could weigh every human and all their domestic livestock, the scales would tip at 1.1bn tons - and every ounce of this living flesh depends on plant life. Humans are not just leaders in the field, they and their livestock consume most of the field.

Consume is the word. There could be about 270,000 species of flowering plants already named, and perhaps another 50,000 to be identified. And, says Peter Crane, director of the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew in London, around 30% of them are threatened. A quarter of them could vanish within 50 years.

Which is why he is about to formally open a new kind of world bank to store the seeds of plants at risk for up to 200 years and push for yet more research into the green things that bankroll all animal life. Plants produce the oxygen that humans breathe, and the food they eat, the medicines they use, the clothes they wear and the shelters in which they live.

The odd thing is that after millennia of co-existence, most humans know very little about them. Only about 7,000 species of plant have been gathered or cultivated, a mere 200 have been domesticated and around a dozen of them provide 75% of the world's calories. Two of them, rice and wheat, produce - directly - 45% of the world's protein. Indirectly, of course, plants provide all of it.

These brutal economic facts make research institutions such as Kew the keepers of the planet's future. It is not the only important botanical gardens - there is a network of them, co-operating in research - but it is the tallest poppy in the meadow. Its £80m millennium seed bank at Wakehurst Place in Sussex is about to open to the public.

It already holds seeds from most of Britain's flora and for the next nine years Kew's scientists will be out in the field collecting tens of thousands of specimens to be dried, and kept at sub-zero temperatures, to be taken out again and grown and gathered and frozen again - a kind of vegetable Noah's Ark, to save species otherwise doomed by human expansion into the wilderness.

Many of them will be from the dry lands, the regions of the earth where plants are already most at risk and humans struggle every day for survival. "Why should we care?" says Crane. "Someone like me who sees what we have today as the product of tens of millions of years of evolution asks: is it really rational to allow, in a space of a couple of generations, such a catastrophic change to occur? I think there is an ethical, moral issue there that has to do with our place in nature and the way we view ourselves and our general stewardship of the planet, these sorts of things. For me that is a pretty powerful argument. For some people that wouldn't cut a lot of ice. But for me there is a justification for pausing a moment and saying: is this rational? Do we want to wreak these kinds of irreversible changes?"

He has seen such changes already. His first business was palaeobotany. He worked in the Field Museum in Chicago on fossil plants. Flowering plants began to bloom on the planet only about 130m years ago, and soon trees related to magnolias, and precursors of the walnut and the oak were co-existing with the dinosaurs. There were palms, dogwoods, gingers and a diversity of other things. There were no grasses - the precursors of the wheats and ryes and cocksfoots that feed the world turned up only 30m years ago - but the shales and coal measures and chalk deposits kept producing evidence of an enduring and slowly altering kingdom, flowering into greater and greater diversity.

From Chicago, Crane - born in Britain, educated at Reading, 45, and married with two children - moved to take over Kew and his view switched from the past to the future. What he saw - what any biologist would have seen - was a massacre of living things, a huge narrowing of green diversity.

"In the western world we are very insulated from nature, or at least we tend to think we are. Our day to day reliance on plant diversity is not the same as it is in other places," he says. "But they reckon that 80% of the world is still reliant on plant resources for its primary health care."

He has just come back from a visit to a co-operative project in the dry lands of north-east Brazil. "They don't have the money to pay the bus to go to the hospital. If they go to the hospital they haven't the money to pay for the drugs they need. So they grow medicinal plants in their gardens and those medicinal plants help them through the less serious parts of their health care needs. They are very, very important. Intestinal parasites, for instance: there are lots of plants they use as purgatives. Curiously enough we are seeing the same trend here, with Chinese herbalists."

Diversity pays dividends in all sorts of ways. An enthusiastic British gardener might have a dozen species of useful plants on his plot. An African or Latin American family might have more than 100: when the game is uncertain, it pays to spread your bets. The botanists went to Brazil to help, but they also went to learn. One farmer in the Brazilian drylands had found a new way with a neglected resource, Crane says.

"He was growing cattle, but they basically don't have enough water. So periodically he has nothing to feed these things, so he was very interested in how you get through the bad times. One of the things they had been working on in these groups was the use of cacti for the boundary fences. He was using three or four different species of cacti for keeping animals out of growing areas but what he had also found out was he could harvest these cacti as food for his animals. In the ordinary course of events he wouldn't be feeding his animals cacti, but when things get really rough he can almost coppice them, get the spines off them and have good, short-term animal fodder. It's pretty nutritious."

The tropical wet forests are disappearing because of ruthless commercial exploitation of hardwoods and colonisation by desperate farmers. In the drylands, plants are perishing because people are struggling to survive: their cattle clear the landscape and the farmers collect what is left as fuel because they have no other choice. Greed and poverty are one set of enemies, human movement is another, as lusty foreign species take over in precarious ecosystems. The only way ahead is to work with the people who depend on their local flora - and collect like mad for the millennium seed bank.

"It's a fairly last-ditch approach," says Crane. "It's better to conserve the plants in the field in which they grow, and they might support the eco-system they support, or on which they depend. But in a lot of cases it's a matter of saying: let's get these things into a safe haven, that we can then use in the future for reintroduction, before they diminish to such a level that either the genetic diversity has been stripped out, or they have gone more or less completely."

A seed bank exhibition opens to the public at Wakehurst Place, Ardingley, Sussex (01444 894 000) on Saturday. The bank itself opens for business in October. Link: www.kew.org.

webTitle: Pre-Inca ruins found in lake Titicaca

fields.headline: Ancient wonder
fields.standfirst: Pre-Inca ruins found in lake Titicaca
fields.trailText: The ruins of what is thought to be a huge ancient temple have been discovered by archaeologists diving beneath Lake Titicaca in the Andes between Bolivia and Peru.
fields.body:
The ruins of what is thought to be a huge ancient temple have been discovered by archaeologists diving beneath Lake Titicaca in the Andes between Bolivia and Peru.

An international team of scientists announced the finding this week after making more than 200 dives in Titicaca, which, at 3,800m above sea level, is the world's highest navigable lake.

"We've found what appears to have been a 200-metre-long, 50-metre-wide holy temple, a terrace for crops, a pre-Incan road and an 800-metre-long containing wall," said Lorenzo Epis, the Italian leading the Atahuallpa 2000 expedition. Ceramic artefacts were also found on the lake's floor.

Titicaca has long been the subject of legends about a lost underwater city, but there has been little research because of the logistical difficulties of diving at altitude.

While a submerged city has not been found, Mr Epis said the ruins appeared to be 1,000 to 1,500 years old. It thus predates the Incas and could point to the Tihuanaco people, who lived on Titicaca's shores before becoming part of the Incan empire.

"This means our civilisations have left more footprints than we had thought," said Antonio Eguino, Bolivia's vice-minister of culture. The ruins were found in an area of the lake between the town of Copacabana and the popular tourist destinations of the Island of the Sun and Island of the Moon. The divers followed a submerged road until they arrived at the discoveries, at a depth of about 20 metres.

In addition to the practical difficulties, the research project had to contend with a worried public, who had not been informed of the project. Diving was delayed for four days because of the distrust of the local population on the Island of the Sun, who believe the lake is sacred.

Akakor Geographical Exploring, an Italian cultural association that organised the expedition, first made a trip to Titicaca in 1998 to look at underwater caves and to research diving techniques at high altitude.

Marco Antonio Simi, who was on that expedition, said that the groundwork on pressure levels allowed the group to return this year; most diving technology is based on ocean-bound dives, where pressure levels are very different.

Mr Simi said this was the first time top-level divers and professional archaeologists had investigated Titicaca together, adding that it was rare for specialists of both disciplines to work side by side.

The team was looking for an underwater temple. "What they found was the beginning of what they were looking for," he said.

Akakor Geographical Exploring, an Italian cultural association that organised the expedition, first made a trip to Titicaca in 1998 to look at underwater caves and to research diving techniques at high altitude. Marco Antonio Simi, who was on that expedition, said that the groundwork on pressure levels allowed the group to return this year; most diving technology is based on ocean-bound dives, where pressure levels are very different. Mr Simi said this was the first time top-level divers and professional archaeologists had investigated Titicaca together, adding that it was rare for specialists of both disciplines to work side by side. The team was looking for an underwater temple. "What they found was the beginning of what they were looking for," he said.

webTitle: Success or failure still brings top-dollar reward

fields.headline: Success or failure still brings top-dollar reward
fields.trailText: "If you pay people peanuts, you get monkeys." That is how FTSE 100 companies justify offering multi-million pound windfalls to directors.
fields.body:
"If you pay people peanuts, you get monkeys." That is how FTSE 100 companies justify offering multi-million pound windfalls to directors.

So is it true? Is there a relationship between the weight of directors' pay packets and performance? The answer, on the surface from the Guardian-Inbucon boardroom pay survey, is yes - the most obese of the fat cats were at highly successful companies.

Closer examination of the figures casts a dubious light on the claim that money buys an inspirational performance. The headline figures earned by the chiefs of Britain's hottest companies are enormous - Paul Chisholm of the stock market phenomenon Colt Telecom took home £15.2m last year. Mike Grabiner of Energis, which has seen its shares surge seven-fold since 1998, enjoyed a package of £11.6m.

The top three earners in the FTSE 100 work for three of the index's top four companies in terms of shareholder return.

Those at the bottom still did very nicely. Bob Ayling, for example, who was sacked after navigating British Airways into loss-making territory, walked away with £2.48m in his last year.

Other dunces included Sir Clive Thompson - once dubbed "Mr 20%" for his record in increasing profits at Rentokil. Despite a 22% slump in shareholder returns, he scooped £963,000.

The worst blue-chip performer of all, Marks & Spencer, paid its embattled boss, Peter Salsbury, an above-average £573,000. Graham Mackay of South African Breweries, which experienced a 12% fall in sales amid economic turbulence around the Cape, still pocketed £812,000.

Pay at FTSE 100 companies is decided by non-executive directors. The same names crop up everywhere - effectively, remuneration in the City is decided by a few hundred people, most of whom see each other as friends.

These over-the-hill businessmen have become increasingly inventive in designing "incentive" packages. They usually claim that these are closely linked to performance, to give top executives a financial incentive to do well.

The real picture is that different methods of pay are delicately balanced, to give a hefty return irrespective of circumstances. At the top of the tree, executives scoop millions from share options, enjoying the benefits of their surging stock prices.

Among unexciting stalwart companies at the bottom, basic salaries are much higher - because an outstanding performance is not expected.

Among the top 10 payers in basic salary are Kingfisher, Unilever and Rentokil - all resolutely old economy, low-growth companies. Their chiefs all picked up more than £750,000, before performance was even taken into account.

Meanwhile, at fast-growing companies such as Arm Holdings, Sema and Capita Group, some senior directors rubbed along on little more than £100,000, making up the difference in options.

Many of the worst performing companies still paid bonuses - James Crosby of the Halifax was awarded an extra £108,000 after presiding over a 5% fall in profits and a 14% slump in shareholder returns. The bonus was apparently to reward him for meeting an undisclosed "target" set by fellow directors.

Graham Brown of National Power, which suffered a 10% reverse in profits and a 17% dive in shareholder value, got a bonus of £117,000 for "strong performance in a difficult market".

The system devised by the City's non-executive community offers little scope, therefore, for penalising failure.

Members of the tight-knit network serving on remuneration committees are reluctant to single out colleagues for punishment.

Therefore, top directors can sleep complacently at night with little fear that mediocre performances will hurt their bank balances.

fields.headline: Uplift: Gherkin approved
fields.trailText: Lord Foster's controversial plans to build a 180-metre tower, dubbed "the erotic gherkin", on the site of the City's Baltic Exchange were given the go-ahead yesterday by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott.
fields.body:
Lord Foster's controversial plans to build a 180-metre tower, dubbed "the erotic gherkin", on the site of the City's Baltic Exchange were given the go-ahead yesterday by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott.

Building the 41-storey tower will involve levelling the grade II listed Baltic Exchange building that was severely damaged by an IRA bomb in 1992.

The "erotic gherkin" is the first tall structure given permission to be built in the City since the 1970s, and will stand shorter only than Tower 42, formerly known as the NatWest Tower.

Mr Prescott's all-clear is the final stage in the planning process. The Corporation of London last month gave its approval.

It is likely to fuel fears of a rush of applications for towering office blocks in the City. Applications already filed, include plans for a 37-storey tower in Bishopsgate and a 420-metre tower at London Bridge station.

webTitle: DTI under fire over Post Office's German deal

fields.headline: DTI under fire over Post Office's German deal
fields.trailText: The government and the Post Office have been rapped over the knuckles by the National Audit Office (NAO) over their handling of the Post Office's £289m acquisition of German Parcel.
fields.body:
The government and the Post Office have been rapped over the knuckles by the National Audit Office (NAO) over their handling of the Post Office's £289m acquisition of German Parcel.

A report to be presented to parliament today by auditor general Sir John Bourne calls on the Department of Trade and Industry to make a number of changes before overseeing future deals.

The NAO concluded the DTI had acted "reasonably under the circumstances," but expressed concern it had employed only one adviser who was required to work to a tight, commercially driven timetable.

The audit office calls on the DTI and other government departments with similar roles to establish a team with corporate finance and relevant sectoral experience to enable them to appraise takeover deals more effectively.

The report says the DTI should have demanded much more information on the German parcel delivery operator than was given by the Post Office, particularly on issues such as price.

The Post Office and DTI last night said they had taken on board the NAO's recommendations and the department was appointing Deloitte & Touche as permanent advisers.

The Post Office bought German Parcel in January 1999 in one of the first major acquisitions by a publicly owned industry for many years. It has since concluded more than a dozen smaller deals.

fields.headline: No: 1706
fields.standfirst: Kama Sutra
fields.trailText: Kama Sutra
fields.body:
Age: Old but still surprisingly nimble.

Can you be a little more precise? Not really - 1,500 is a reasonable guesstimate, although anywhere between the 1st century BC and the 5th century AD is feasible. It was supposedly written in Sanskrit by an Indian sage called Vatsyayana and translated by the explorer Sir Richard Burton in 1883.

Sex manual, isn't it? Not according to Channel 4, which is turning the book into a series called Position Impossible. "We're getting away from the idea that it's just an old version of The Joy of Sex."

Oh yeah, pull the other one. Ah, I see you've read it.

Anything to boost ratings. You misunderstand the nature of the enterprise. Channel 4 says it's as much about gardening as sex.

And is it? Gardening is indeed one of the 64 practices of the Kama Shastra - the science of Kama.

You've lost me. I thought it was all about copulation. You've obviously been reading the abridged version.

What about all those impossible positions? You mean the congress of the cow, dog, goat and deer, the forcible mounting of an ass, the congress of the cat, the jump of the tiger, the pressing of the elephant, the rubbing of the boar, the mounting of the horse etc, etc.

Yes. All very tricky. Best stick to the hydrangeas.

Any useful tips? Prune in September.

No, on love-making. "Sexual intercourse can be compared to a quarrel." Vatsyayana is enthusiastic about biting and smacking; he's also surprisingly keen on group sex and herbal recipes for penis enlargement.

Not to be confused with: Charlie Dimmock's Bumper Gardening Handbook.

Do say: "This work is not intended to be used merely as an instrument for satisfying our desires. A person acquainted with the true principles of Dharma, Artha and Kama is sure to obtain mastery over his senses."

Don't say: "Can I have the penis enlargement recipe please?"

fields.headline: Energis chief weighs his options
fields.trailText: Mike Grabiner has been well rewarded for building Energis into one of Britain's leading business telecoms companies - he took home a total of £11.6m last year.
fields.body:
Mike Grabiner has been well rewarded for building Energis into one of Britain's leading business telecoms companies - he took home a total of £11.6m last year.

Most of the money came from exercising options, as Mr Grabiner, 50, took advantage of a seven-fold surge in the firm's shares since 1998.

Energis was originally part of National Grid - its business was built on stringing telephone cables between electricity pylons. It was spun off two years ago and has benefited from demand for high-speed communications, alongside the growth of the internet.

Energis' big coup last year was the purchase of Racal's telecoms business for £750m. This brought on board a list of new commercial customers and took out a significant competitor.

The company remains in the red - it made a pre-tax loss of £31.1m last year. But UK earnings were positive for the first time and Energis has established itself as a stronger player than an other power company spin-off, Scottish group Thus.

Mr Grabiner has a basic salary of £431,000 - about average for a chief executive in the FTSE 100. He gets a cash performance bonus of up to 50% of his salary, and Energis awards its directors generous options based on varying performance criteria.

Those exercised by Mr Grabiner were awarded in 1996 and became exercisable if shares performed better than the FTSE All Share index.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Reno rules out Gore inquiry
fields.body:
Reno rules out Gore inquiry

The US attorney general, Janet Reno, will not appoint special counsel to investigate vice-president Al Gore's 1996 campaign fundraising activities, it was announced yesterday.

After reviewing a transcript of an April interview between Mr Gore and federal investigators, she concluded that "I have decided that a special counsel is not warranted. Further investigation is not likely to result in a prosecutable case ... The transcripts reveal neither false statements nor perjury".

AP, Washington

Italian paper lists paedophiles

An Italian newspaper has named 16 people it claims are convicted paedophiles, after public fury over two girls, aged four and eight, who were sexually abused and murdered last week.

The newly-launched rightwing Libero newspaper, lists 12 men and four women it says are guilty of crimes ranging from aiding and abetting sex abusers to child rape.

Reuter, Rome

Chimps inherit £40,600 in will

Six chimpanzees in Copenhagen zoo have inherited £40,600 after the death of an 83-year-old widow.

A judge said Jimmy, Trunte, Fifi, Trine, Grinni and Gigi had behaved better during the reading of the will than many human heirs he had seen in court. The money will be used to improve the chimpanzees' facilities.

Reuters, Copenhagen

Turkey struck by earthquake

An earthquake registering 5.8 on the Richter scale struck Turkey's Sakarya province yesterday.

The area, 90 miles east of Istanbul, was badly damaged in the quakes which killed more than 17,000 people last year. There were no reports of injuries or damage from yesterday's quake.

AP, Istanbul

Russian lawyer commits suicide

A former top prosecutor in the Soviet Union has committed suicide at a seaside town in southern Russia, apparently overcome by the recent death of his wife and son, and plagued by financial problems.

Alexander Katusev died after a shot in the head with his own service pistol in a town on the Azov Sea on Monday.

AP, Moscow

webTitle: Democracy in Nigeria adds fuel to delta oil conflict

fields.headline: Democracy adds fuel to delta oil conflict
fields.standfirst: The resumption of civilian rule in Nigeria has not brought promised improvements
fields.trailText: The resumption of civilian rule in Nigeria has not brought promised improvements.
fields.body:
Anthony Ogbise, 81, is among the few who have remained in Odi after the destruction. The Nigerian army came in the early hours, razing house after house, but carefully bypassing the banks and government offices, until they got to his door.

"They dragged me out and a captain said 'go and wash him', which meant they would kill me next to the river and dump me in the water.

"Somebody hit my arms and head with the butt of a gun. Another kicked me in the stomach. But they didn't kill me. They dragged me to their headquarters and beat me more.

"They used kerosene to burn the houses. I'm 81 years old. I'm not rich. I can't build a new house."

There is not much left of Odi. Almost all its several thousand houses were burned by the soldiers. Hundreds of people were killed and buried in shallow graves beside the road. All but a few of the people fled.

The destruction did not occur at the hands of one of Nigeria's repressive military dictatorships. It happened just nine months ago under the elected civilian government of Olusegun Obasanjo.

The government blamed the army. The army accused militant Ijaw youths of provoking the attack by murdering a group of policemen in the town. The youths said the government was to blame, because it failed to fulfil its promise of relief for the Niger delta.

The region's misery is well documented. The 2m barrels of oil pumped from the delta each day provides more than 90% of Nigeria's foreign income. The delta communities have little to show for it beyond contamination, repression, and an ever more restless younger generation which has found violence, hostage-taking and extortion in place of jobs.

Changes for the worse

Today the burnt-out houses stand as a monument to the failed hope that democratic rule would rescue the delta. Its blighted communities looked to the new government to ensure that the region benefited from the riches it gives up. But a bill to set up a development commission to return some of the oil profits to the delta is stuck in the national assembly, a victim of the endless feuding between MPs and President Obasanjo.

"Things haven't improved," said Oronto Douglas, one of the more militant of the Ijaw youth leaders and head of the Pan Niger Delta Resistance Movement.

"In some instances they've actually got worse. There is a general belief, especially in the west, that the coming to power of Obasanjo has changed things for the better. I would say he is practising dictatorial democracy.

"It is democracy designed by dictators and run by an ex-dictator for the benefit of the cronies and hangers on."

Compounding the misery is the phenomenon of oil pipeline explosions. A month ago 312 villagers scooping fuel from a burst pipeline deep in the bush at Viri-Court were killed when two wheelbarrows carrying off the plundered oil collided and provided the spark for the blast, which extended almost a mile along the pipe. Trees as far as five miles away were scorched.

An organised racket

The survivors, many of them children with third-degree burns over much of their bodies, can be found in local hospitals. Many others with serious injuries refused to go to hospital, despite the authorities' assurance that they would not be arrested for stealing fuel.

A week later 18 died in a similar blast two miles away. A week after that it was 40 near Sapele. In all, more than 2,000 people have been killed in pipeline explosions in the past two years.

The oil companies accuse villagers of breaching the pipes, either to steal the fuel or to claim compensation for the resulting pollution. But in one recent explosion it was clear that the pipe was so old that it had fallen apart.

There is also evidence of a well-organised racket involving the police, army and employees of the state oil company, the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation. The NNPC concedes as much by saying that it is not easy to breach a pipeline.

"Our engineers have told us that vandalisation of oil pipelines takes a scientific process which ordinary villagers can't engage in," its spokesman, Ndu Ughamadu, said. "There must be well-placed people that have links with this pipeline vandalisation. Where they have located a pipeline they will perforate holes and quietly they will lay pipeline up to one kilometre where they siphon the fuel at will."

The oil is pumped into lorries, sometimes guarded by soldiers, and sold on the black market or driven across the border to places where fuel prices are much higher. When the tankers leave, villagers move in at great risk.

The NNPC's managing director, Jackson Gaius-Obaseki, said the damage extended far beyond those caught in the explosion.

"The fear and mourning are not only for the dead but for millions of Nigerians living in communities around the vandalised sites, who would be inhaling hydrocarbon vapour and would either suffer lung cancer or begin to die gradually."

Eleven communities hit by the recent pipeline explosions, including Viri-Court, are seeking £34m in compensation "We want to let the world know that the fire affected lives and property within a 20-kilometre [12-mile] radius, creating a devastating effect that will last for the next 1,000 years in addition to leaving an everlasting group of widows, widowers and orphans," their spokesman said.

"Our communities suffered the environmental degradation of all streams and rivers. Our main sources of drinking water were severely polluted and all flora and fauna destroyed."

The government has sent paramilitaries to guard the pipelines, but environmental watchdogs accuse them of connivance in the looting, and of killing and raping villagers. The fuel thieves can be just as violent: a month ago a soldier guarding a pipeline near Warri was beheaded by men he tried to stop stealing fuel.

The explosions are a blow to the oil companies' attempts to mend relations with the delta communities. With vast new oil finds about to be exploited, they are keen to end the occupations of oil installations and hostage-taking by youths demanding "compensation" and jobs.

Earlier this month 165 workers, including 20 foreigners, on two Shell drilling rigs were taken hostage. There have been hundreds of similar if smaller cases in recent years. Usually the hostage-takers are paid to go away.

But, for the first time, the companies are also facing effective legal challenges. Shell Nigeria, a consortium which includes Elf, Agip and the NNPC, is appealing against a high court award of 4bn naira (£24m) compensation for a 30 year-old oil spill which has still not been cleaned up.

It says it has long paid compensation for spills, which is true. But the companies know that the money did not go to clean up pollution or benefit the affected communities, but straight into the pockets of the soldiers and politicians.

That suited the army and the companies, which bought their way out of moral and legal responsibility. The companies say times have changed, and so they have. But the people of the delta have yet to be convinced that they will benefit.

There is also evidence of a well-organised racket involving the police, army and employees of the state oil company, the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation. The NNPC concedes as much by saying that it is not easy to breach a pipeline. "Our engineers have told us that vandalisation of oil pipelines takes a scientific process which ordinary villagers can't engage in," its spokesman, Ndu Ughamadu, said. "There must be well-placed people that have links with this pipeline vandalisation. Where they have located a pipeline they will perforate holes and quietly they will lay pipeline up to one kilometre where they siphon the fuel at will." The oil is pumped into lorries, sometimes guarded by soldiers, and sold on the black market or driven across the border to places where fuel prices are much higher. When the tankers leave, villagers move in at great risk. The NNPC's managing director, Jackson Gaius-Obaseki, said the damage extended far beyond those caught in the explosion. "The fear and mourning are not only for the dead but for millions of Nigerians living in communities around the vandalised sites, who would be inhaling hydrocarbon vapour and would either suffer lung cancer or begin to die gradually." Eleven communities hit by the recent pipeline explosions, including Viri-Court, are seeking £34m in compensation "We want to let the world know that the fire affected lives and property within a 20-kilometre [12-mile] radius, creating a devastating effect that will last for the next 1,000 years in addition to leaving an everlasting group of widows, widowers and orphans," their spokesman said. "Our communities suffered the environmental degradation of all streams and rivers. Our main sources of drinking water were severely polluted and all flora and fauna destroyed." The government has sent paramilitaries to guard the pipelines, but environmental watchdogs accuse them of connivance in the looting, and of killing and raping villagers. The fuel thieves can be just as violent: a month ago a soldier guarding a pipeline near Warri was beheaded by men he tried to stop stealing fuel. The explosions are a blow to the oil companies' attempts to mend relations with the delta communities. With vast new oil finds about to be exploited, they are keen to end the occupations of oil installations and hostage-taking by youths demanding "compensation" and jobs. Earlier this month 165 workers, including 20 foreigners, on two Shell drilling rigs were taken hostage. There have been hundreds of similar if smaller cases in recent years. Usually the hostage-takers are paid to go away. But, for the first time, the companies are also facing effective legal challenges. Shell Nigeria, a consortium which includes Elf, Agip and the NNPC, is appealing against a high court award of 4bn naira (£24m) compensation for a 30 year-old oil spill which has still not been cleaned up. It says it has long paid compensation for spills, which is true. But the companies know that the money did not go to clean up pollution or benefit the affected communities, but straight into the pockets of the soldiers and politicians. That suited the army and the companies, which bought their way out of moral and legal responsibility. The companies say times have changed, and so they have. But the people of the delta have yet to be convinced that they will benefit.

fields.headline: Peugeot moves to settle dispute
fields.trailText: Peugeot last night was hoping to settle a row over proposed changes in work practices which has led to a strike threat at the Ryton car plant near Coventry.
fields.body:
Peugeot last night was hoping to settle a row over proposed changes in work practices which has led to a strike threat at the Ryton car plant near Coventry.

The Transport & General Workers' Union said it hoped to put a peace formula to the 2,500 workers today after talks with management produced a softening of the car company's position.

A TGWU spokesman said: "There has been some movement by management and although talks are still continuing and progress is slow we should have something to recommend to members tomorrow."

The dispute blew up two months ago when the French company announced plans to reduce overall weekly working time from 39 to 36.75 hours. Peugeot in return called for compulsory Friday night shifts and various other changes which were recommended by union officials but rejected by the workforce.

In July the Coventry workforce twice went out on 24-hour strikes and threatened to escalate this to an all-out stoppage when it came back from its summer break this week.

The strike was averted when Peugeot agreed to postpone implementation of the new work shifts for three weeks and to hold talks with unions starting last Monday.

The TGWU has argued this week that only dropping Friday night working could prevent the row escalating. It declined to say yesterday how the company had compromised and Peugeot was unavailable for comment.

Even though the union is close to agreement with Peugeot there can be no guarantee the workers will accept it.

webTitle: Four die as blast shakes Burundi

fields.headline: Four die as blast shakes Burundi
fields.trailText: A hand grenade exploded in a crowded market in central Bujumbura yesterday, killing at least four people and injuring 50 as tensions in Burundi rose as the deadline approached for the signing of a peace accord.
fields.body:
A hand grenade exploded in a crowded market in central Bujumbura yesterday, killing at least four people and injuring 50 as tensions in Burundi rose as the deadline approached for the signing of a peace accord.

Soldiers and police sealed off the Buyenzi market, where witnesses saw someone throw the grenade from a nearby bus station at the mainly Hutu traders.

"I heard an explosion and everybody ducked. I saw one person die; other people had their legs cut off," said Patrick Nduwimana, a 16-year-old Hutu waiting to be treated for a leg injury at King Khaled hospital.

Three people were killed instantly and another person died later, doctors said.

It was not clear who was responsible for the attack, but it bore the trademark of Tutsi militia, many of whom have links to hardline Tutsi political parties.

The former South African president, Nelson Mandela, who has been mediating in the talks since December, has invited President Bill Clinton and other world leaders to witness the signing of the accord in the northern Tanzanian town of Arusha next Monday.

The 10 Tutsi political parties said on Tuesday that they would not sign the agreement which they consider favours the Hutu majority, and President Pierre Buyoya has asked Mr Mandela for a postponement.

Hutu rebels have also rejected the agreement. They have been fighting the Tutsi-dominated army since 1993, when Tutsi paratroopers assassinated the first democratically elected president, a Hutu.

The agreement requires the minority Tutsis to relinquish power in the government and army and set up ethnically balanced institutions.

More than 200,000 people have died since 1993. Hutu rebels have recently stepped up attacks on military targets, and the army said it has been fighting off attacks on the outskirts of Bujumbura since last week. Associated Press

webTitle: Letters: Polar ice funding trickles in

fields.headline: Polar ice funding trickles in
fields.trailText: Your front-page headline and first paragraph yesterday (Polar data left unused) give the false impression that data on ice thickness released to us by the Navy are lying unused for lack of funding
fields.body:
Your front-page headline and first paragraph yesterday (Polar data left unused) give the false impression that data on ice thickness released to us by the Navy are lying unused for lack of funding from Natural Environment Research Council (NERC) for data processing. The comment which I made to your reporter was that we have received funding for 18 months to begin the processing of these data, with the likelihood that further funding may follow.

It is certainly the case that the vital task of collecting and processing critical data on global change requires long-term funding support, rather than short-term grants, because of the need for salary support to retain the skills of experienced people in a research team, and the fact that the changes being mapped are progressive and require successive field expeditions for their measurement. In this respect there has been a problem with funding agencies (not just NERC), which tend to shy away from long-term support for such areas of research. It is fair to say that these attitudes are changing.

Dr Peter Wadhams, Scott Polar Research Institute, University of Cambridge

fields.headline: Fat cats thin out
fields.trailText: Ruth Lea of the Institute of Directors says of top executive pay: "There is a shortage of these people. There has been quite a catastrophic turnover" (Lea defends 'pay madness', August 23). Why?
fields.body:
Ruth Lea of the Institute of Directors says of top executive pay: "There is a shortage of these people. There has been quite a catastrophic turnover" (Lea defends 'pay madness', August 23). Why? I haven't heard of dozens of fat cats dying with their boots on. Could it be that large numbers of them are getting the push (Greenbury, Ayling etc) when their feet of clay are discovered? Maybe they are on such huge salaries, they just take the money and run?

IJ Gibson, Ullapool, Ross-shire

Jonathan Freedland's claim (August 23) that unionist and Conservative politicians "rarely made a squeak about the armed men of loyalism" in the 1990s is inaccurate. The Tory party, UUP and DUP publicly and regularly criticised unionist paramilitarism.

Duncan Gardner, London

I was disappointed to see on your front page (August 23) that the Union flag hanging behind the vehemently British Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair's right shoulder was upside down.

Tim Kay, Egham, Surrey

Who says women are the weaker sex at sport (Fighting back, G2, August 21)? Our greatest female cyclist, Beryl Burton, broke the men's 12-hour record in 1967 with 277.25 miles - three-quarters of a mile better than the men's record.

Mary Dawson, Stockton on Tees

Heartening to hear that my success in life, compared with my female peers, has been enhanced by all the time I have spent drinking and playing sport rather than working (Letters, August 23). I feel vindicated to continue.

Tom Wilcox, London

I've tried that argument but my wife didn't fall for it.

Stephen Lane, Clonee, Co Meath

webTitle: Letters: War resumes over Kosovan dead

fields.headline: War resumes over Kosovan dead
fields.trailText: While there was undoubtedly much confusion, hearsay and hype during the Kosovo conflict, to accuse the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and myself in particular of manipulating the facts is dead wrong (The propaganda war, August 21)
fields.body:
While there was undoubtedly much confusion, hearsay and hype during the Kosovo conflict, to accuse the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and myself in particular of manipulating the facts is dead wrong (The propaganda war, August 21)

On the Kosovo-Macedonian border, reporters were usually denied immediate access to the new refugee arrivals at Blace. UNHCR would thus convey refugee reports to the scores of media gathered at a police checkpoint about 250 metres from the frontier. And we would always do so, as Audrey Gillan notes, with the warning that there was no way UNHCR could independently verify the refugee accounts.

In the case of the villages around Lipljan, the similar reports given us by several refugees was later repeated by dozens more witnesses who were interviewed by the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) and by the media.

Audrey Gillan cites the OSCE as a reliable source. I therefore suggest that she and interested readers exam ine the OSCE's own subsequent report (www.osce.org) on what it describes as the "brutal expulsions and killings" of mid-April 1999 in a cluster of villages surrounding the town of Lipljan - Sllovi (Serb name: Slovinje), Hallac I Vogel (Mali Alas) and Ribar I Vogel (Malo Ribare). The accounts collected by OSCE are very similar to the initial refugee arrival reports UNHCR conveyed to reporters at the border.

Nearly 40 people subsequently told OSCE interviewers that between 79 and 200 people were killed in the above three villages between April 15 and 18, 1999. OSCE also quotes interviewees as saying that more murders "and many cases of sexual violence" were described in other villages around Lipljan through till April 20.

OSCE eventually received a total of 39 statements, 35 of them from actual witnesses or victims, describing events in Sllovi/Slovinje on April 15-16 in gruesome detail.They concluded that "a figure of 33 seems entirely plausible" in Sllovi/Slovinje. Moreover, in a May 2, 1999 story datelined Blace, the Associated Press quoted its own refugee witnesses on the alleged killings of 32 people in Sllovi/Slovinje on April 15.

And the Guardian itself carried news of the Sllovi/Slovinje killings on June 25, 1999, when it reported the arrest by British military police of a man suspected in the April 16-17 "massacre of 46 ethnic Albanians in Slovinje".

Ms Gillan implies that the refugee arrival accounts conveyed by UNHCR were "exaggerations for very calculated ends". This is unfair and unfounded. UNHCR prides itself on its impartiality; decades of experience tell us that refugees usually tell the terrible truth.

Ron Redmond, UNHCR, Geneva

A number of crucial questions remain unanswered. First, how many of the 2,788 bodies exhumed actually shows evidence of being massacred and, second, by whom? Third, bearing in mind that the definition of a mass grave is one which contains three bodies or more, we are also entitled to know more about the conditions of burial.

When the International Criminal Tribunal released its interim findings about exhumations in November 1999, no breakdown was given of ethnic origin or manner of death. Yet we know that some of the bodies uncovered were Serbs, and chief prosecutor Carla Del Ponte had admitted that the perpetrators included the Kosovo Liberation Army. We also learned from the forensic team which investigated Istok that many of the bodies disinterred there contained shrapnel from Nato bombs.

Carol Turner, Committee for Peace in the Balkans

Around 80,000 Albanians were driven from their homes between Christmas 1998 and March 1999. I was working in a rural part of Kosovo. A quick audit of my patients shows that in the six months before air strikes, members of seven families had witnessed 42 deaths of unarmed civilians at the hands of Serbian security forces. That figure does not include second-hand accounts, men in combat, or civilians killed by shelling. Most of the deaths occurred in small groups, and the bodies are conventionally buried in single, not mass, graves. I was just one doctor in four villages. My patients were terrified to leave their homes, and terrified to stay. They had no jobs and they could not till their land.

Can those opposed to the use of force suggest another course of action that would have brought the violence to an end? I long to hear it. The "non-violent" use of sanctions against Iraq has cost far more lives than Nato bombing. Though, yes, the military intervention should have been conducted in a different manner

There are more significant questions to ask today: Why can't the international community invest the same financial and political effort that it put into military intervention, in creating a stable peace. Paying public servants decent wages prevents corruption. It is institution building, not premature elections that creates democracy. Further, fudging the issue of Kosovo's future status feeds extremists on both sides who continue to use terror as a means of creating facts on the ground.

Finally, how is reconciliation possible without an end to impunity and the arrest of those most responsible?

Dr Lynne Jones, Cambridge lmj21@cam.ac.uk

fields.headline: Sick leave
fields.trailText: We get around six patients a week not turning up for their appointments (Absent patients costing NHS, August 22).
fields.body:
We get around six patients a week not turning up for their appointments (Absent patients costing NHS, August 22). This is the time I have to catch up if late, do referral letters, have a coffee, read the post, chat to staff, ring those who need ringing and put my feet up when stressed. I don't regard any of these activities as costing the NHS and the next patient gets a far happier doctor.

Dr John Sampson, Poringland, Norfolk woodton@easynet.co.uk

So, 52% of GPs want to charge patients for missed appointments. I am happy to pay if GPs will refund me if I am kept waiting in the surgery.

Henry Thompson, Harrogate, North Yorks henry.wh.thompson@bt.com

fields.headline: Literary sex
fields.trailText: Kim Blake is right about prostitutes having no power (Letters, August 22). But the phrase "prerogative of the harlot" was almost certainly given to Baldwin by his cousin, Rudyard Kipling
fields.body:
Kim Blake is right about prostitutes having no power (Letters, August 22). But the phrase "prerogative of the harlot" was almost certainly given to Baldwin by his cousin, Rudyard Kipling, who learnt about such matters in the different moral climate of India. In his story, On the City Wall, the prostitute Lalun is respected. She adopts a nationalist stance by refusing to allow English to be spoken in her Lahore brothel, which doubles as a literary and political salon. And she can trade bawdy Persian verses "with a triple pun in every other line".

Andrew Lycett, Author, Rudyard Kipling

webTitle: Letters: Listening to the voice of the consumer

fields.headline: Listening to the voice of the consumer
fields.trailText: Any rebranding of the Department of Trade and Industry (Towards a second term, August 21) should not forget a crucial element in the success of the UK economy: the UK's 60m consumers who spend over £400bn a year on goods and services.
fields.body:
Any rebranding of the Department of Trade and Industry (Towards a second term, August 21) should not forget a crucial element in the success of the UK economy: the UK's 60m consumers who spend over £400bn a year on goods and services. Crucial to a successful business environment is ensuring consumers feel confident to deal in the market place and are sufficiently protected when they do.

Significant steps have been taken. The government has reformed competition laws, improved the rules that protect consumers from unfair terms in contracts and given a stronger consumer focus to energy regulation. We are hoping for a bill in the Queen's Speech to toughen laws for dealing with cowboy traders. Significantly, the government published the first consumer white paper for more than 20 years.

Victor Keegan is right to highlight communications. But the next stage is to broaden the focus of the department's activities. If anything, the DTI should be rebranded the Department for Consumers and Industry.

Andrew Barnett, National Consumer Council

In a converging and rapidly changing communications industry, it is important that the consumer voice is heard across all communications sectors. Victor Keegan proposes turning off the analogue television signal as soon as possible, but government must balance the interests of consumers and industry. Forcing all consumers to pay for costly new equipment to receive extra services they may not want would not be the action of a responsible government.

Analogue switch-off and more competition in telecommunications, following local loop unbundling, are signs of the pace of change in the industry. They also point to a third urgent policy initiative. The DTI should set up a dedicated Communications Consumer Council to ensure that a strong and clear consumer voice is heard amid the industry clamour as UK communications converge. This should be central to the government's long-anticipated communications white paper, which is likely to shape the future of the industry.

Michelle Childs, Consumers' Association

webTitle: Leader: There is no quick route to male/female equality

fields.headline: The mending of men
fields.standfirst: There is no quick route to equality at home
fields.trailText: Work-life balance was a little known concept at the start of the 90s. By the end of the decade it was tripping off the tongue of every politician, policy-maker and commentator. It labelled one of the most prevalent forms of millennial angst: that while Britain may have achieved low inflation growth, it had paid a heavy price in terms of the well-being of our families and ourselves.

Work-life balance was a little known concept at the start of the 90s. By the end of the decade it was tripping off the tongue of every politician, policy-maker and commentator. It labelled one of the most prevalent forms of millennial angst: that while Britain may have achieved low inflation growth, it had paid a heavy price in terms of the well-being of our families and ourselves. We worried that we had the highest divorce rate and the longest working hours in Europe, and that the two statistics were linked. Beyond them, lay worse: the highest number of single parents and the largest proportion of children living in poverty.

There has been no shortage of genuine concern within the government. Harriet Harman was at the forefront of initiatives to ease the pressures on working mothers. That is what makes her leaked memo yesterday, warning of the difficulties of extending parental leave for small businesses, all the more surprising. One never expected Ms Harman to be the one to call for a slow-down. But her old friend, Patricia Hewitt at the Department of Trade and Industry, is under acute pressure from small businesses ahead of the green paper on parental rights due in the autumn.

Ms Harman's concerns are taken further in an Industrial Society pamphlet, "Mothers versus men", published yesterday. It argues that the current structure of maternity leave can backfire, opening women up to discrimination. Prospective employers can be deterred from employing, training or promoting women because of the costs and inconveniences of their maternity rights. This is where the pattern of discrimination sets in, setting men and women on radically different career trajectories, which results in the stubborn 20% pay gap between women and men. Motherhood, it concludes, carries a heavy penalty in earning power.

The solution to inequality in the workplace, the pamphlet claims, is to institute equality in the home. Everything else has been tried to reduce the pay gap the equal pay act, corporate and government initiatives... Now, we must go radical. The priority for campaigners, it argues, should be to equalise parental rights rather than extending maternity rights. Only when men are encouraged to take a fuller role in the care of children - equality in the home - will there be equality in the workplace. And to ensure that the message gets out loud and clear from the top of every organisation, the government should offer 90% of take home pay even to top executives for six weeks' parental leave. Level the playing field.

This is wonderful stuff. The kids would love dad around. What woman would not love her partner to pitch in, keep track of the children's inoculations, remember their PE kit - in short, apply some of their management skills to their home life? If men devoted as much time and energy to parenting as women do, it would certainly undermine patterns of discrimination and revolutionise our work culture into becoming less pressurised and more family-friendly. But this thinking is close to utopian. It ignores a quickening global economy and technological change which have considerably increased the pressures on employees. It overlooks the choices men are making every day to work long hours, thus missing the school-run and bathtime: male identity is still powerfully linked to the competitiveness and ambition of the office. Until that alters, giving men generous paternity leave instead of extending women's maternity leave would be a waste of legislative effort.

fields.headline: Nancy Evans
fields.trailText: The English mezzo-soprano Nancy Evans, who has died aged 85, was an accomplished and professional artist admired by Benjamin Britten, who wrote several pieces for her, including his song-cycle, A Charm of Lullabies.
fields.body:
The English mezzo-soprano Nancy Evans, who has died aged 85, was an accomplished and professional artist admired by Benjamin Britten, who wrote several pieces for her, including his song-cycle, A Charm of Lullabies.

Evans was educated at Calder High School, Liverpool and took her first singing lessons with John Tobin. She had further tuition from Maggie Teyte, a singer favoured by Debussy, and Eva de Reusz. She made her recital debut in her home town, a day after her 18th birthday, and a year later performed for the first time in London, accompanied by Gerald Moore.

Four years later, in 1938, she made it to the dramatic stage when she appeared in a production at the Princes Theatre, London, of the now almost-forgotten operetta, The Rose of Persia, by Basil Hood and Sir Arthur Sullivan. In 1939, she first appeared at the Royal Opera House in minor roles, having already sung in the chorus at Glyndebourne.

During the war, Nancy Evans was a stalwart of ENSA (Entertainments National Services Association), singing for servicemen and women in unlikely venues throughout Europe and the Middle East. Then, in 1946, she became part of the fledgling English Opera Group, which had been created by Benjamin Britten, the painter John Piper, and the author and librettist Eric Crozier, whom Evans was to marry in 1949 (her first marriage had been to record producer Walter Legge).

Her first major part was in Britten's two-act chamber opera, The Rape of Lucretia, where she shared the title role with Kathleen Ferrier. In 1947, she created the character of Nancy in Britten's next opera, Albert Herring, and then appeared as Polly Peachum in his original adaptation of The Beggar's Opera. In 1951, she was Dido in Britten's realisation of Purcell's Dido and Aeneas, and the following year she created another new part, Lucinda Woodcock in Arthur Oldham's modern version of Thomas Arne's ballad opera Love in a Village. This was first performed by the English Opera Group on the BBC's Third Programme, and soon after became an Aldeburgh Festival production.

However, her work took her beyond the Britten circle. For Glyndebourne, she appeared in the 1957 production of Mozart's The Magic Flute, and a couple of years later, as Annina in Richard Strauss's Der Rosenkavalier; she performed in highly-praised recordings of both works. She never lost her taste for musical adventure and created eight roles in Malcolm Williamson's two-act opera, The Growing Castle, first performed in Dynevor Castle, South Wales, in 1968.

Evans was as much lauded in recitals and concerts as in the opera house. She was a versatile performer with a catholic taste in music; but it was as an interpreter of the French and 20th-century English song repertoire that she was best-known. In 1948, she premiered A Charm of Lullabies at the Holland Festival; in 1944, she had been the soloist in the first performance of Malcolm Sargent's orchestration of Brahms's Four Serious Songs.

She was a regular guest artist at the Proms and performed at major musical festivals. In later life, she devoted much of her time to training young singers through her work at the Britten-Pears School in Aldeburgh.

It is difficult not to see her early career as having been overshadowed by the magnificent Kathleen Ferrier. Both women were good friends and had a high regard for each other's work. If she never really reached the heights of celebrity singers, it is no reflection on her outstanding abilities. She was an excellent creative artist, loved and respected by fellow musicians and audiences.

She is survived by a daughter from her first marriage.

Nancy Evans, opera singer, born March 19 1915; died August 20 2000

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: The actress Caroline Quentin featured in a Parents piece yesterday about having children in close succession, G2, page 8. A picture showed her at an awards event with the costume designer James Baylan. A caption said that he (misspelled as Bayland) was her partner, which he is not. We apologise to both people in the photo and to their respective partners.
fields.body:
The actress Caroline Quentin featured in a Parents piece yesterday about having children in close succession, G2, page 8. A picture showed her at an awards event with the costume designer James Baylan. A caption said that he (misspelled as Bayland) was her partner, which he is not. We apologise to both people in the photo and to their respective partners.

Yesterday's Sport story on the Arsenal Football Club player Patrick Vieira, page 32, was accompanied by a photo purporting to show him being sent off in a match against Liverpool at Highbury on Monday night. The picture was, in fact, from 1998 when the same referee sent him off in a Chelsea match. Arsenal's sponsor has since changed from JVC to Dreamcast.

A heading for Inside Story, G2, page 4, yesterday referred to "Hollywood's only publically acknowledged lesbian couple". The word is publicly. In the same edition's broadsheet, page 2, two-minute Guardian flagged our inquiry into "boardroom renumeration". Remuneration, that is.

It was wrongly said in an article on page 3 yesterday that Sir Richard Branson held the Blue Riband for the fastest sea crossing of the Atlantic. His 1986 bid did break the record, but because he refuelled three times, he was held to have broken the terms and did not get the prize.

The name of the founder of the Webbys, the main awards ceremony for the internet, was misspelled on page 8, Online, August 10. She is Tiffany Shlain, not Schlain.

Our story on the depletion of Atlantic fish stocks, pages 1-3, August 14, referred to Wolof as a local dialect in Senegal. It is in fact a language, part of the northern branch of the west Atlantic sub-family of the Niger-Congo language family.

In our article on last year's EgyptAir crash (August 18, page 14), we said that in a transcript of the cockpit recording the co-pilot, Gamil al-Batouti, asked: "What's happening?" The speaker was the captain, Ahmed al-Habashi.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Gilbert Parkhouse
fields.trailText: Gilbert Parkhouse, who has died aged 74, was one of the most elegant and talented Welsh-born batsmen, perhaps the best, ever to play for Glamorgan.
fields.body:
Gilbert Parkhouse, who has died aged 74, was one of the most elegant and talented Welsh-born batsmen, perhaps the best, ever to play for Glamorgan.

He made seven Test appearances and, despite the formidable competition from the top order at the time, might have enjoyed greater recognition.

His career with Glamorgan, of 435 matches, extended from 1948-64. He scored more than 1,000 runs in his first season, when Glamorgan won the championship against most predictions. It was often said that the county succeeded because of its brilliantly pre-planned close-fielding; most of the catches went to the leg-trap, orchestrated by Wilf Wooller, though Parkhouse, not long out of national service, revealed exceptionally safe hands at first slip. Indeed, he went on to take, in all, 324 catches.

But it was his batting that rapidly earned acclaim as he was promoted from No 3 to open. There was a technical refinement about his shots: the crisp driving, powerful cutting and studied leg deflections. And he took on fast bowlers with a visible relish, leaning back to hook them to distant parts, not just at the old Arms Park or his native St Helens at Swansea (where once he also played rugby).

Fifteen times in a row, he passed 1,000 runs in a season, and his total career aggregate was 23,508 (average 31.68). Stands with Emrys Davies and Bernard Hedges are still warmly recalled. England's selectors were made to realise that his constant high scoring (32 hundreds in total) could not be ignored. What was more, he was able to play spinners as adeptly as the fast men.

His Test appearances had their disappointments, but a good-looking 69 against the West Indies at Trent Bridge ensured a place on the 1950-51 tour of Australia and New Zealand, where poor health and injury worked against him. He played in three Tests, and was then discarded until 1959, when he was selected twice against India, scoring 78 at Leeds. But it was not enough to convince the selectors again.

At the crease, Parkhouse was a neat, rather than robust, figure. Some of his team mates, while much admiring his qualities as a batsman and team-member, never quite knew what to make of him as an individual. He had been educated at Wycliffe, an English public school, and there was little trace of a Welsh accent in his voice. He has been variously described as "erudite", "quiet", "perhaps not the easiest person to integrate into the dressing room", "very confident, even veering to arrogance when it came to fast bowlers; he'd try at times to make them look silly and that could occasionally rebound on him..."

One colleague, Phil Clift, remembers: "Gilbert was a great eater and he still didn't put on a pound. He'd also come back after making a 100 and never perspire. We couldn't understand it. When he returned from the Australian tour, he barely mentioned it, though others would have been full of their experiences."

Parkhouse was a self-contained man, not one of cricket's drinkers. He was sensitive, and without ever being in the least boastful, knew his worth. Once when Glamorgan had lost a match and Wooller was berating them, Parkhouse, captaining the county that day, turned to the volatile secretary and said: "I'll have you know, Mr Wooller, that I've played for England."

Several times, too, after Glamorgan had been set a demanding target by the opposition on the last day, Wooller would say to Parkhouse: "We're not going for them: block it out." But Parkhouse and Hedges would gradually discover, as the score grew, that they were in with a chance, and they went on to win. "Wilf would then take all the credit, despite his earlier instructions." There was a touch of resentment in his tone.

Parkhouse was a good hockey player who represented Wales as well as Swansea, and a keen golfer. After giving up cricket as a player, he briefly coached Worcestershire, and for more than 20 years was cricket coach at Stewarts Melville College in Edinburgh. He leaves a wife, Dorothy, a son and a daughter. He was a true Glamorgan star.

William Gilbert Anthony Parkhouse, cricketer, born October 12 1925; died August 10 2000.

webTitle: Leader: Why does Britain neglect its scientists?

fields.headline: Second-class heroes
fields.standfirst: Why does Britain neglect its scientists?
fields.trailText: Imagine that Sir Isaac Newton's Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica were a book of poetry, or perhaps an early novel, and not the greatest work of one of the greatest scientists of all time. Would his personal letters and notebooks have been allowed to gather dust in the Earl of Macclesfield's stately home for 300 years?
fields.body:
Imagine that Sir Isaac Newton's Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica were a book of poetry, or perhaps an early novel, and not the greatest work of one of the greatest scientists of all time. Would his personal letters and notebooks have been allowed to gather dust in the Earl of Macclesfield's stately home for 300 years? Almost certainly not, for Britain has always been more ready to honour a second-division poet than a first-division scientist. Of the 3,000-odd people commemorated in Westminster Abbey, only 27 won their place through science (or just over 40 if engineers are included). In contrast, poet's corner has room for over 100.

That makes it all the more heartening that a newly disinterred archive of Sir Isaac's private papers is likely to go to Cambridge University - though the university needs to find enough extra money to supplement a £4.79m grant from the National Lottery. There are working notes here from the most fruitful period of Sir Isaac's life - the early years, when his discoveries included calculus and many of the basic rules of physics. Sir Isaac, though, has always been one of Britain's chosen scientific few thanks to his media-friendly observations under an apple tree. Others have fared less well. Charles Babbage, the inventor of the mechanical computer, is commemorated only by a half-completed calculating machine in the Science Museum. Sir Frank Whittle, inventor of the jet engine, at least got a knighthood. Edward Jenner, the pioneer of vaccination, was not even granted that. And while Haworth Parsonage and Rydal Mount are places of pilgrimage for devotees of Britain's great writers, Down House, where Charles Darwin wrote the Origin of Species, rotted for years, neglected. English Heritage is to be congratulated for saving it at last.

Why, when Britain has produced so many world-changing scientists, do we overlook them like this? Perhaps it is because of the progressive nature of science itself. Michael Faraday's astounding work on electricity laid the path for a century of progress towards the digital age, but his findings have still been superseded by later work by lesser men. Beowulf or Macbeth, in contrast, retain their originality and genius for all the poems and plays written since. But that means the case for commemorating our scientists is all the greater. Let us hope Cambridge's acquisition of these historic papers is just the start.

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Rosemary Stewart writes: I was fortunate to count Anne Mueller (obituary, August 1) as a friend. Two of her major interests were art and gardening.
fields.body:
Rosemary Stewart writes: I was fortunate to count Anne Mueller (obituary, August 1) as a friend. Two of her major interests were art and gardening.

Despite being so busy, she found time to be knowledgable, active and discerning. Her own small London garden was a model of what can be achieved in unpromising circumstances. Later her flat, and its balconies, were like being in a garden. Art and flowers provided the background for her dinners: she was an excellent host. But her taste was much broader than the landscapes on her walls, as she served as a trustee of the Whitechapel Art Gallery for 10 years.
